audioDescription: The Grizzly Giant accessible trailhead is located at the northwest end of a large accessible parking lot. A paved path leads to the right. A map, three green recycle bins, three brown trash bins, a split log used as a bench, and a small, brown, wood structure that houses vault toilets, line the paved walkway on the north side of the lot. At the trailhead, a wooden sign reads, Grizzly Giant 0.1 mile. The trail begins on a dirt road then continues on a paved, accessible trail to the left of the road. The path clears an opening in the forest and leads directyl to a large giant sequoia that is noticeably larger than all the surround trees, off in the distance. The trail is lined with boulders, a simple wood fence, and a few wayside exhibits.

title: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center
listingDescription: The Happy Isles Art and Nature Center is a family-oriented space designed for nature and art lovers of all ages. The center is open April through October and offers natural history exhibits, interactive displays, and art workshops with professional artists. Nearby, short trails focus on the area's four different environments: forest, river, talus, and fen. You can also see substantial evidence of the huge 1996 rockfall from the Glacier Point cliff far above the nature center.

images.altText: A single story building with a steeply pitched roof and river rock exterior walls
images.title: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center
images.caption: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center

bodyText:
The Happy Isles Art and Nature Center is a family-oriented space designed for nature and art lovers of all ages. The center offers natural history exhibits, interactive displays, and art workshops.

Nearby, short trails focus on the area's four different environments: forest, river, talus, and fen. You can also see substantial evidence of the huge 1996 rockfall from the Glacier Point cliff far above the nature center.

Yosemite Conservancy Art Programs
Join Yosemite Conservancy for a range of activities at the Yosemite Conservancy Bookstore at Happy Isles Art and Nature Center. Learn from a professional artist, drop in for a kids' activity, browse supplies and original artwork, and more.

Yosemite Conservancy bookstores are your best source for information on Yosemite. Browse the shelves for art supplies, guidebooks, gifts, apparel and more.

Daily art classes for teens and adults are taught by volunteer instructors in the summer, and are typically held outside, for a fee. Instructed classes for children ages 2 to 12 are also offered for free. To learn more and register:

  • Visit yosemiteconservancy.org/art
  • Contact us at 209/372-0631 or artcenter@yosemiteconservancy.org

Hours

April through October
9 am to 4 pm

Getting Here

Located in Happy Isles, a short walk from shuttle stop 16. Follow signs for Happy Isles Art and Nature Center. There is no parking in the immediate area.

Accessibility

This facility is accessible. Limited designated accessible parking spaces are available nearby.
audioDescription:
From shuttle stop 16, a paved side path, lined with several types of trees and bushes, leads past the restrooms, to the Happy Isle Art and Nature Center. Along the way, another paved path intersects and leads to the isles in the river to the left and toward the Fen to the right. As you approach the stone and timber building, the American flag waves on a tall flagpole to the right side of the path, and a wooden sign on the left reads, Happy Isles Nature Center, explore the world of nature. The building has stone siding and high-pitched wooden rooves.

A large sign near the entrance of the building reads, let nature inspire your curiosity and creativity here beside the Merced River. Outside, observe the wonders all around you: tranquil trees, rushing water, a lush fen, and rocky slopes. Look for signs of wildlife along the river. Can you spot tracks in the earth, or birds winging overhead?

When the center is open, step inside to enjoy family friendly programs, explore fascinating ecosystems and create your own park-inspired artwoork with Yosemite Conservancy. See postings for seasonal hours and art program schedule or visit yosemiteconservancy.org.

A collage of photos show a painting of Half Dome using warm colors to indicate the alpenglow, a female ranger holding a coyote pelt and a replica of a animal skull while a young girl is amazed and has her mouth open. Another photo shows a person painting on an easel with watercolor paints. Lastly, a bird with a deep orange breast and black crown has black wings and tail that are speckled with white.

A wayside exhibit titled, A Place for Small Fry, is also on the path near the building. The exhibit panel has a faint, green-toned, background photo of a stone building on the banks of a river. Panel text reads, the Nature Center at Happy Isles is often filled with curious children, but the building once teemed with a different kind of "small fry" - baby trout! Built in 1927, the building housed a fish hatchery for thirty years. Since its conversion to a nature center in 1956, thousands of visitors have learned about the wonders of Yosemite's natural world in this rustic building.

Black and white photo 1: A man holds up a small girl from behind so she can look into a microscope on an exhibits table.

Caption: Children and adults alike enjoy the Nature Center's exhibits.

Black and white photo 2: Next to a tree-lined body of water, a man on a horse holds a rope that is attached to another horse that walks behind him. A small bundle is on the horse's back.

Caption: Transporting trout fingerlings from the fish hatchery to the high country, 1942.

passportStampImages.altText: A green circular stamp contains text that reads Yosemite National Park, Happy Isles Nature Center.
passportStampImages.title: Happy Isles Nature Center Passport Stamp

title: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center Architecture

images.altText: A single story building with a steeply pitched roof and river rock exterior walls
images.title: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center
images.caption: Happy Isles Art and Nature Center

bodyText:
The building that now houses the Happy Isles Art & Nature Center was originally constructed in 1927. The state of California operated a fish hatchery in the building to stock lakes and streams for recreational fishing. The hatchery was shut down in 1956 and the National Park Service took ownership of the building.

In subsequent years, the building and surrounding area was developed into a visitor information center, and eventually the art and nature center it is today.

The building was constructed during the rustic era and displays numerous features similar to other rustic park buildings such as the museum and administration building in the village. The walls of the building are inlaid with river rocks and several aspects feature rough-hewn log accents.

title: Harden Lake Trailhead
listingDescription:
Admire the views as you hike through a pine forest and pass by small granite domes before reaching boulder-dotted Harden Lake.

Hike along a gravel road-part of the original Tioga Road-that follows the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River for part of the route. At a trail junction 1.75 miles (2.8 km) down the road, follow the signs to the lake.

Harden Lake (Moderate)
5.8 miles (9.3 km) round trip; 2-4 hours,
355-foot (122-m) elevation gain on the
return trip.

Hours :
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here :
Begin across from White Wolf Lodge. If the road to White Wolf is closed, add at least two additional miles, roundtrip, to these hikes.

Rules & Regulations :
- Stay on established trails
- Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
- Pack out what you pack in
- Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
- Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
- Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
- Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings :
- Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
- Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
- Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility :
This trail is not accessible.

images.altText: Trees surround a lake and reflect in its waters.

audioDescription: The trailhead to Harden Lake begins across the street from the White Wolf Lodge front office building. There is a row of parking spaces that are lined with tall pine trees. The trail begins near the center of the parking row and enters into the forest. Two trailhead signs are posted. The first sign is brown with white text and shows the mileage of several hiking destinations that begin at this trailhead. The sign reads, Lukens Lake - 2.3, Harden Lake - 5.7, Ten Lakes - 9.7, Pate Valley - 10.4, Smith Meadows - 11.1, Yosemite Valley - 13.9, Hetch Hetchy - 17.0. The other sign is also brown with white text and lists wilderness regulations. The sign reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

title: Hetch Hetchy Entrance
listingDescription: Hidden in Yosemite National Park's peaceful northwest corner, Hetch Hetchy Valley is a treasure worth visiting in all seasons. Located at 3,900 feet, Hetch Hetchy boasts one of the longest hiking seasons in the park and is an ideal place for thundering spring waterfalls and wildflower displays. The Hetch Hetchy Road is open from 8 am - 5 pm.

images.altText: Small wooden building with American flag on pole
images.title: Hetch Hetchy Entrance
images.caption: Hetch Hetchy Entrance

bodyText:
Hidden in Yosemite National Park's peaceful northwest corner, Hetch Hetchy Valley is a treasure worth visiting in all seasons.

The Hetch Hetchy Road has seasonal hours corresponding roughly with daylight hours. There is no access to Hetch Hetchy trailheads when the road is closed.

The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased, wilderness permits are issued, and brochures are available here.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome). See website to check trailhead availability and for more information on how to make a reservation.

Entrance Fees

(valid for seven days with receipt)

  • Private vehicle: $35 (no per-person fee)
  • Motorcycle: $30 (no per-person fee)
  • Individual (walk-in, bicycle, horse, in a bus): $20 per person, aged 16 or older

Passes

  • Yosemite Pass: $70
    Valid for one year in Yosemite.
  • Interagency Annual Pass: $80
    Valid for one year at all federal recreation sites.
  • Interagency Senior Pass: $80
    (Lifetime) For U.S. citizens or permanent residents 62 and over.
  • Interagency Annual Senior Pass: $20
    For U.S. citizens or permanent residents 62 and over.
  • Interagency Access Pass (Free)
    (Lifetime) For permanently disabled U.S. citizens or permanent residents.
  • Interagency Military Pass (Free)
    (Annual) For active duty U.S. military and dependents.
  • Interagency 4th Grade Pass (Free)
    (Annual) For fourth graders and their families. Must present paper voucher. For paper voucher and more information visit

See website for more details.

Hours

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open only during daylight hours, from sunrise to sunset. 

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (1,1) for current road conditions.

Getting Here

Hetch Hetchy is located 1 hour, 15 minutes from Yosemite Valley. The Hetch Hetchy Road begins just outside the park on Highway 120, near the Big Oak Flat Entrance.

Warnings

There is no public transportation to Hetch Hetchy.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.
audioDescription: One inbound lane and one outbound lane are on each side of a small wooden kiosk that has a cobblestone base at the Hetch Hetchy Entrance. The National Park Service logo is placed above the windows on the kiosk. The logo consists of a downward pointing arrowhead, a sequoia tree, a mountain range, a lake, a bison, and text that reads National Park Service. A flag pole waving the American Flag is located in front of the kiosk. A small knee-height triangular sign reads U.S. Fee Area and has the National Park Service logo. Another sign, posted on the front side of the kiosk reads Hetch Hetchy Entrance, Elevation 4,750 feet. A white dry erase board on the side of the kiosk shows the local weather forecast. The kiosk is heavily shaded with the number of trees surrounding it.

passportStampImages.altText: A green circular stamp contains text that reads Yosemite National Park, Hetch Hetchy, CA.
passportStampImages.title: Hetch Hetchy Passport Stamp

title: Hetch Hetchy Reservoir - O'Shaugnessy Dam
listingDescription: Stand on the O'Shaughnessy Dam and ask yourself, where does my drinking water come from? This reservoir currently supplies drinking water to 2.7 million San Francisco Bay Area residents.After parking your vehicle, take a short walk onto the O'Shaughnessy Dam to get views of the reservoir and two waterfalls, Tueeulala Fall and Wapama Fall, in the distance.

images.altText: Reservoir with granite features on all sides, flowers and a butterfly in foreground
images.title: Hetch Hetchy Reservoir
images.caption: Hetch Hetchy Reservoir

bodyText:
Stand on the O'Shaughnessy Dam and ask yourself, where does my drinking water come from? This reservoir currently supplies drinking water to 2.7 million San Francisco Bay Area residents.

After parking your vehicle, take a short walk to the O'Shaughnessy Dam to get views of the reservoir and two waterfalls, Tueeulala Fall and Wapama Fall.

The O'Shaughnessy Dam (named for the chief engineer) was completed in 1938. Today, this 117-billion-gallon reservoir supplies pristine drinking water to 2.7 million Bay Area residents and industrial users. It also supplies hydro-electric power generated by two plants downstream. The reservoir is eight miles long and the largest single body of water in Yosemite.

Hours

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open only during daylight hours, from sunrise to sunset. 

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (1,1) for current road conditions.

Getting Here

Located on the Hetch Hetchy Road, which becomes a one-way loop road, eventually leading to the O'Shaughnessy Dam parking area.

Rules & Regulations

  • Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.
  • You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.
  • Swimming and boating are prohibited in Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in order to maintain a clean source of drinking water.
  • Dogs and other pets are prohibited on all trails and on the dam. Wild animals are threatened by domestic animals in their territory and may endanger your pets. Dogs are allowed in the parking area but must be leashed at all times.
  • Fishing is allowed year-round in the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir. A valid California fishing license is required. Daily bag limit for the Hetch Hetchy reservoir is five per day and ten in possession.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
audioDescription:
The Hetch Hetchy Reservoir is accessible by way of a one-way loop road. Just beyond the O'Shaughnessy Dam, the road starts to go up hill, at which point, multiple roadside parking spots are available on the right side of the road. Cars are able to pull directly into the diagonal spaces, right off of the main road. A knee-high stone barrier and a cement curb, line the parking area. A few tall trees grow on the opposite side of the stone barrier. Beyond the stone barrier is a deep valley, which the waters of the dam empty into. A narrow stream makes its way through the V-shaped valley. Near the top of the hill where the parking area is located, across the street, are a few picnic tables. A wayside exhibit inside a log frame stands nearby and reads, Recreation tips:

Bring plenty of water when hiking. Summer months can be very hot.
Bears are active in the area. You can help keep Yosemite's bears wild and alive by storing all food in a bear-proof storage canister available at park entrance stations. Speeding cars are a common cause of bear and other wildlife casualties, so please drive safely at all times.
Enjoy the area but leave no trace behind. Pack out what you pack in. Stay on the trails to avoid erosion and to protect the landscape and water quality.
Fishing is allowed from the bank of the reservoir, but please use artificial bait and obtain a valid fishing license before entering the park.
Overnight backpacking requires a Yosemite National Park wilderness permit, available at the entrances. Day hiking requires no permit.
Please exercise caution when hiking near the Tuolumne River or around waterfalls. These areas can be very slippery, and the force of the water can be dangerous, especially during high flows between late spring and early summer.

Photo: Two people with large backpacks are on a trail, facing away from the camera, looking down a deep valley that has a river running through it.

Caption: Leave no trace outdoor ethics
Plan ahead and prepare
Travel and camp on durable surfaces
Dispose of waster properly
Leave what you find
Minimize campfire impacts
Respect wildlife
Be considerate of other visitors.
Please learn, practice, and pass on Leave No Traces outdoor skills and ethics. Following these principles will help protect precious backcountry resources. For more information on Leave No Trace, call (800) 332-4100 or visit www.lnt.org.

Photo: A Native American woman with a long dress has a baby in a cradle basket on her back. She faces away from the camera. She is in a meadow with a tall waterfall in the background.

Caption: Suzie and Sadie McGowan (Mono Lake Paiute), Yosemite Valley, 1901.

Panel text reads, American Indians of the Yosemite region were the original stewards of this area, living sustainably from the ecosystem's plants and animals for many years before the first Euro-American visitors arrived. The very name "Hetch Hetchy" is derived from Indian words for grasses and seeds common to this area. Please respect these extraordinary lands, as portions are considered sacred by the tribes and are protected under federal law.

Photo: Two wildflowers are shown. One wildflower is deep red and is sprouting from a crack in a rock. It is labeled stonecrop. The other flower is pink and yellow and has multiple blossoms on one stem. It is labeled Harlequin Lupine.

Panel text reads, the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir, while providing water to millions of people, also provides access to spectacular beauty and some of the most pristine wilderness in California. Some of the most colorful and exotic plant species in North America can be viewed in the Hetch Hetchy watershed. More than 1,000 species of wildflowers can be found in the park including Heuchera, California poppy, lupine, wallflower, shooting stars, waterfall buttercups, bright California fuschia, brodiaea, dwarf monkey flower, clarkia, and Sierra leisiga.

In the center of the exhibit panel is a glass case that contains a poster that reads, each year, 200 people finish their hike like this...
A photo is shown of 8 people carrying a person in a stretcher, down stone steps.
Text continues to read, don't let it be you.
Stay on the trail! Traveling off trail is a leading cause of hiking accident in Yosemite.
Ask about trail conditions before you go.
Stay away from swift moving streams and rivers.
Carry 2-3 liters of water and stay hydrated.
Bring high energy foods.
Wear sturdy shoes that protect your ankles.
Rest often.
Bring a headlamp or flashlight in case you are delayed.
Hike smart, and have a safe day!

Looking down the hill from the small picnic area, past the parking area, allows for a great view of the blue waters of the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir and the O'Shaughnessy Dam, which you can walk on.

title: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead
listingDescription: Get a bird's-eye view of the Hetch Hetchy area from one of two popular hiking destinations, Lookout Point or Smith Peak. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone.

images.altText: Wooden trailhead sign with mileages on it
images.title: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead
images.caption: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead

bodyText:
Get a bird's-eye view of the Hetch Hetchy area from one of two popular hiking destinations, Lookout Point or Smith Peak.

Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone.

Visit the Hetch Hetchy Entrance to get more information about hikes in this area.

Lookout Point (moderate)

The Lookout Point trail is a two-mile hike that involves moderate climbing and brings hikers to a rocky outcropping overlooking Hetch Hetchy.

2 miles (3.2 km) round-trip; 1 hour

Smith Peak (moderate to strenuous)

The Smith Peak (7,751 feet) trail takes you through forest and meadow to the highest point in the area and offers outstanding views of the Hetch Hetchy area. It has two trailhead options. One route begins at the entrance station and is 16 miles round-trip with 3,300 feet of elevation gain. The other route begins six miles beyond the entrance station. This trail is 13 miles round-trip with 3,700 feet elevation gain. The Smith Peak trails can be used to access the Yosemite high country.

13.5 miles (21.6 km) round-trip; 6 to 8 hours

Hours

Hetch Hetchy Road Daily Hours

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open only during daylight hours, from sunrise to sunset. 

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (1,1) for current road conditions.

Getting Here

The trailhead is located on the Hetch Hetchy Road near the Hetch Hetchy Entrance. The Hetch Hetchy Road begins just outside the park on Highway 120, near the Big Oak Flat Entrance.

Rules & Regulations

  • Stay on established trails
  • Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
  • Pack out what you pack in.
  • Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit.
  • Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
  • Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
  • Carry sunscreen and watch for rattlesnakes and poison oak.
  • Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility

This trailhead is not accessible.
audioDescription: This trailhead is located on the right side of the road, across the street from the Hetch Hetchy Entrance Station. It is marked by a wooden sign that reads, Lookout Point - 1.0 miles, Cottonwood Meadows - 3.2 miles, Smith Meadows - 6.4 miles, Hetch Hetchy - 7.3 miles, Harden Lake - 11.7 miles, Pate Valley - 17.7 miles, Yosemite Valley - 20.9 miles. Another small sign is located on the wooden post, beneath the wooden sign. The metal sign is bright yellow and reads, Warning, burned watershed. Risks include rockfall, falling trees, washed out trails, and trees blocking trails.

title: Homestead Cabin
listingDescription: Much of the high country around Yosemite Valley had been claimed by individuals in the late 1800s. The Hodgdon family, ranchers from the San Joaquin Valley, built this cabin on their homesteaded land in Aspen Valley and grazed cattle there each summer.

images.altText: Two story wooden cabin with covered porch
images.title: Homestead Cabin
images.caption: Homestead Cabin

bodyText:
Much of the high country around Yosemite Valley had been claimed by individuals in the late 1800s. Thomas “Tom” Hodgdon acquired land for grazing cattle in Aspen Valley, now within Yosemite National Park. In 1879, Tom hired workers to build an access road, and a two-story cabin, on the land. To build the two-story log cabin, he hired a Chinese American cowboy named Ah Hoy and a neighbor named Franklin Babcock. The Hodgdon family, ranchers from the San Joaquin Valley, grazed cattled on their homesteaded land in Aspen Valley each summer.

Tom and family ran a ranching business, grazing cattle in nearby meadows. After these meadows became part of Yosemite National Park in 1890, U.S. Army troops enforced park regulations against grazing by dispersing cattle, and the Hodgdons lost grazing privileges. The family didn’t use the cabin for a while, and patrolling soldiers, and even Army horses, sheltered inside occasionally.

No longer able to earn a living with livestock in Yosemite, the Hodgdon family adapted to make money from tourism. In 1882, as part of the Great Sierra Wagon Road, the Hodgdons’ access road was improved upon by Chinese workers, and extended to Tioga Pass for silver mining. When the Tioga Road opened to the public, tourist traffic increased through Aspen Valley. The Hodgdon family used their cabin, and created a complex of new buildings, used for tourist lodging. Eliza Hodgdon, Tom’s spouse, added to the entrepreneurial effort by selling hot meals to hungry travelers.
audioDescription: From the walking trail, this two-story log cabin is approached from the side. There is a stairway leading up to a door on the second floor. In the front, the roof extends out beyond the house, creating a covered porch. There is a door in the middle with a vertical rectangle window on each side. A long wooden bench sits below each window.

title: Housekeeping Camp
listingDescription: Perfect for those who love camping outdoors but don't want the hassle of setting up a tent, Housekeeping Camp is a Yosemite favorite.

images.altText: A few of the housekeeping structures among trees
images.title: Housekeeping Camp
images.caption: Housekeeping Camp

bodyText:
Perfect for those who love camping outdoors but don't want the hassle of setting up a tent, Housekeeping Camp is a Yosemite favorite.

Perched alongside the Merced River in the middle of Yosemite Valley, the camp features three-sided concrete structures with canvas roofs and privacy curtains. Nearby sandy beaches are perfect for relaxing in the sun by the river. From Housekeeping Camp, you'll have unmatched views of Yosemite Falls and Half Dome as you prepare your dinner on your campfire ring's grill. Enjoy your meal on your covered patio as you take in the sights and sounds of Yosemite.

At Housekeeping Camp you'll find a camp store, laundry room, shower facility, and the free shuttle bus, which will take you throughout Yosemite Valley. Guests can rent sheets, blankets, pillows, chairs, cribs, cots and stoves for their stay at Housekeeping Camp. Here is a map of the property.

See website for more information about the rooms, to check availability, to book a room, and to get an idea of what to bring, and what to do in the Housekeeping Camp area.

Housekeeping Camp units come with two bear lockers measuring:

  1. 33 inches deep x 45 inches wide x 18 inches tall, and
  2. 17 inches deep x 49 inches wide x 17 inches tall

Hours

Mid-April to early October, weather permitting
The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day. For actual dates and hours see website :

  • Check-in: 4 pm
  • Check-out: 10 am

Getting Here

Located in Yosemite Valley, on Southside Drive, across from Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center and shuttle stop 12.

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all accommodations and buildings in Yosemite.

  • There are no pets allowed on property.

  • Bear-proof food lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash.

Food Storage Guidelines:

  • Treat your food locker like a refrigerator-never leave it open.

  • Place food inside resealable containers and store the containers in the food lockers.

  • Ensure your food locker is fully closed and latched, even when padlocked.

  • When you leave, empty your food locker.

  • Failure to comply with food storage policies may result in a $5000 fine and/or your removal from the camp.

  • Cars used for food storage may be impounded.

Hazards & Warnings

You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Select lodging units within Housekeeping Camp are accessible, with a nearby accessible restroom. Designated accessible parking spaces are available. The laundry, shower, and grocery store facilities are all accessible.
audioDescription: Housekeeping Camp is a lodging area that offers a camp-like experience. It is located along the Merced River and has 266 lodging units scattered across the property. There is also a front office, store, laundry facility, and shower facility on site, near the entrance of the property. One unit includes a three-sided concrete structure that has a canvas roof and curtains for privacy. Each unit contains a cement floor, an electrical outlet, a light, bunk beds, shelves, and a mirror. A cement patio extends off the front of the unit and contains a circular picnic table and a light. An additional canvas roof covers two back-to-back units and their patio areas. A wooden fence surrounds a portion of each patio for privacy. Two small food lockers are stacked on top of two larger ones, both situated on the side of the back-to-back units. Communal restrooms are randomly placed throughout the property.

title: Housekeeping Camp Architecture

images.altText: A concrete duplex structure with a canvas roof, wood fencing, and bear lockers in front
images.title: Housekeeping Camp
images.caption: Housekeeping Camp

bodyText:
Before Mission 66, Housekeeping Camp was previously a campground for tent camping. At the time, the park concessioner offered some campsites outfitted with tents and camping gear for visitors who didn’t bring their own.

Building on this idea, architect Eldridge T. Spencer designed the simple duplexes still used in Housekeeping Camp today. Constructed during Mission 66, these structures occupy a space somewhere between tent camping and cabin lodging. In addition to the concrete bunk structures, they include a fenced-in concrete footer that served as a “living room” of, originally, a wood stove, table, and chairs.

This is a seasonally active camping area. Do not enter any campsites or disturb the campers.

title: Indian Village
listingDescription: Go back in time and walk through a re-constructed Indian village to learn more about structures the native people lived in and the plants they used for survival. The reconstructed Indian Village of Ahwahnee offers outdoor displays about the culture and lives of the Ahwahneechee inhabitants of Yosemite Valley. Follow this trail through a re-constructed Yosemite Indian village of the 1870s. Signs along the path will introduce you to the structures in the village and the plants.

images.altText: Reconstructed bark houses within the Indian Village
images.title: Indian Village of Ahwahnee
images.caption: Reconstructed bark houses in the Indian Village

bodyText:
Walk through a re-constructed Indian village to learn more about structures the native people lived in and the plants they used for survival.  

The reconstructed Indian Village of Ahwahnee offers outdoor displays about the culture and lives of the Ahwahneechee inhabitants of Yosemite Valley.

Follow this trail through a re-constructed Yosemite Indian village of the 1870s. Signs along the path will introduce you to the structures in the village and the plants used by native people.

This reconstructed village is located on the former site of the largest Indian village in Yosemite Valley. The bark houses, ceremonial roundhouse, sweathouse, pounding rocks, cabin, acorn granaries, and chief's house are representative of the structures found in a Sierra Nevada Miwok village of the late nineteenth century. Today the village is still actively used by members of the local American Indian community for ceremonies and special gatherings.

Hours

Year-round

Getting Here

Located in Yosemite Valley, near bus stops #5, behind the Yosemite Museum and Yosemite Valley Visitor Center.

Accessibility

A short, partially paved loop trail winding through the Indian Village has displays that incorporate audio buttons. The village's central area is level but unpaved.
audioDescription: Behind the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center, a path leads into the Indian Village. A sign is at the apex of the trail, that extends to the left and the right. The sign reads Welcome, heeyeko in Southern Miwok. An arrow points to the right and the sign reads self-guiding trail through the Indian Village of Ahwahnee. An illustrated map shows the layout of the Indian Village. A green circular path with counter clockwise arrows shows the direction to go. A red dot indicates You are here. A series of multi-sized brown circles indicate, from right to left, Acorn graneries, a ceremonial roundhouse, and a sweathouse, all on the outer side of the trail. In the center of the loop trail is the Chief's house, a cabin, indicated by a brown square, and a cluster of bark houses, otherwise known as umachas. A stream runs through the center of the loop trail, right next to the umachas, cabin, and Chief's house. Three-quarters of the way around the loop trail from where the red dot indicates 'You are here,' is an arrow that points downward and reads 'To Museum.' The rest of the sign reads We invite you to follow this trail through a re-constructed Yosemite Indian village of the 1870s. The largest Miwok village in Yosemite Valley, the Village of Ahwahnee, was once in this area. Signs along the path will introduce you to the structures in the village and the plants used by Native people. A stack of booklets are held in a dispenser that reads booklets, 50 cents. There's a coin slot to the right of it.

title: Jail, Powder House, and Morgue
listingDescription: As auto-touring increased, the newly-formed National Park Service recognized that roads needed improvement. Road-building in this region was not easy. Granite rock was blasted away to form roadbeds. Powderhouses were used to store blasting powder. In 1933, access to Yosemite Valley from Wawona was improved with the completion of the Wawona Tunnel. The tunnel's power lines, its carbon monoxide sensors, and its high-speed fans made it an engineering feat. Workers used 275 tons

images.altText: An old cot can be seen through the open door of a small stone structure with a pointed roof.

bodyText: As auto-touring increased, the newly-formed National Park Service recognized that roads needed improvement. Road-building in this region was not easy. Granite rock was blasted away to form roadbeds. Powderhouses were used to store blasting powder. In 1933, access to Yosemite Valley from Wawona was improved with the completion of the Wawona Tunnel. The tunnel's power lines, its carbon monoxide sensors, and its high-speed fans made it an engineering feat. Workers used 275 tons of blasting powder and spent nearly two years drilling the tunnel at a rate of roughly 20 feet per day.
audioDescription: This small, one-room stone structure has a wooden, pyramid style roof. There is only one wooden door, no windows. Inside, there is a very low ceiling and a lone steel-framed cot with exposed springs. An exhibit sign reads: Powder House - Jail: The black powder and dynamite used in the routine State work in Yosemite Valley were kept in the "Tool House" before John Degnan built this stone magazine in the 1890s. In addition to thick stone walls, the powder house also had six inches of sand in the ceiling as protection from fire. Later, the powder house was converted into a jail, a very poor one. In 1915, two young car thieves escaped by digging away the mortar between the rocks with a leg they had twisted off the rickety steel frame cot. The pair claimed the task was so easy that they waited until after breakfast to perform their escape. Patrol rangers recaptured them, and shackled them by leg irons to the corners. Following this incident, horseshoes were imbedded in the floor to provide a chain or base of greater security. Occasionally, the powder house-jail also served as a morgue.

title: John Muir Trail
listingDescription:
Let the overwhelming views of Tuolumne Meadows' peaks and meadows compete for your attention as you venture into Lyell Canyon via the John Muir Trail.

Begin across the road from Dog Lake parking area. This trail passes through Lyell Canyon, along the Lyell Fork of the Tuolumne River. Early in the season, the trail can be muddy in places. There are several creek crossings, including Rafferty Creek (bridged) and Ireland Creek (unbridged). Spectacular Kuna Creek cascades down the side of the east canyon wall near the eight-mile mark. For a shorter trip, walk 1/2 hour each way to the Lyell Fork and "Twin Bridges."


John Muir Trail
Tuolumne Pass, Vogelsang High Sierra Camp, Donohue Pass, Merced Lake, and Yosemite Valley are all destinations beginning from this trailhead.

A Donohue Pass exit quota is in effect for John Muir Trail hikers exiting Yosemite over Donohue Pass. You can apply for this on your wilderness permit application. (This does not apply if you're hiking the John Muir Trail only within Yosemite.)


Lyell Canyon (easy)
8 miles (12.8 km) one-way; 4 hours
200 ft (61 m) elevation gain

For hiking and trail information, please visit a Wilderness Center or Visitor Center.



Hours :
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here :
Begin across the street from the Dog Lake parking area, just west of Tuolumne Meadows Lodge.

Rules & Regulations :
- Stay on established trails
- Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
- Pack out what you pack in
- Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
- Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings :
- Stay off domes during thunderstorms!
- Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
- Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
- Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.


Accessibility :
This trail is not accessible.

images.altText: A trailhead sign reads John Muir Trail.
images.caption: A trailhead sign marks the start of the John Muir Trail.
