This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
The John Muir Trail begins across the street from the Dog Lake Parking lot. Residential housing consisting of wooden cabins with canvas roofs, are located on the west side of the parking area. A large exhibit panel set inside a log frame, stands on log posts next to the Dog Lake trailhead. The panel text reads, welcome to Dog Lake Parking. This trailhead accesses the hike to Dog Lake, Lembert Dome, Young Lakes, and Lyell Canyon, among others. Hiking maps and guidebooks are available at the visitor center. For your safety, please follow trail signs and do not walk along the road.

The upper half of the panel is a trail map of the area. Beginning at where the red dot indicates, you are here, yellow lines, representing trails, sprawl out from this point. An icon for parking and accommodations are near to the red dot. A blue line indicates the water of the Tuolumne River and Dog Lake, and a thick white line represents Tioga Road, which runs left to right, with thinner white lines branching off Tioga Road, indicating smaller backroads. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at 209/379-1035.

The left column of panel text reads, take a hike! The hike to Dog Lake and/or Lembert Dome begins at the uphill (north) side of this parking lot. Pay attention to signs posted at every trail junction. Remember, this is the "Dog Lake" parking area.

Dog Lake (moderately strenuous) - Surrounded by forest, this quiet lake is home to many species including water birds, song birds, deer, and dragonflies. Despite its name, pets are not allowed at Dog Lake, nor on any other trail.

Lembert Dome (moderately strenuous) - After Gaining 600 feet (183 m) of elevation, look for the trail junction to the summit of Lembert Dome. The trail climbs through the forest to the bare rock of the dome. There is no trail on the rock. Follow the easiest path for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.

The Loop (moderately strenuous) - It is possible to combine the Lembert Dome and Dog Lake hikes into a five-mile loop. Study the map for details. Do not walk on the road from the Lembert Dome parking area back to this parking area. Instead, use the trails indicated on the map.

Lyell Canyon (easy) - To hike up Lyell Canyon on the John Muir and Pacific Crest Trails, begin at the downhill (south) side of this parking lot. Cross the road at the crosswalk and follow the trail upstream. You can enjoy a short stroll along the river until you are ready to turn around. One mile up the trail you will reach Twin Bridges, a scenic crossing of the Lyell fork. If you're feeling more adventurous, this trail could take you to Mt. Whitney, over 200 miles (322 km) away, or all the way to Mexico.

The right column of panel text reads, before you go. Stay on trail. Careless steps damage this fragile landscape. Plants have a short growing season before winter snow blankets the land.

Be prepared. Carry plenty of water and high energy food. Bring a map; don't rely on cell phones and GPS. Pack a flashlight in case your hike takes longer than expected. Wear appropriate clothes and shoes. Tell someone where you're going and when you plan to return.

Pack out what you pack in. To help this wilderness thrive, leave no trace of your presence. You must pack out your used toilet paper and trash.

Never feed wild animals. Human food is unhealthy for wildlife and encourages aggressive behavior. Respect animals at a distance. If an animal changes its behavior due to your presence, you are too close.

Pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed only on roads accessible by vehicle, never on trails. Pets must be on a leash at all times, and owners must bag and dispose of pet waste.

Weather can change quickly in the mountains. Be aware of building thunderstorms. Stay off of exposed granite domes, open meadows, and lakes when storms are approaching.

Get there safely. Roads in the park are narrow and winding. Protect park wildlife, other visitors, and yourself by obeying posted speed limits and using turnouts.

Feeling the altitude? Give yourself a day or two to become accustomed to the altitude. Signs of altitude sickness can include nausea, dizziness, and headache. Descending to a lower elevation can help alleviate symptoms.

Wilderness use regulations. Wilderness permits and and allowed bear-resistant food containers are required year-round for overnight trips. They are available at the Yosemite Valley and Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Centers, Wawona Visitor Center, Big Oak Flat Information Station, and the Hetch Hetchy Entrance Station. No motorized vehicles are permitted.

In the middle of the left and right text columns is a small map outline of the entire park. The main roads and areas are the only things labeled. On the far left side of the park is a road that runs north to south. At the top point is Hetch Hetchy, coming down to Big Oak Flat, then down to Wawona, which is near the bottom tip of the park. A little less than half way up the road is an intersection the leads into the Yosemite Valley via a loop road. Just above Yosemite Valley is a road that extend from the left to the right of the park, the Tioga Road, With Tioga Pass labeled at the far right. To the far right of the Tioga Road, near Tioga Pass, is a red dot that indicates, you are here.

From north to south, the parking lot slopes downhill a bit. There is a neat line of recycle bins, trash bins, and food storage lockers in the south parking lot. A crosswalk leads across the street to the Lyell Canyon trailhead. A wooden sign reads, John Muir Trail, Tuolumne Pass 6.1 miles, Vogelsang H.S.C. 6.7 miles, Donohue Pass 11.9 miles, Merced Lake 14.7 miles, and Yosemite Valley 27.5 miles. A sign is posted prohibiting dogs on the trail.

title: Lembert Dome and Dog Lake Trailhead
listingDescription: Let the overwhelming views of Tuolumne Meadows' peaks, meadows, and river compete for your attention atop Lembert Dome, then take in the sparkling waters of Dog Lake. Lembert Dome The trail climbs through the forest to the bare rock of the dome. There is no trail on the rock. Follow the easiest path for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks. Lembert Dome was sculpted by glaciers, which have filled Tuolumne Meadows many times over millions of years. D

images.altText: People walk on granite bedrock that curves upward into a large dome.

bodyText:
Let the overwhelming views of Tuolumne Meadows' peaks, meadows, and river compete for your attention atop Lembert Dome, then take in the sparkling waters of Dog Lake.

Lembert Dome
The trail climbs through the forest to the bare rock of the dome. There is no trail on the rock. Follow the easiest path for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.

Lembert Dome was sculpted by glaciers, which have filled Tuolumne Meadows many times over millions of years.

Dog Lake
Surrounded by forest, this quiet lake is home to many species including water birds, song birds, deer, and dragonflies. Despite its name, pets are not allowed at Dog Lake, nor on any other trails.


Lembert Dome (moderately strenuous)
3.4 miles (5.5 km) round-trip; 3 hours
850 ft (259 m) elevation gain

Dog Lake (moderately strenuous)
3.6 miles (5.8 km) round-trip; 3 hours
600 ft (183 m) elevation gain

Lembert Dome and Dog Lake can also be combined into a five mile loop hike. For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.



Hours:
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here:
Begin at the Lembert Dome Parking Area, just east of Tuolumne Meadows Store.

Rules & Regulations:
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings:
Stay off domes during thunderstorms!
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.


Accessibility:
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: A slightly crescent shaped, paved parking area is near the Lembert Dome/Dog Lake trailhead. Just east of the parking lot, beyond a stand of tall pines, is a granite dome, Lembert Dome. The dome is shaped like a slide, the left side being a steep incline, while the right side has a long gradual decline. At the north end of the parking lot are two dumpsters, a brown one for trash, and a green one for recycling, each having a carabiner to clip their chutes shut. Near the dumpsters is a thin metal post with two signs. The top sign reads, no camping or overnight parking. The second sign reads, no parking any time, and has a two sided arrow pointing left and right. Not far to the right of the dumpsters are the vault toilets, which are two grey structures located on a wooden deck, accessible by steps or a ramp. Next to the restroom is a dirt path that leads into the forest. A wooden sign reads Lembert Dome, Dog Lake Trailhead. Two icons are located within two separate square outlines, and each have a red diagonal line slashing down it's center. The first icon is of a dog and the second icon is of a bicycle. To the right of the trailhead is a large, green tone, exhibit panel, inside a log frame, with log posts.Panel text reads, welcome to Lembert Dome parking. The dome above you was sculpted by glaciers, which have filled Tuolumne Meadows many times over millions of years. If you stood here thousands of years ago during a glacial period, you would be buried under 2,000 feet of ice! This trailhead accesses hikes to Lembert Dome, Dog Lake, Soda Springs, Glen Aulin, and Young Lakes. The upper half of the panel is a trail map of the area. Beginning at where the red dot indicates, you are here, in the middle of the map, yellow lines, representing trails, sprawl out from this point. To the upper left, the trails lead toward Soda Springs and Glen Aulin. To the upper right, the trail splits off to the right to Lembert Dome, before continuing to Dog Lake and Young Lakes. An icon for Parking, picnic area, and restrooms are next to the red dot. Blue indicates the water of Dog Lake and the Tuolumne River, and white represents Tioga Road, which runs left to right, with thinner white lines indicating smaller backroads. For more information about Yosemite maps, please call 209/379-1035The left column of panel text reads, take a hike! The trail to Lembert Dome or Dog Lake begins on your left (west) and passes in front of the bathrooms. Pay attention to signs, posted at every trail junction. Remember, this is the Lembert Dome Parking Area. Lembert Dome is moderately strenuous. The trail climbs 850 feet (259 km) through the forest to the bare rock of the dome. There is no trail on the rock. Follow the easiest path for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks. Dog Lake is moderately strenuous. Surrounded by forest, this quiet lake is home to many species including water birds, song birds, deer, and dragonflies. Despite its name, pets are not allowed at Dog Lake, nor on any other trails. The Loop is moderately strenuous. It is possible to combine the Lembert Dome and Dog Lake hikes into a five-mile loop. Study the map for details. Do not walk on the road from the Dog Lake parking area back to this parking area. Instead, use the trails indicated on the map. Soda Springs is easy. Follow the gravel Soda Springs Road on your left. When you reach the gate, continue straight for about a half mile to the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge. This easy, mostly flat walk opens up to views of the Tuolumne River, Tuolumne Meadows, and the surrounding peaks. Carbonated water bubbles out of the ground at Soda Springs. The Parsons Memorial Lodge has been a reading room, shelter, and place for lively discussion since it was built in 1915. The right column of panel text reads, before you go. Stay on trail. Careless steps damage this fragile landscape. Plants have a short growing season before winter snow blankets the land. Be prepared. Carry plenty of water and high energy food. Bring a map; don't rely on cell phones and GPS. Pack a flashlight in case your hike takes longer than expected. Wear appropriate clothes and shoes. Tell someone where you're going and when you plan to return. Pack out what you pack in. To help this wilderness thrive, leave no trace of your presence. You must pack out your used toilet paper and trash. Never feed wild animals. Human food is unhealthy for wildlife and encourages aggressive behavior. Respect animals at a distance. If an animal changes its behavior due to your presence, you are too close. Pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed only on roads accessible by vehicle, never on trails. Pets must be on a leash at all times, and owners must bag and dispose of pet waste. Weather can change quickly in the mountains. Be aware of building thunderstorms. Stay off of exposed granite domes, open meadows, and lakes when storms are approaching. Get there safely. Roads in the park are narrow and winding. Protect p

title: Lower Pines Campground Restroom Architecture

images.altText: A small single story building with a low angled roof with overhanging eaves
images.title: Lower Pines Campground Restroom
images.caption: Lower Pines Campground Restroom

bodyText:
During Mission 66, the park undertook significant efforts to improve visitor infrastructure, including modernizing campgrounds and building many additional restrooms.

While simple, these restrooms possess a small number of character-defining features. The low-angled roof and framed rectangular windows are unique to the many restrooms built in Yosemite during this era.

This is an active camping area. Do not enter any campsites or disturb the campers
audioDescription: The Lower Pines campground restroom is a small, single-story building made of concrete blocks painted brown. The roof has a low angle with overhanging eaves painted in a contrasting light brown. All around the upper edge of the building just below the roof line, single-pane rectangular windows surround the building. Wood fencing, also painted brown, shelters doors to the men’s and women’s restrooms, which are located on opposite sides of the building. The building has a small sign with the label “409.”

title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Early Tourism
listingDescription:
Early Tourism
After leading the first tourist party into Yosemite Valley in 1855, entrepreneur James Hutchings promoted the Valley's "Scenes of Wonder and Curiosity" in his own California Magazine. Not long after, a steadily increasing stream of visitors traveled to the Valley on foot, by horseback, and later by stagecoach. Makeshift hotels were often strained beyond capacity as news of Yosemite's scenic wonders spread.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit with a bronze tactile relief section stands near a log that is strategically cut into a bench.

bodyText:
Early Tourism
After leading the first tourist party into Yosemite Valley in 1855, entrepreneur James Hutchings promoted the Valley's "Scenes of Wonder and Curiosity" in his own California Magazine. Not long after, a steadily increasing stream of visitors traveled to the Valley on foot, by horseback, and later by stagecoach. Makeshift hotels were often strained beyond capacity as news of Yosemite's scenic wonders spread.
audioDescription:
A wayside exhibit stands near the start of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of Yosemite Falls. The caption reads, Thomas Ayres' drawing of Yosemite Falls, 1855.

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, Early Tourism, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of the Lower Yosemite Fall. Panel text reads, after leading the first tourist party into Yosemite Valley in 1855, entrepreneur James Hutchings promoted the Valley's "Scenes of Wonder and Curiosity" in his own California Magazine. Not long after, a steadily increasing stream of visitors traveled to the Valley on foot, by horseback, and later by stagecoach. Makeshift hotels were often strained beyond capacity as news of Yosemite's scenic wonders spread.

Under a heading that reads, Inspiring a Nation, panel text reads, Artist Thomas Ayres, who accompanied Hutchings on his first trip to Yosemite, drew some of the first sketches of the Valley. Hutchings later published this work in his magazine, giving the nation its first glimpse of Yosemite's spectacular beauty. Ayres was the first of many artists inspired by the wonder and awe of Yosemite Falls.

Black and white photo 1: Eight people, four men and four women, sit on horses that are standing in an open meadow, with Yosemite Falls as their backdrop.

Black and white photo 2: A horse-drawn, covered wagon is parked in an open meadow with Yosemite Falls as the backdrop. One man is sitting in the driver's seat, while another man leans on the large, wooden, back driver's side wheel. â€˜Yosemite or Bust,' is painted on the wagon canopy.

Black and white photo 3: A group photo of six people posing in front of a four-team, horse-drawn wagon, with Yosemite Falls as the backdrop, fills the frame. Two men propped up on their elbow, lay on their side and face the camera. Two women in long dresses sit on luggage while one man props his right elbow on the front driver's side wheel. Another man stands with his arms behind his back.

Caption for the three photos: Since the days of these early tourists, millions of visitors - just like you - have captured their Yosemite experience in images of Yosemite Falls.

title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - James Hutchings
listingDescription:
James Hutchings
After bringing the first tourists to Yosemite Valley, James Mason Hutchings established Hutchings House in 1864. Using the boardinghouse know-how of his mother-in-law, he and his wife launched a career as Yosemite inn-keepers. Hutchings was a gracious host, whose charm made up for the lack of amenities in his hotel.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit with a bronze tactile relief of a man stands near a path.

bodyText:
James Hutchings
After bringing the first tourists to Yosemite Valley, James Mason Hutchings established Hutchings House in 1864. Using the boardinghouse know-how of his mother-in-law, he and his wife launched a career as Yosemite inn-keepers. Hutchings was a gracious host, whose charm made up for the lack of amenities in his hotel.
audioDescription:
A wayside exhibit stands near the start of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of and older man with a long beard wearing a suit and bow tie. The caption reads, Writer Helen Hunt Jackson called James Hutchings "an enthusiast, a dreamer, a visionary...all this is plainly to be seen in his mobile, artistic face, and in the affectionate ring of every word that he speaks of the Valley."

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, James Hutchings, and has a faint, sepia-toned photograph of a basic two-story building with seven windows spaced out on the second floor, and five windows and three doors on the first floor. The caption reads, "upstairs, the rooms [at Hutchings House] were only divided by pieces of cotton cloth and were very small at that...Fanny J's soap slipped from her fingers when washing and flew into the parlor." - A New England guest, June 1864.

Panel text reads, after bringing the first tourists to Yosemite Valley, James Mason Hutchings established Hutchings House in 1864. Using the boardinghouse know-how of his mother-in-law, he and his wife launched a career as Yosemite inn-keepers. Hutchings was a gracious host, whose charm made up for the lack of amenities in his hotel.

Under a heading that reads, Pioneer and Entrepreneur, panel text reads, James Hutchings built a family cabin directly in view of Yosemite Falls. It was located adjacent to the apple orchard he planted across the way, which still bears fruit after 150 years. Here, his family raised produce and livestock to feed the hotel guests. Where you are standing now, a smokehouse once cured meat.

Black and white photo: An older man with a white beard sits in a chair. A young boy is to the left of him and a woman, with a hat and long dress, stands, resting her right arm on the back of the chair. They are on a lawn in front of a wooden house with a high pitched roof.

Caption: James Hutchings (center) is pictured here with his son Willie and daughter Gertrude "Cosie" Hutchings, in front of their cabin, c. 1890s.

Black and white photo: A granite tombstone has the following words chiseled out of it: James Mason Hutchings, February 10, 1818, October 31, 1902, Father of Yosemite. Builder of the first trails, road, bridges, and dwellings of the Valley.

Caption: En route to the Valley in 1902, Hutchings was killed in a carriage accident. You can visit the family burial site in the Pioneer Cemetery in Yosemite Village.

title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - John Muir Woodcutter
listingDescription: In 1869, innkeeper James Hutchings hired a young woodcutter named John Muir to rebuild and operate his sawmill. Muir worked here for almost two years, milling trees blown down in a storm to build improvements at Hutchings' Yosemite Valley hotel. During his Yosemite years, Muir became an outspoken proponent of America's wild places.

images.altText: A wooden path with a wood railing circles around a large granite boulder.

bodyText: In 1869, innkeeper James Hutchings hired a young woodcutter named John Muir to rebuild and operate his sawmill. Muir worked here for almost two years, milling trees blown down in a storm to build improvements at Hutchings' Yosemite Valley hotel. During his Yosemite years, Muir became an outspoken proponent of America's wild places.
audioDescription:
A wayside exhibit stands in the curve of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of a man sitting on a rock, his legs crossed, his right hand holding onto a walking stick while his left arm rests on top of the walking stick. He has a long beard and wears a hat. The caption reads, Muir was instrumental in getting his beloved Yosemite and several other national parks established. In 1892 he became the founding president of the Sierra Club.

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, John Muir...The Woodcutter, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of a young man with hair combed back, a long beard, and mustache. Panel text reads, In 1869, innkeeper James Hutchings hired a young wilderness explorer named John Muir to rebuild and operate his sawmill. Muir worked here for almost two years, milling trees blown down in a storm to build improvements at Hutchings' Yosemite Valley hotel. During his Yosemite years, Muir became an outspoken proponent of America's wild places.

Quote: "As long as I live, I'll hear waterfalls and birds and winds sing. I'll interpret the rocks, learn the language of flood, storm, and the avalanche. I'll acquaint myself with the glaciers and wild gardens, and get as near the heart of the world as I can." - John Muir

Under a heading that reads, Remains of the Millrace, panel text reads, this 1940 photograph shows the channel that was dug to divert water from Yosemite Creek, possibly to power the sawmill or irrigate Hutchings' apple trees. Directly below, you can see what may be the remains of this millrace.

Black and white photo: Four men stand in a flat, open area in a forest. One man in a black suit and hat is writing in a book. Another man holds a long, rolled-up, piece of paper while looking down at the ground. Another man, dressed in a National Park Service uniform, looks down at the ground, too. Another man, in the far background, looks toward the other men.

Black and white photo: A shabby wooden structure has water running beneath it.

Caption: In the shadow of Yosemite Falls, Muir lived in a "hang nest," a boxy retreat he attached to the sawmill.

title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Profile of a Waterfall
listingDescription: Do you wonder what it's like up at the top of Yosemite Falls, before the water spills over the brink? Learn more at this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit with a bronze tactile relief section stands next to a trail that leads toward a tall waterfall.

bodyText: Do you wonder what it's like up at the top of Yosemite Falls, before the water spills over the brink? Learn more at this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
On a paved path lined with tall trees that leads toward Lower Yosemite Fall, a paved clearing on the right side of the trail holds a long log that has a one-quarter wedge cut out of it length-wise, letting it serve as a bench with a backing, and includes metal arm rests at the ends. A wayside exhibit stands nearby.

On the left one-quarter side of the wayside exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of the three tiers of Yosemite Falls. The caption reads, between Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls, the water tumbles through pools and rapids of the Middle Cascades before it careens down the Lower Fall. The water once again becomes Yosemite Creek as it meanders on its way to the Merced River.
The remaining right side of the panel is titled, Profile of a Waterfall, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of river water right before it goes over a waterfall. The caption reads, Yosemite Creek as it pours over the top of Upper Yosemite Fall. Panel text reads, do you wonder what it's like up at the top of Yosemite Falls, before the water spills over the brink? The Falls begin as snow in the granite reaches of Yosemite wilderness. When the snow melts each spring, Yosemite Creek transforms into a free-falling torrent. Watch the comets of spray. Hear the water roar. And from the Lower Fall Bridge, feel the shower of a lifetime!

Under a heading that reads, Seasonal Flow, four pictures of Yosemite Falls are shown.

Black and white comparison photo 1: Two waterfalls are stacked on top of each other. The upper fall is full of water and the lower fall has a slightly more narrow, shorter, stream of water.

Caption: Spring - The force and volume of melting snow reaches its peak.

Black and white comparison photo 2: Two waterfalls, stacked on top of each other, have dwindled down to a thin, hair-like strand of water.

Caption: Summer - As the snowpack in the high country recedes, the flow of water starts to diminish.

Black and white comparison photo 3: The Upper Yosemite Fall is more like a wet rock wall. No steady stream of water is seen, just darkened wet spot on the rock wall.

Caption: Autumn - When the water dries up, the lichen-stained cliff face traces the course of the waterfalls.

Black and white comparison photo 4: A thin stream of water falls over a large granite rock wall. White ice has built up on the rock face on both sides of the thin waterfall. The trees surrounding the lower half of the rock wall are all snow covered.

Caption: Winter - The meager spray dribbles over the cliff and freezes. Listen for ice crashing in the morning.

title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Shaping Yosemite Valley
listingDescription:
Shaping Yosemite Valley
Like giant bulldozers, ice-age glaciers carved and plucked rock from Yosemite Valley's granite walls. As the glaciers receded, "hanging valleys" were left behind. The streams from these ancient valleys now flow over waterfalls-like Yosemite Falls.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit with a bronze tactile relief section stands along a path. A tall waterfall can be seen above the treeline.

bodyText:
Shaping Yosemite Valley
Like giant bulldozers, ice-age glaciers carved and plucked rock from Yosemite Valley's granite walls. As the glaciers receded, "hanging valleys" were left behind. The streams from these ancient valleys now flow over waterfalls-like Yosemite Falls.
audioDescription:
A wayside exhibit stands in a clearing on the right side of a paved path lined with tall trees that leads to Lower Yosemite Fall. On the left one-quarter side of the exhibit is a bronze tactile panel of a finger-like spire outcrop from off the side of a cliff face. The caption reads, to the right of Upper Yosemite Fall, you can see a finger of granite known as the Lost Arrow. Its name comes from a story about a deer hunter who was in the high country celebrating his conquests. From the cliffs above the Valley, he shot a victory arrow into the air. When the wayward point dropped to the ground, it turned to stone.

The remaining right side of the panel is titled, Shaping Yosemite Valley, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photograph of a big pile of boulders. Panel text reads, like giant bulldozers, Ice-Age glaciers carved and plucked rock from Yosemite Valley's granite walls. As the glaciers receded, "hanging valleys" were left behind. The streams from these ancient valleys now flow over waterfalls - like Yosemite Falls.

Black and white photo: The terrain above Yosemite Falls is covered with snow. Yosemite Falls is full of water as it plummets over the granite precipice.

Under a heading that reads, And the Rocks Come Down, panel text reads, all is peaceful and calm now. But imagine what it was like long ago when the boulders to your left tumbled and crashed to the Valley floor. Rockfalls are as central to shaping the face of Yosemite Valley as fire or flood. Long before recorded history, these boulders, known as talus, fell as a result of weathering and erosion. For eons, this ongoing natural process has worked upon Valley walls. When water in cracks repeatedly freezes and thaws, rocks break free. Likewise, lichens, moss, and plant roots can grow in the cracks, helping to pry fragments loose. Be aware that rockfalls can happen at any time.

title: Lower Yosemite Fall Tour - Tactile Model
listingDescription:
Bronze Tactile Model of Yosemite Falls
Feel the trees, trails, rock formations, cliff faces, and Yosemite Falls, on this bronze tactile model of the Yosemite Falls area.

images.altText: A bronze tactile relief model sits on a granite rock pedestal along a paved trail leading toward a tall waterfall.

bodyText:
Bronze Tactile Model of Yosemite Falls
Feel the trees, trails, rock formations, cliff faces, and Yosemite Falls, on this bronze tactile model of the Yosemite Falls area.
audioDescription: On a paved path lined with tall trees leading to Lower Yosemite Fall, a clearing on the right side of the trail holds a bronze tactile model of Yosemite Falls. A mosaic of stonework covers the flat clearing in the path, and the bronze 2 foot by 2 foot model sits on a waist-high granite cube. The model mimics the terrain on which the Yosemite Falls is found, which includes the high cliff walls, its textures, and its trails. Small bumps found all over the model represent trees. A trail to the left of Yosemite Falls, represented by raised tick marks, has a series of switchbacks leading up about one-third of the rock face before it flattens out to the right for another one-third of the trail, then starts ascending to the immediate left of Upper Yosemite Fall for the remainder of the trail to the top of Yosemite Falls. At the top of the rock face, the trail disperses out to the left, straight, and to the right. Raised, flat lines indicate the trails and roads on the valley floor. Slightly concaved lines, with squiggly textured lines within, indicate waterways in Yosemite Valley. The model reads, Yosemite Falls Area, and has a line of tick marks labeled 0.25 miles.

title: Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead
listingDescription: Witness the strength of this mighty waterfall by site, sound, and the feel of its mist, when you stand at its base in spring and early summer when the waterfall peaks in volume. The falls are often only a trickle or completely dry by August.

images.altText: Visitors viewing Yosemite Falls from the trailhead with a full waterfall in the background.
images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead
images.caption: View of Yosemite Falls from the Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead.

bodyText:
Delight in stunning views of Yosemite Falls in its entirety, with the opportunity to walk to the base of the lower fall; it roars in spring but falls silent by late summer.

Trail to Lower Yosemite Fall (Easy)

Lower Yosemite Fall is the final 320-foot (98-meter) drop of Yosemite Falls. Deafening in spring and early summer when the waterfall peaks in volume, you can expect to get sprayed with water when standing on the footbridge near its base. The falls are often only a trickle or completely dry by August, then are revived again by late fall storms. This short, easy walk rewards with spectacular views of both Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. This paved loop trail offers different vantage points of Yosemite Falls and Yosemite Creek, and you can stop at the many exhibits to learn more about the natural and cultural history of the area.

Overview

  • 1 mile (1.6 km) loop trip; 30 minutes;
  • 50 feet (15 m) elevation gain

Hours

Year-round

Getting Here

Located on Northside Drive in Yosemite Valley, near shuttle stop #6, and across from the Yosemite Valley Lodge.

Rules & Regulations

  • Share the trail! Leashed pets and strollers are allowed.
  • Bicycles are prohibited, with numerous bicycle racks located nearby for your convenience.
  • Keep your food within arm's reach at all times and do not feed the wildlife.

Hazards & Warnings

Stay on the paved trail. Above the wooden footbridge that crosses Yosemite Creek, the rocks and boulders are slippery even when dry. Scrambling off-trail in this area frequently leads to serious injuries.

Accessibility

The western portion of the loop trail is not accessible due to its grade. An accessible trail is available a little further east, near shuttle stop #6.
audioDescription: A paved walking path cuts through the forest and leads to the base of Lower Yosemite Fall. At the trailhead, the forged path allows for full views of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. The Yosemite Falls Picnic Area is nearby and has about seven randomly placed wooden picnic tables, trash and recycle bins, bike racks, a drinking fountain, and a restroom.

title: Lukens Lake Trailhead from Tioga Road
listingDescription: Enjoy fishing, swimming, or viewing the wildflower display that often wraps around the lake in the summer. This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow. Shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers abound, often through July. Please stay on designated trails to protect the meadow, even if the trail is wet or muddy.

images.altText: A brown and white roadside sign reads, "Lukens Lake," and has an icon of a hiker.

bodyText:
Enjoy fishing, swimming, or viewing the wildflower display that often wraps around the lake in the summer.

This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow. Shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers abound, often through July. Please stay on designated trails to protect the meadow, even if the trail is wet or muddy. The trail is wet and muddy until early August.

Lukens Lake (strenuous)
1.6 miles (2.6 km) round-trip; 1-2 hours,
200 foot (60 m) elevation gain.

Hours
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here
Begin at Lukens Lake Trailhead on Tioga Road, 2 miles east of White Wolf Road

Rules & Regulations
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings 
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility 
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
The paved parking area for Lukens Lake Trailhead is on the west side of Tioga Road and has three green recycle bins, three brown trash bins, two brown food lockers, and one wayside exhibit titled, Upper Montane. The trailhead is across the street and marked by a brown sign with an icon of a hiker inside a white square outline.

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, this is snow country, where plants and wildlife must cope with a high-mountain climate that brings winter snow that can remain until June. Here, the summers are short, cool, and moist. Only specialized species can survive. The red fir is one such hardy tree that can handle snowloads that exceed 30 feet. This tree grows in pure stands in the upper montane zone.

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of the first two labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the bottom to top of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet).

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic.

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, The plants and animals of the habitat around you are uniquely connected. Interdependence is the only way to suvive within this extreme environment. One important interrelationship involves fungus, flying squirrels, and owls. Root fungi absorb food from trees, while simultaneously improving the roots' water and nutrient absorption. Truffle-like mushrooms growing from this fungus provide a food source for flying squirrels. In turn, owls prey upon the flying squirrel. In this circle of dependency, one missing link might threaten the survival of all.

Illustration: A tree above ground and its roots below ground are a part of the main focal point of this illustration. A squirrel digs into the soil and reaches an oval-shaped object that is growing on the tree's roots underground. An owl is hovering in the background.

title: Lukens Lake Trailhead from White Wolf
listingDescription:
Enjoy this small mountain lake surround by a meadow full of shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers in the summer.

Follow the trail through a mixed conifer forest to Lukens Lake. The trail crosses the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River and is wet and muddy until early August.

Lukens Lake from White Wolf (Moderate)
4.6 miles (7.4 km) round trip; 2-3 hours,
400-foot (122-m) elevation gain.



Hours :
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here :
Begin across from White Wolf Lodge. If the road to White Wolf is closed, add at least two additional miles, roundtrip, to these hikes.

Rules & Regulations :
- Stay on established trails to protect the meadow
- Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
- Pack out what you pack in
- Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
- Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
- Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
- Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings :
- Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
- Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
- Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility :
This trail is not accessible.

images.altText: Tall pine trees surround a lake. Puffy clouds reflect in the water.

bodyText:

Accessibility :
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: The trailhead to Lukens Lake begins across the street from the White Wolf Lodge front office building. There is a row of parking spaces that are lined with tall pine trees. The trail begins near the center of the parking row and enters into the forest. Two trailhead signs are posted. The first sign is brown with white text and shows the mileage of several hiking destinations that begin at this trailhead. The sign reads, Lukens Lake - 2.3, Harden Lake - 5.7, Ten Lakes - 9.7, Pate Valley - 10.4, Smith Meadows - 11.1, Yosemite Valley - 13.9, Hetch Hetchy - 17.0. The other sign is also brown with white text and lists wilderness regulations. The sign reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

title: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area Trailhead
listingDescription: Explore and experience the wonder of being surrounded by some of the rarest and most remarkable living things on the planet in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias. Marvel at the towering giant sequoias in the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area, as you prepare to embark on your grand adventure into the grove. All trails begin here at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area.

images.altText: Wide flat accessible trail with place name sign and people walking on fence lined trail
images.title: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area

bodyText:
Explore and experience the wonder of being surrounded by some of the rarest and most remarkable living things on the planet in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias.

Marvel at the towering giant sequoias in the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area, as you prepare to embark on your grand adventure into the grove.

All trails begin here at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. They range from a relatively flat stroll to half- or full-day hikes that require strenuous uphill hiking. Each has its own rewards.

Big Trees Loop Trail (easy)

0.3 mile (0.5 km) loop from trailhead, 30 to 45 minutes (wheelchair accessible)

Begin at Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. Winding through a forest with many giant sequoias, this trail features the Fallen Monarch and interpretive panels on the life and ecology of giant sequoias. This loop is relatively flat and is wheelchair accessible.

Grizzly Giant Loop Trail (moderate)

2 miles (3.2 km) loop from trailhead, 1.5 to 2 hours

Begin at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. Start along the Mariposa Grove Trail at the Big Trees Loop and hike past notable trees such as the Bachelor and Three Graces, the Grizzly Giant, and California Tunnel Tree. Vehicles with a disability placard can drive as far as the Grizzly Giant accessible parking and enjoy this area of the grove via a section of trail that is wheelchair accessible.

Guardians Loop Trail (strenuous)

6.5 miles (10.5 km) round trip from trailhead, 4 to 6 hours
1,200 feet (366 m) elevation gain

Begin at Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. This trail follows a route that people have used to access the grove for generations. See famous sequoias such as the Bachelor and Three Graces, the Faithful Couple, and the Clothespin Tree along this somewhat strenuous route to the upper reaches of the grove. After hiking to the tranquil upper portion of the grove, a 1.5-mile (2.4 km) loop takes hikers past many famous features including the fallen Wawona Tunnel Tree, the Telescope Tree, and the Mariposa Grove Cabin.

Mariposa Grove Trail to Wawona Point (strenuous)

7 miles (11.3 km) round trip, 4 to 6 hours
1,200 feet (366 m) elevation gain

Begin at Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. This trail follows a route that people have used to access the grove for generations. See famous sequoias such as the Bachelor and Three Graces, the Faithful Couple, and the Clothespin Tree along this somewhat strenuous route to the upper reaches of the grove. Continue to historic Wawona Point, an overlook with panoramic views. A number of alternative trails are used to access the upper portion of the grove. These trails are generally steeper and more primitive than the Mariposa Grove Trail.

Seasonality

  • Take the shuttle and hike into the grove from early March through late November. Vehicles displaying disability placards can drive into the grove at 25mph and park at the Arrival Area.
  • From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

See website for more information.

Getting Here

Located near Yosemite National Park's South Entrance. Park at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and take the free shuttle (spring - fall) or hike into the grove, 2 miles one way. Only vehicles displaying a disability placard are permitted to drive into the Grove at any time.

Rules & Regulations

Stay on established trails

  • Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
  • Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time. Feeding or approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to keep your food within arm's reach at all times, or store properly.
  • Overnight camping is allowed in the Mariposa Grove from December 1 through April 15, if the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to cars. A wilderness permit is required to camp. Camping is only allowed above the Clothespin Tree.
  • In the winter, water is only available at the Welcome Plaza and pit toilets are available in the Mariposa Grove at the arrival area, near the Grizzly Giant, and near the Mariposa Grove Cabin.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. The Mariposa Grove Arrival Area is accessible, as well as the Big Trees Loop Trail, 0.3 mile (0.5 km). Vehicles displaying a disability placard can drive as far as the Grizzly Giant accessible parking area and enjoy a close up view of the Grizzly Giant and California Tunnel Tree, via a section of trail that is wheelchair accessible, 0.13 mile (0.21 km).
audioDescription:
Approaching the Mariposa Grove Trailhead from either the parking area or the shuttle drop off area, the most noticeable feature is the fenced-in pathway that zigzags between towering giant sequoias as it makes its way deeper into the grove. On the right side of the path entranceway sits a row of trash and recycle bins and a split log that serves as a long bench. To the left of the entranceway are several interpretive panels, a drinking fountain, and a bronze, tactile relief model of the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias (Caution: The bronze, tactile relief model is often in direct sunlight and could be too hot to touch). Three interpretive panels are lined up against a waist high fence. The first panel is titled A Way of Life Continues and explains the origins of stewardship of the grove by local native tribes, the Bishop Paiute Tribe, Bridgeport Indian Colony, Mono Lake Kutzadika Tribe, North Fork Rancheria of Mono Indians of California, Picayune Rancheria of Chukchansi Indians, Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation, and Tuolumne Band of Me-Wuk Indians. There is a sepia toned picture of a group of people, with a caption that reads, some members of the Tribal Working Group, Yosemite Conservancy, and NPS staff. There is also an area titled Greetings from the Traditionally Associated Tribes of Yosemite National Park, that contains five different tribal translations. There is also a map that shows the ancestral homelands of the park's Traditionally Associated Tribes, which are marked by a red dot in areas surrounding Yosemite.

The second panel is titled Visiting the Mariposa Grove. There is a map showing all the trails in the Mariposa Grove, and a list containing hiking trail options that range from easy, to moderate, to strenuous. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. A call-out box titled Grove Etiquette reads, You are visiting a truly special place. Please take care to not damage this grove or impact the experience of other visitors. Please stay on designated trails and respect fenced areas. Be a steward of the grove - please no climbing or graffiti. Strive to leave no trace. No dogs, no collecting, no bikes. A third panel is titled A Legacy of Conservation and shows a sepia toned picture of Abraham Lincoln, as well as a picture of a National Park Service (NPS) uniform hat and belt, to show the significance of the sequoia cones featured on both the NPS uniform hat band and belt. Panel text reads, Welcome to the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias. This forest is legendary, and even sacred, to those who have experienced its majesty-from the seven Traditionally Associated Tribes of Yosemite, to important conservation leaders, and visitors who saw their first sequoia just yesterday. As you explore the grove, you'll be following in the footsteps of countless people who have revered and worked to protect these magnificent trees. This grove is also honored because it is one of our country's first protected public lands. The seeds of the national park movement were sown here when artists, writers, politicians, and early preservationists convinced the US Congress and President Abraham Lincoln to protect the giant sequoias from logging, tourism, and development in the mid-1800s. Every National Park Service ranger carries a reminder of the significance of these trees and the movement they inspired. Look closely at the NPS emblem, belt, and hatband pictured here with the sequoia cone and tree silhouette. A sign at the trailhead reads, Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias.

title: Mariposa Grove Picnic Area
listingDescription: The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is a terrific place to enjoy your meal amongst nature! Whether it's before or after your visit to the Mariposa Grove, refuel your energy levels here, then continue seeing all that Yosemite National Park has to offer. The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is open at all times to vehicles displaying a disability placard and to those who are hiking the Washburn Trail.

images.altText: Picnic tables and restroom, grill, and garbage and recycling containers
images.title: Mariposa Grove Picnic Area
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Picnic Area

bodyText:
The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is a terrific place to enjoy your meal amongst nature! Whether it's before or after your visit to the Mariposa Grove, refuel your energy levels here, then continue seeing all that Yosemite National Park has to offer.

The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is open at all times to vehicles displaying a disability placard and to those who are hiking the Washburn Trail. Vehicles not displaying a disability placard may use the picnic area when shuttle buses are not operating.

Hours

From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

See website for more information.

Getting Here

The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area is located along both the Mariposa Grove Road and Washburn Trail.

Rules & Regulations

Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings

  • For your safety and that of wildlife:
  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Mariposa Grove Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible.
audioDescription: As you face the picnic area, knee-height granite boulders separate the gravel parking area from the picnic area. To the far left of the parking lot, a path leads into the picnic area. Trash and recycle bins and a vault toilet are on the left side of the path. To the right of the path are three picnic tables, in close proximity to each other. Each table has an extended top and each have their own grill. Trees and shrubs surround the dirt area.

title: Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 1: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area
listingDescription: Park at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and board the free shuttle bus to get a glimpse of these giants. The Mariposa Grove Shuttle provides free shuttle service between the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, near Yosemite's South Entrance, and the Mariposa Grove from early March through late November. This is the primary way to get to the Mariposa Grove. From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates.

images.altText: Bus at covered bus shelter in Mariposa Grove
images.title: Mariposa Grove - Shuttle Stop #1
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Arrival Area - Shuttle Stop #1

bodyText:
Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias is the park's largest stand of giant sequoias, with about 500 mature sequoias in the grove. Park at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza and board the free shuttle bus to get a personal glimpse of these giants.

The Mariposa Grove Shuttle provides free shuttle service between the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, near Yosemite's South Entrance, and the Mariposa Grove from early March through late November. This is the primary way to get to the Mariposa Grove.

From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

Shuttle operation dates are subject to change based on conditions and may vary from year to year. The road and shuttle service may open as early as April 1 and will close on or before November 30 (depending on conditions).

Season and Hours of Operation

  • April 1 through May 14: 8 am to 7 pm (last bus leaves Mariposa Grove at 8 pm). Buses pick up about every 15 minutes.

  • May 15 through September 7: 8 am to 7 pm (last bus leaves Mariposa Grove at 8 pm). Buses pick up about every 10 minutes.

  • September 8 through November 7: 8 am to 5:30 pm (last bus leaves Mariposa Grove at 6:30 pm). Buses pick up about every 15 minutes.

  • November 8 through November 30: 8 am to 3:30 pm (last bus leaves Mariposa Grove at 5 pm). Buses pick up about every 15 minutes.

  • December 1 through March 30: No shuttle service available.

See website for more information.

Getting Here

Mariposa Grove shuttle stop 1 is located in the Mariposa Grove, at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area.

Rules & Regulations

  • Allow wheelchairs to board first
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated
  • Board shuttles using the front doors ONLY, and exit through the rear doors
  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops
  • No pets
  • No food or drink
  • No smoking

Hazards & Warnings

In case of emergency, alert the shuttle driver or park staff.

Accessibility

Vehicles displaying a disability placard can either drive to the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, park in a designated accessible space, then ride the shuttle, or they can drive up the Mariposa Grove Road and park at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area or at the Grizzly Giant accessible parking area. Parking is limited.
audioDescription: The Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 1 has a bus stop shelter made of wooden posts and beams that has concrete sitting areas beneath. The Bus stop sign reads "1, Mariposa Grove Trailhead, Grove Shuttle, Shuttle Route," and shows a basic map of the shuttle route as well as the schedule, which both change with the seasons. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. The shuttle stop area is surrounded by giant sequoias and is near a restroom and water filling station.

title: Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 2: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza
listingDescription: The Mariposa Grove Shuttle provides free shuttle service between the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, near Yosemite's South Entrance, and the Mariposa Grove from early March through late November. This is the primary way to get to the Mariposa Grove. From approximately December to March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates.

images.altText: Shuttle bus near stop with map displayed nearby
images.title: Mariposa Grove - Shuttle Stop #2
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza - Shuttle Stop #2

  • May 15 through September 7: 8 am to 7 pm (last bus leaves Mariposa Grove at 8 pm). Buses pick up about every 10 minutes.

  • December 1 through March 30: No shuttle service available.

See website for more information.

Getting Here

Mariposa Grove shuttle stop 2 is located at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, near Yosemite National Park's South Entrance.

Rules & Regulations

  • Allow wheelchairs to board first
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated
  • Board shuttles using the front doors ONLY, and exit through the rear doors
  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops
  • No pets
  • No food or drink
  • No smoking

Hazards & Warnings

In case of emergency, alert the shuttle driver or park staff.

Accessibility

Vehicles displaying a disability placard can either drive to the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, park in a designated accessible space, then ride the shuttle, or they can drive up the Mariposa Grove Road and park at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area or at the Grizzly Giant accessible parking area. Parking is limited.
audioDescription: The Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza is built on a downward slope, allowing for four tiered areas. The lower first and second tiers are parking areas, where as the third tier is an information station containing interpretive panels, a bookstore, restrooms, drinking fountains, and benches. Steps lead to the fourth, upper most tier, where Mariposa Grove shuttle stop 2 is located. There is a bus stop shelter made of wooden posts and beams that has concrete sitting areas beneath. The Bus stop sign reads "Stop 2, Mariposa Grove Parking, Mariposa Grove Shuttle, Shuttle Route," and shows a basic map of the shuttle route as well as the schedule, which both change with the seasons. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

title: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza & Parking
listingDescription: The Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias is awe-inspiring. Leave noise and civilization behind to walk among these stately giants. Visitors have access to parking, restroom facilities, visitor information, and can board a free shuttle for the two mile ride to the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area.

images.altText: Wooden and stone building that houses the restrooms and Depot bookstore.
images.title: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza

bodyText:
The Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias is awe-inspiring. Leave noise and civilization behind to walk among these stately giants.

Visitors have access to parking, restroom facilities, visitor information, and can board a free shuttle for the two mile ride to the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. See local postings for shuttle information.

Pop into The Depot, a Yosemite Conservancy bookstore, your best source for information on Yosemite, to pick up any maps, guidebooks, gifts, or apparel before or after visiting the grove or shop online!

The road to the grove, beyond the welcome plaza, is closed to private vehicles when the shuttle is operating. Vehicles displaying a disability placard can drive up the Mariposa Grove Road at any time. There are designated accessible parking spaces at Mariposa Grove Arrival Area and at Grizzly Giant accessible parking area. Parking is limited.

Hours

From approximately December through March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

See website for more information.

Getting Here

After entering Yosemite National Park's South Entrance, turn right at the roundabout, the welcome plaza is less than a quarter-mile up the road.

Rules & Regulations

  • Bicycles are allowed on the Mariposa Grove Road between the welcome plaza (near South Entrance) and the Grizzly Giant when the road is open for the season. Bicycles are not allowed elsewhere in the the Mariposa Grove.
  • Pets are not allowed on any trails in the Mariposa Grove. Pets are allowed in the parking lots on leash only. Pets are not allowed on shuttles.

Accessibility

Vehicles displaying a disability placard can either drive to the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, park in a designated space, then ride the shuttle, or they can drive up the Mariposa Grove Road and park at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area or at the Grizzly Giant accessible parking area. Parking is limited.
audioDescription:
The Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza is built on a downward slope, allowing for four tiered areas. The lower first and second tiers are parking areas, which include designated spaces on the second tier parking area, where as the third tier is an information station containing interpretive panels, a bookstore, restrooms, drinking fountains, and benches. Steps lead to the fourth, upper most tier, where Mariposa Grove Shuttle Stop 2 is located. There is a bus stop shelter made of wooden posts and beams that has concrete sitting areas beneath.

The interpretive panels includes information about Giant Sequoia ecology, stewardship of the grove, how to visit the grove, and contains a map of Yosemite, highlighting other areas of the park. In the center of the interpretive panels is a large slice of a giant sequoia, with a sign titled A history revealed, which shows an illustration of the sequoia slice, and dates according to it's rings. One of the inner most rings dates back to 1149. There are also some bronze, tactile relief models of Sequoia trees, a chipmunk, and various paw prints.

title: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza Parking
listingDescription: Walk among Yosemite's stately giants in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias.Visitors have access to parking, restroom facilities, visitor information, and can board a free shuttle for the two mile ride to the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. See local postings for shuttle information.The road to the grove, beyond the welcome plaza, is closed to private vehicles when the shuttle is operating. There is limited parking in the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area for visitors who wish to ent

images.altText: Cars parked in the lot at the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza
images.title: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza Parking
images.caption: Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza Parking

bodyText:
Walk among Yosemite's stately giants in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias.

Visitors have access to parking, restroom facilities, visitor information, and can board a free shuttle for the two mile ride to the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area. See local postings for shuttle information.

The road to the grove, beyond the welcome plaza, is closed to private vehicles. 

Vehicles displaying a disability placard can drive up the Mariposa Grove Road at any time. There are designated accessible parking spaces at Mariposa Grove Arrival Area and at Grizzly Giant accessible parking area. Parking is limited.

Hours

From approximately December through March, the Mariposa Grove Road is closed to vehicles and the shuttle no longer operates. The road, along with all trails within the Grove, remain open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

See website for more information.

Getting Here

After entering Yosemite National Park's South Entrance, turn right at the roundabout, the welcome plaza is less than a quarter-mile up the road.

Rules & Regulations

  • Bicycles are allowed on the Mariposa Grove Road up to near the Grizzly Giant when the road is open. Bicycles are not allowed anywhere else in the Mariposa Grove.
  • Pets are not allowed on any trails in the Mariposa Grove. Pets are allowed in the parking lots on leash only. Pets are not allowed on shuttles.
  • Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.
  • You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility

Vehicles displaying a disability placard can either drive to the Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, park in a designated space, then ride the shuttle, or they can drive up the Mariposa Grove Road and park at the Mariposa Grove Arrival Area or at the Grizzly Giant accessible parking area. Parking is limited.
audioDescription: The parking lot consists of an upper and lower lot. The one-way entrance is in the lower lot and leads to a long row of parking spaces. Near the end of the row, the road turns left and descends slightly uphill, then loops to the left to another long row of parking. The upper lot eventually leads to the exit of the property. In the bottom lot, half-way across the parking lot are a green recycle dumpster, a brown trash dumpster, and a set of steps that lead to the upper lot, across a crosswalk, to the exhibits, store, and shuttle boarding area. Several designated accessible parking spots are located to the right of a large, wooden building that has a sign that reads, Mariposa Grove Welcome Plaza, in front. Tall pine trees surround most of the parking area.

title: May Lake Trailhead
listingDescription: Spend a day, or a night, at this stunning alpine lake that reflects a picturesque view of Mt. Hoffmann. A short trail leads through a conifer forest and across granite slabs to reach May Lake. Enjoy views of Half Dome and surrounding mountains on the way.If the dirt road is closed, the trailhead will require an additional 2 mile hike uproad, one way. May Lake (moderate)2.4 mi (3.9 km) round-trip; 1-2 hours 485 ft (150 m) elevation gainFor hiking and trail information, plea

images.altText: A mountain peak and puffy clouds reflect in a calm, glassy lake.

bodyText:
Spend a day, or a night, at this stunning alpine lake that reflects a picturesque view of Mt. Hoffmann.

A short trail leads through a conifer forest and across granite slabs to reach May Lake. Enjoy views of Half Dome and surrounding mountains on the way.

If the dirt road is closed, the trailhead will require an additional 2 mile hike uproad, one way.

May Lake (moderate)
2.4 mi (3.9 km) round-trip; 1-2 hours
485 ft (150 m) elevation gain

For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.

Hours:
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here:
Begin at the May Lake parking area, 1.75 miles (2.8 km) north of Tioga Road.

Rules & Regulations:
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
No oversized vehicles on road to parking area.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings:
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility:
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
The May Lake Trailhead is in a small parking lot located, on a rugged, paved, one-lane road east of the Tioga Road. When the parking lot is at capacity or the road is closed due to snow and ice, an additional two-mile hike, one-way, from the Tioga Road is necessary. A brown trash bin, green recycle bin, and small, brown structure, which holds the vault toilet, line the parking lot. The dirt trail begins in the midst of trees, near a small pond, next to the vault toilet, and is marked by two signs.

The first metal sign reads, May Lake High Sierra Camp - 1.2 miles.

The second metal sign is brown and reads, Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry watercourses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red line diagonally slashed across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

title: McGurk Meadow Trailhead
listingDescription: Traipse through a meadow of wildflowers (while staying on the trail, of course), and embrace the cool sub-alpine air this remarkable hike has to offer. The trail leads downhill to McGurk Meadow and the site of an old cabin that belonged to sheepherder John McGurk. During early summer, look for a tremendous show of wildflowers.

images.altText: Green grassy meadow with blue skies and trees
images.title: McGurk Meadow
images.caption: McGurk Meadow

bodyText:
Traipse through a meadow of wildflowers (while staying on the trail, of course), and embrace the cool sub-alpine air this remarkable hike has to offer.

The trail leads downhill to McGurk Meadow and the site of an old cabin that belonged to sheepherder John McGurk. During early summer, look for a tremendous show of wildflowers. You can continue along the trail an additional mile (1.6 km) to reach the Pohono Trail, which runs west to Dewey Point and Tunnel View and east to Bridalveil Creek, Taft Point, and Glacier Point.

McGurk Meadow (strenuous)

  • 1.6 miles (2.5 km) round-trip; 1-2 hours,

  • 150 ft (50 m) elevation gain

Dewey Point

  • 8.2 miles (13.2 km) round-trip; 4-6 hours,

  • 750 ft (225 m) elevation gain

Hours

The trail is only accessible when the Glacier Point Road is open, approximately late May through October or November. When Badger Pass Ski Area is open (mid to late December through March), the Glacier Point Road is groomed for cross-country skiing beyond the ski area. See website for more information.

Getting Here

Begin at McGurk Meadow Trailhead, 0.2 miles west of Bridalveil Creek Campground turnoff, along the Glacier Point Road.

Rules & Regulations

The Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, call: 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat stream or spring water.

  • Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.

  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility

This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
A small, dirt, roadside parking area is located about 10 yards away from a brown and white sign that reads McGurk Meadow, which has an icon of a hiker inside a white square outline. In the parking area, which is lined with trees, one green recycle bin and one brown trash bin sit next to two brown food lockers. At the McGurk Meadow trailhead sign situated along the road, a dirt path leads into the shaded forest. Two signs are bolted to a metal post. The top sign is brown and white and it reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness. Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least 6 inches deep 100 feet away from water. Bury or pack out toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

The second sign is a metal sign with text cut out of it that reads, view of Yosemite Valley 3.9 miles, Dewey Point 3.9 miles, Taft Point 4.2 miles, Crocker Point 4.6 miles, Stanford Point 5.3 miles, Glacier Point 7.6 miles, Inspiration Point 9.8 miles, Yosemite Valley via Union Point 12.4 miles.

title: Meadow Grill
listingDescription: Curry Village's Meadow Grill offers a wide variety of grilled foods - including burgers, chicken sandwiches, fish sandwiches, salads and numerous vegetarian options. Open April - September, see website for hours. Located in Curry Village, in eastern Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: People stand in line beneath a sign that reads, 'Meadow Grill,' on a deck with picnic tables.

bodyText:
Curry Village's Meadow Grill offers a wide variety of grilled foods - including burgers, chicken sandwiches, fish sandwiches, salads and numerous vegetarian options.

Hours:
April - September
See website for hours

Getting Here:
You can reach Yosemite Valley via Highways 41, 140, and 120. Follow signs for Curry Village, located in eastern Yosemite Valley. 

Rules & Regulations:
Human food is not healthy for wild animals, and it is illegal to feed any animal in the park.

Accessibility:
This outdoor dining patio is accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby.
audioDescription: Curry Village services are located in one building complex, with a layout shaped like a big square, with only two sides of the square being utilized. As you approach the building from the Curry Village Parking area, there is a raised deck that extends along a majority of the front side of the building that requires going up a few steps. Circular, sometimes umbrella'd, picnic tables are randomly placed on the deck. Placement of services are as follows, from left to right, The Mountain Shop and Yosemite Mountaineering School entrance, the Meadow Grill order and pick-up windows, and The Curry Village Gift Shop. Near the gift shop are another set of steps and a ramp that leads down to a walking path that goes around the side of the building to more services. Another raised deck extends across almost half of that side of the building. After climbing a few steps onto the deck, more circular picnic tables are randomly placed about. Placement of services are as follows, from left to right, The Pizza Patio order and pick-up windows, the Curry Village Bar, and the entrance to go inside the Curry Village Pavilion to access Mother Curry's Kitchen, the Coffee Corner, indoor seating, and restrooms.

title: Merced Grove
listingDescription: Visit Yosemite's quietest stand of giant sequoias at the Merced Grove.The Merced Grove is home to approximately 20 mature giant sequoias, accessible only on foot. This trail follows an old road that curves down into the Merced Grove, the smallest and most secluded of Yosemite's three sequoia groves. The trail drops down 1.5 miles, making this a moderate hike on the uphill portion.

images.altText: Brown and white sign at trailhead "Merced Grove"
images.title: Merced Grove
images.caption: Merced Grove Trailhead Sign

bodyText:
