The Merced Grove will close on July 10, 2023 and will remain closed for 2-3 months. This closure is needed to safely remove hazardous fuels surrounding the giant sequoias. High severity fires fueled by hazardous fuels have killed nearly 20% of all giant sequoias in the past three years in the southern part of the range. This is the first step towards implementing an interagency prescribed fire that will provide protection of the giant sequoias from high severity fire and promote sequoia seedling germination. This project is part of a larger project to remove hazardous fuels from around giant sequoias and communities.

Visit Yosemite's quietest stand of giant sequoias at the Merced Grove.

The Merced Grove is home to approximately 20 mature giant sequoias, accessible only on foot. This trail follows an old road that curves down into the Merced Grove, the smallest and most secluded of Yosemite's three sequoia groves. The trail drops down 1.5 miles, making this a moderate hike on the uphill portion. An old ranger patrol cabin, the former summer retreat of park superintendents, is part of the grove's history. Look for dogwoods blooming here in the spring.

Hours

Year-round
In the winter, The trail leading into Merced Grove is open to hikers, snowshoers, and skiers.

Winter in Merced Grove

Ski or snowshoe touring in Yosemite can be a magnificent experience! The Merced Grove has a trail rating of 'Most Difficult.' The first half mile is level and easy, providing a good warm-up for the steep 1 mile (1.6 km) descent into the grove. This trail requires heavy snowfall from a cold, lower-elevation storm to be skiable. Trails are not groomed in the Crane Flat area. Icy or
crusty conditions, or deep snow can make trails much more difficult.

3 miles (4.8 km) round trip;
520-foot (158 m) elevation gain on return.
1-3 hours.

Getting Here

Located 3.5 miles north of Crane Flat and 4.5 miles south of Big Oak Flat Entrance, along the Big Oak Flat Road (Highway 120 from the west). The trail is marked by a sign and a post labeled B-10.

Rules & Regulations

Pets or bicycles are not allowed on this trail.

Hazards & Warnings

There is no drinking water at the parking area or down in the grove. Be sure to bring drinking water with you.

Accessibility

This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
A small, paved, parking area is next to a main road and is surrounded by forest. A green recycle bin, brown trash bin, and a small, brown, wood, structure, which holds a vault toilet, all line the parking lot. A wayside exhibit, framed in thick, log posts, stands at the trailhead, which appears to be a wide dirt road that is gated at the entrance.

The green-toned exhibit panel is titled Merced Grove Trailhead and has an illustrated map, which takes up a majority of the left side of the panel. The map shows a red dot at the bottom of the map, which is labeled, you are here. A yellow squiggle line, representing the trail, makes its way through a faint canopy of trees to the grove. An aerial view of about 12 bold tree tops are shown at the end of the trail, as well as a small cabin.

Caption: The path to the Merced Grove is the roadbed of the historic Coulterville Road. Started in 1870, John Taylor McLean invested his entire fortune to ensure the success of the project. Although his efforts failed financially, his contribution resulted in the historic accomplishment of completing the first road into Yosemite Valley. Regularly scheduled stage travel began June 18, 1874.

Black and white photo: A classic car is stopped next to a large tree, on a narrow dirt road that passes through a forest of tall trees.

Caption: This small grove of about twenty trees was named Crane Flat Grove by the Whitney Survey in 1870. The grove was later re-named Merced Grove, reportedly due to its proximity to the Merced River.

Text on the right side of the panel reads, the smallest of Yosemite's three giant sequoia groves, the Merced Grove offers perhaps the best opportunity for a solitary experience among these colossal giants.

While enjoying your walk to the grove, consider the rarity of this experience. At one time, sequoias covered an extensive range, but now grow only in isolated groves on the Sierra Nevada's western slope. Limited by specialized growing needs, these trees require both moisture-mostly from winter snowfalls-as well as periodic fire. Frequent burns expose bare mineral soil for seeds to take root. Fire also reduces the number of competing species and opens the forest canopy for sunlight to reach the sun-loving trees. Sequoias appear large and strong; however, their shallow roots are quite vulnerable to damage. Avoid walking in areas immediately surrounding the bases of the trees. Leave cones and other natural items that you find.

Illustration: A wedge-like, cross-section illustration that is thick on one end and tapers to a thin edge on the other, shows the slope of the trail. A red dot at the top of the wedge reads, you are here. A yellow line, indicating the trail, squiqqles downhill to the grove of trees. At the bottom of the wedge, an arrow goes from one end to the other and is labeled, 1.5 miles.

Trail Conditions: Carry enough drinking water for a fairly rigorous hike. Make sure to allow 3 to 4 hours for a 3-mile round-trip hike. There are no restrooms or running water in the grove. The return uphill is moderately strenuous (600ft. (183 m.) elevation gain). This trail is marked for cross-country skiing and snowshoeing in winter.

Black and white photo: A small log cabin sits in the midst of a forest. On the front side of the cabin, a door is in the center with one window on each side. A stone chimney rises out of the roof.

Caption: The old cabin along this trail was built in 1934 as a summer retreat for park superintendents. More recently, it has served as a retreat and learning space for school children visiting the park.

title: Mirror Lake
listingDescription: Mirror Lake is famous for its reflections of Half Dome and Mount Watkins and is one of the few lakes that are easily accessible in Yosemite National Park. Mirror Lake is a seasonal lake on Tenaya Creek, in the shadow of Half Dome. Wayside exhibits explain the natural and cultural features of the area. Mirror Lake is in a state of transition. Sand carried by Tenaya Creek collects here, and will eventually form a meadow.

images.altText: Low water levels in Mirror Lake with people wading into water
images.title: Mirror Lake
images.caption: Mirror Lake during a warmer time of year when water levels are low.

bodyText:
Mirror Lake is famous for its reflections of Half Dome and Mount Watkins and is one of the few lakes that are easily accessible in Yosemite National Park.

Mirror Lake is a seasonal lake on Tenaya Creek, in the shadow of Half Dome. Wayside exhibits explain the natural and cultural features of the area.

Mirror Lake is in a state of transition. Sand carried by Tenaya Creek collects here, and will eventually form a meadow. Even now, the shallow lake disappears into the sand in late summer, transforming into "Mirror Meadow." Exhibits along the trail tell the story of this transformation, and highlight some of the cultural history of the area.

Hours

Year-round
24 hours

Getting Here

Located in Yosemite Valley, along the Happy Isles loop, via a one mile paved service road, beginning at shuttle stop #17. Private vehicles are not permitted along the Happy Isles Loop unless displaying a disability placard.

Rules & Regulations

  • Leashed pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed on the first paved mile of the trail. Beyond that, they are prohibited.
  • Keep your food within arm's reach at all times and do not feed the wildlife.
  • Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.).
  • Mirror Lake is considered a stream and is only open to fishing during stream fishing season. The season for stream and river fishing begins the last Saturday in April and continues through November 15. People 16 or older should have a valid California fishing license. See website for more fishing regulations.

Hazards & Warnings

  • During spring and early summer, when water levels are highest, always remember when approaching moving water to look at the conditions downstream. Waters in this area may appear ankle deep at first, but can quickly become thigh deep, and, all too often, hikers are swept into dangerous whitewater and pinned against rocks.
  • Learn more about past experiences visitors had with swift water in this area of the park.

Accessibility 

Vehicles with a disability placard are permitted to drive at 15 mph, with emergency flashers on, to Mirror Lake. There are two designated accessible parking spaces available.
audioDescription: Depending on time of year, Mirror Lake is either a full body of water or an open meadow. The water reflects the surrounding granite cliffs that rise up above the treeline, including the iconic Half Dome. The lake is surrounded by a forest of oaks, pines, and firs.

title: Mirror Lake Trailhead
listingDescription: With a fresh perspective looking up at Half Dome directly from its base, you'll be rewarded with views of Tenaya Canyon, Mount Watkins, Washington Column, and more. While pleasant at any time of year, Mirror Lake is fullest in spring and early summer. When water is calm, the lake offers beautiful reflections of surrounding cliffs. Mirror Lake is often referred to as Mirror Meadow in late summer due to the lack of water.

images.altText: Signs and service road at Mirror Lake Trailhead
images.title: Mirror Lake Trailhead
images.caption: Mirror Lake Trailhead signage and service road to Mirror Lake

bodyText:
With a fresh perspective looking up at Half Dome directly from its base, you'll be rewarded with views of Tenaya Canyon, Mount Watkins, and Washington Column.

While pleasant at any time of year, Mirror Lake is fullest in spring and early summer. When water is calm, the lake offers beautiful reflections of surrounding cliffs. Mirror Lake is often referred to as Mirror Meadow in late summer due to the lack of water. 

The first mile of this trail is a paved service road that leads directly to Mirror Lake. You may access the loop trail from the end of the paved path. The loop follows Tenaya Creek beyond the lake, and crosses two bridges after the Snow Creek Trail junction before returning past Mirror Lake on the south side of Tenaya Canyon. (There is no safe access to the north side of Mirror Lake directly from the south side of the loop, except via bridges at the west and east ends of the trail). See map.

Mirror Lake (Easy)

2 miles (3.2 km) round trip; 1 hour; flat

Mirror Lake Loop (Moderate)

5 miles (8 km) full loop; 2-3 hours; flat

Water

Drinking water is not available at the trailhead or along the trail. Come prepared.

Restrooms

Vault toilets are available about 0.5 miles (0.8 km) from the trailhead and also at Mirror Lake.

Hours

Year-round

Getting Here

Located in Yosemite Valley, along the Happy Isles loop at shuttle stop #17. Private vehicles are not permitted along the Happy Isles Loop unless displaying a disability placard.

Rules & Regulations

  • Leashed pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed on the first paved mile of the trail. Beyond that, they are prohibited.
  • Keep your food within arm's reach at all times and do not feed the wildlife.
  • Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.).

Hazards & Warnings 

  • Be aware of slick conditions along the south side of this loop trail during winter and early spring. When winter conditions exist, consider making an out and back trip along the north side of the loop.
  • Stay on the trail! This is especially important during spring and early summer when water levels are highest. When hiking on the south side of the loop, hikers often spot what appears to be an easy way to rock-hop across Tenaya Creek, either just for fun, or as a way to shortcut the loop and rejoin the trail without doing the entire loop. While this crossing is only ankle deep at first, it quickly becomes thigh deep, and, all too often, hikers are swept into dangerous whitewater and pinned against rocks. Don't be tempted to leave the trail, and always remember when approaching moving water to look at the conditions downstream.

Accessibility

Vehicles with a disability placard are permitted to drive at 15 mph, with emergency flashers on, to Mirror Lake. There are two designated accessible parking spaces available.
audioDescription:
A green and white shuttle stop sign stands next to the roadside turnout where the shuttle bus stops. The sign reads, Valley shuttle, Mirror Lake Trailhead, and has the number 17 in white font within a green circle. Next to the sign is a wooden shelter that holds two benches. A yellow chain barrier is set up to help queue the line. A brown trash bin, a green recycle bin, and a wayside exhibit and a sign that has three small panels across the top and a large map on the bottom, are near the shuttle stop shelter. A paved path/road retreats into the trees behind the shelter. The first panel on the sign is yellow with a green bar across the top. Text in the green bar reads, shuttle bus schedule. The text in the yellow section reads, shuttle stop 17, Mirror Lake. From 7am to 10am, service every 30 minutes. From 10am to 7pm, service every 20 minutes. From 7pm to 10pm, service every 30 minutes.

The second panel is white with a blue bar across the top. Text in the blue bar reads, Did You Know? Text in the white section reads, Mirror Lake is not really a lake at all. Until the middle of the 20th century, park personnel dredged sand to maintain a pond that reflected the cliffs above. Current park policy is to let the natural succession of pond to meadow occur. During high water, however, you can still see a stunning reflection of Half Dome. Photo: One person stands in ankle-deep snow, with a backpack on the ground by his side, and his back turned from the camera. He is facing a small body of water and the large face of Half Dome which towers over this lake. Snow covers the landscape.

Caption: At Half Dome's base, Mirror Lake forms in winter and spring, but is more of a sandy beach during the dry season. NPS photo by Erik Skindrud.

The third panel is white with an orange bar across the top. Text in the orange bar reads, Be Bear Aware. Text in the white box reads, Keeping bears away from your food isn't just a way to avoid a fine-it could save a bear's life. Do not store food in vehicles after dark. When not stored in a locker or cabin, food must be within arm's length. Stay at least 50 yards from a bear. If a bear approaches, yell to scare it away.

Photo: A reddish-brown black bear with yellow plastic tags on both ears, is hanging halfway out of a parked car's side door window. The door frame is bent half way down, the side view mirror is dangling, and the glass has been busted out. It is dark out.

Caption: Bear break-ins can cost thousands of dollars and put visitors and bears at risk. NPS photo by Tammy Evans.

A large map showing three different shuttle routes in Yosemite Valley is below. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

The wayside exhibit panel is located on the right side of the path and is titled, Mirror Lake. The panel has a faint, black and white, background photo of a body of water lined with trees and tall, granite, rock faces. Text reads, in the 19th century, Mirror Lake became famous for its magnificent views of surrounding peaks reflected in the water's glassy surface. But the "lake" was misnamed - it is simply a broad shallow pool in Tenaya Creek. The reflecting pool varies with the season. By late summer, when Tenaya Creek is no longer fed by melting snows from above, the pool disappears.

Under a heading that reads, A Well-Traveled Path, text reads, Mirror Lake was a much publicized attraction for late 19th century tourists. It is still one of Yosemite's most popular hiking destinations. The view of Half Dome's 4,800-foot sheer face, seen from its base, is an attraction any time of the year.

Another section of the panel is about mountain lion habitat and reads, you are in a mountain lion habitat. Children should not run ahead or lag behind on the trail. Hiking alone and jogging are not recommended. In the unlikely event that you see a mountain lion, do the following:

Stay calm. Do not run. Do not turn your back on the lion.
Adults should pick up small children.
Make yourself appear as large as possible; raise your arms over your head and open your jacket.
If it acts aggressively, wave your arms, shout, and throw rocks and sticks at the lion.
If attacked, fight back!

Illustration: A mountain lion, standing on a downhill slope, faces to the left with its mouth slightly open and its ears perked.

title: Mist Trail and John Muir Trail Trailhead
listingDescription: Climb along nature's "giant staircase," where you will be rewarded with close-up views of two waterfalls and numerous geologic features (depending on how far you choose to hike). Powerful and turbulent, these two waterfalls will soak you in spring and entice you year-round.

images.altText: A full Vernal Fall with hikers along the rock steps of the Mist Trail
images.title: Mist Trail and John Muir Trail Trailhead
images.caption: Mist Trail leading to Vernal Fall

bodyText:
The very popular John Muir and Mist Trails offer spectacular, up-close views of two large waterfalls, enjoyable scenery along the Merced River, and unique views across Yosemite Valley. About 1 trail mile from the trailhead, beyond the Vernal Fall Footbridge, the Mist Trail and the John Muir Trail diverge. Consider accessing Vernal and Nevada Fall via the Mist Trail, looping around and taking the John Muir Trail back down to the Valley. Prepare for slippery footing and a tremendous amount of waterfall spray in spring and early summer. See more information about trails. 

Water

Drinking water is available at shuttle stop #16, near the trailhead, and also at the Vernal Fall Footbridge (May to October). This is the only drinking water available along the trail, so carry plenty of water for your hike.

Amount of water to bring

Vernal Fall Footbridge 1 quart/liter
Top of Vernal Fall 2 quarter/liters
Top of Nevada Fall 3-4 quarts/liters

Restrooms

Restrooms are located at the shuttle stop, near the trailhead. Additionally, restrooms are located at the Vernal Fall footbridge, approximately 1 mile up the trail (May to October). Vault toilets are available beyond the top of Vernal Fall (along the Mist Trail) and at the top of Nevada Fall (along the Mist Trail).

Vernal Fall Footbridge (Moderate)

1.6 miles (2.6 km) round trip; 1-1.5 hours
400 feet (120 m) elevation gain

Top of Vernal Fall (Strenuous)

2.4 miles (3.9 km) round trip (via Mist Trail); 3 hours
1000 feet (300m) elevation gain

Top of Nevada Fall (Strenuous)

5.4 miles (8.7 km) round trip (via Mist Trail); 5-6 hours
2,000 feet (610 m) elevation gain

You can also take the John Muir Trail to the top of Vernal Fall (via the Clark Point cutoff) and the top of Nevada Fall, or combine the Mist Trail and John Muir Trail into a loop. See map.

Hours

Year-round, however, the lower portion of the Mist Trail along Vernal Fall closes in winter due to risk of falling ice and rock. Also, the upper portion of the John Muir Trail between Clark Point and the top of Nevada Fall is closed in winter due to treacherously icy conditions. Keep in mind that the sections of trail that remain open in the winter may be very icy and/or snowy. View current conditions for trail closures.

Getting Here

Located at Happy Isles at shuttle stop #16. Follow the signs across the bridge to where the trail begins. There is no parking in the immediate area.

Rules & Regulations

  • Stay on the established trail: do not swim or wade in the river and do not walk along the edge of the river.
  • Observe warning signs and railings - these exist for your safety.
  • Pets, bicycles, and strollers are prohibited.
  • Do not shortcut switchbacks, which causes rapid trail erosion and results in injuries.
  • Keep your food within arm's reach at all times and do not feed the wildlife.
  • Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.).

Hazards & Warnings

Carry a head lamp (with fresh or extra batteries) in case you end up hiking more slowly or farther then planned and find yourself hiking back in the dark.
Sprained ankles and knee injuries are common on this trail. There are many areas of loose rock/decomposed granite, mixed with steep steps, and water, which makes for slippery footing in places.

Avoid becoming dehydrated or experiencing heat exhaustion. Drink plenty and drink often; pace yourself; rest in the shade; and eat salty snacks.

The granite steps along the Mist Trail leading up to the brink of Vernal Fall can be slick and crowded. Consider making a loop by continuing on the trail, past the brink of Vernal Fall and Emerald Pool, taking the cutoff trail to Clark Point, and then hiking down the John Muir Trail.

Accessibility

This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: At the trailhead, a brown sign with a hiker icon reads, Mist Trail, Vernal Fall, Nevada Fall and John Muir Trail, and has an arrow pointing right. A sandy path next to a river eventually ends and takes a hard left up an immediately steep, paved trail. The hike has started at this point and proceeds uphill, into the forest. Not too far up the trail, which is lined with shed-sized boulders in some areas, is a large wooden sign that lists the destinations reachable on this trail.

title: Mono Meadow Trailhead
listingDescription: Enjoy magnificent views of the Clark Range, Mount Starr King, and Half Dome, from Mono Meadow. The trail descends steeply to Mono Meadow-an area that is very wet throughout the summer. Expect log crossings over creeks and lots of mud. Follow the trail from the east end of the meadow for a half mile (0.8 km) to an unmarked clearing. From here, the views will open up to the Clark Range and beyond.

images.altText: Trail sign in a wooded area
images.title: Mono Meadow Trailhead
images.caption: Mono Meadow Trailhead

bodyText:
Enjoy magnificent views of the Clark Range, Mount Starr King, and Half Dome, from Mono Meadow.

The trail descends steeply to Mono Meadow; an area that is very wet throughout the summer. Expect log crossings over creeks and lots of mud. Follow the trail from the east end of the meadow for a half mile (0.8 km) to an unmarked clearing. From here, the views will open up to the Clark Range and beyond.

Mono Meadow (strenuous)

  • 3 miles (4.8 km) round-trip; 2-3 hours

Hours

The trail is only accessible when the Glacier Point Road is open, approximately late May through October or November.

Getting Here

Begin at Mono Meadow parking area (2.5 miles east of Bridalveil Creek Campground), along the Glacier Point Road.

Rules & Regulations

The Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call: 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat stream or spring water.

  • Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.

  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility

This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: The Mono Meadows Trailhead is found at the east end of a dirt parking lot. The parking area is surrounded by forest, with Glacier Point Road to the north. Two brown trash bins and two green recycle bins, along with a row of brown, metal food lockers line the outskirts of the parking lot. Two signs are bolted to a metal post at the trailhead to Mono Meadows. The top sign is metal with letters that are cut out of it. The sign reads, Mono Meadows 0.6 miles, Illilouette Creek 2.0 miles, Nevada Fall 6.1 miles, and Buck Camp 15.3 miles. The lower sign is metal with words etched out of it. The words were painted red, but a majority of it has faded or chipped off. The text reads, entering Yosemite wilderness. Wilderness permit required, overnight users only. Pets and firearms prohibited. No wood fires above 9,600 feet. Pack out all that you pack in. Bear habitat - proper food storage required by federal law.

title: Mono Pass Trailhead
listingDescription: Follow the path of Yosemite's first people, over their trade route to the east. This historic, trans-Sierra trail climbs gently at first from the Mono Pass parking area, through wet meadows and rushing creeks. At the Spillway Lake junction, the trail climbs steadily and more steeply to Mono Pass (elevation 10,600 feet). Don't miss the spectacular view of Mono Lake and Bloody Canyon.

images.altText: A sign that reads, 'Mono Pass,' and has an icon of a hiker and an arrow pointing left, can be seen through some trees.

bodyText:
Follow the path of Yosemite's first people, over their trade route to the east.

This historic, trans-Sierra trail climbs gently at first from the Mono Pass parking area, through wet meadows and rushing creeks. At the Spillway Lake junction, the trail climbs steadily and more steeply to Mono Pass (elevation 10,600 feet). Don't miss the spectacular view of Mono Lake and Bloody Canyon: from the pass, hike a bit farther toward Upper Sardine Lake.

Mono Pass (moderately strenuous)
8 miles (12.9 km) round-trip; 4-6 hours
1,000 ft (305 m) elevation gain

Parker Pass is also accessible via this trailhead.

For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.

Hours
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here 
Begin at Mono Pass trailhead, on Tioga Road, six miles east of Tuolumne Meadows.

Rules & Regulations 
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings 
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility 
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: The small, paved, parking area for Mono Pass Trailhead is located along the south side of Tioga Road. It is marked by a brown metal sign that has a white icon and text. The sign reads, 'Mono Pass,' and has an icon of a backpacker and an arrow that pointing to the right.In the parking area, there are two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, a row of food lockers, and a small, brown facility, which holds a vault toilet. Two small signs that read, 'no camping,' and 'no dogs,' line the curb, near the trailhead. A wooden fence separates the parking area from the wilderness area.Six signs line the dirt path at the Mono Pass Trailhead. The first sign is a wayside exhibit titled Yosemite Ghost Mines, and has a faded black and white photo of a log structure, too shabby and small to be a cabin, but very cabin-like. Text reads, as early as 1860, prospectors explored Mono Pass in search of rich rock. Here, among the glacially carved granite and craggy peaks of the Sierra crest, these hardy men discovered silver deposits and went to work in hopes of fortune.Buildings of the Past - five log cabins mark the location of the Golden Crown and Ella Bloss miners near Mono Pass. This windswept site was established in 1879 during the Tioga silver boom that also produced Bennettville and the Great Sierra Mine near Tioga Pass. Significant wealth was predicted, but around 1890, the mines were abandoned.A Past Preserved - The cabins are increasingly fragile reminders of mining on the Sierra crest. Please help preserve these valuable historic resources by not using them as campsites or fire shelters. It is illegal to damage, deface, or remove archaeological objects or features from federal land. The second sign is separated into five sections. Two small square panels on top, a large map in the middle, and two small square panels on bottom. The Top left panel is maroon with white text and reads, Mono Pass Trailhead, follow the path of Yosemite's first people, the Miwok, over their trade route to the east.Mono Pass is 3.7 miles and Parker Pass is 5.2 miles. The entire watershed of the Dana Fork of the Tuolumne is closed to overnight camping to protect water quality.The top right panel is blue with white text and reads, Wilderness Regulations, the natural integrity of Yosemite's high country depends on you. Help protect the wilderness, and avoid a citation, by following these regulations.Camp at least four trail miles from all developed areas.Pets, firearms, and bicycles are prohibited in wilderness.Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks kills vegetation and causes erosion. Maximum group size for cross-country travel is eight people.Avoid disturbing wildlife and other visitors by keeping quiet on the trail and in camp.Use a gas stove for cooking; wood fires are allowed only below 9,600 feet in existing fire rings using dead and downed wood.Leave campsites as you find them; do not build windbreaks, fire rings, hitch racks, chairs, drainage trenches, or other "improvements."Pack out everything you carry in; do not burn trash.Wilderness permit required for all overnight use.A series of three white circles containing three different icons are outlined in red and have a red diagonal line slashing through the middle. The three icons are of a gun, a dog, and a person on a bicycle.The large middle panel is a detailed map of the eastern portion of the park. Roads, trails, peaks, and lakes are labeled. For more information about Yosemite maps, please call 209/379-1035.The bottom left panel is blue with white text and reads, Water Quality - clean, sparkling water is one of the joys of the high country. Wildlife, wilderness visitors, and people downstream all need clean water to stay healthy.Protect your water suppy by following these regulations and suggestions:Camp at least 100 feet (40 steps) from water.Deposit human waste in a six-inch-deep hole at least 100 feet from water; carry out toilet paper.Wash dishes and yourself at least 100 feet from water; even biodegradable soap pollutes.Carry a large water container and limit your trips to collect water; eroded stream banks and lake shores contribute to poor water quality.Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks increases erosion and leads to silt-filled streams.Giardia lamblia is a disease-causing protozoan that can be present in all Sierran water; treat all water before drinking. The bottom right panel is yellow with black text and reads, Black Bears - the health and well-being of Yosemite's bears depends on you.Bears are intelligent, curious, adaptable, and hungry. Human food, however, is harmful to bears and other animals here. Keep wildlife wild by using these food storage methods.At the trailhead: Remove all food, ice chests, and scented items from your car. Store them in food storage lockers where available. Never feed bears or other wildlife.In the backcountry: Store food, garbage, and scented items in bearproof canisters, available at front country locations. Keep items s

title: Mountain Room Lounge
listingDescription: In addition to the wonderful Swedish-style fireplace, you'll enjoy the classic furnishings as you sip a cocktail and munch on delicious appetizers. During the warmer months, you can enjoy sitting outside on the patio, where you'll take in the gorgeous surroundings. Open year-round, see website for hours, menu, or to make a reservation. Located at Yosemite Lodge, Shuttle Stop 8.

images.altText: A sign reading, "Mountain Room Lounge," is located on top of a double-door entrance leading to a lounge made up of glass windows.

bodyText:
In addition to the wonderful Swedish-style fireplace, you'll enjoy the classic furnishings as you sip a cocktail and munch on delicious appetizers. During the warmer months, you can enjoy sitting outside on the patio, where you'll take in the gorgeous surroundings.

See website for hours and menu See website for hours, menu, or to make a reservation.

Hours:
Year-round
See website for hours.

Getting Here:
Located on the Yosemite Valley Lodge premises, shuttle bus stop #8. Here is a map of the Yosemite Valley Lodge area.

Accessibility:
This facility is accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby.
audioDescription:
The Yosemite Valley Lodge complex is made up of three main buildings that are situated in close proximity to each other, and form a triangular shape, around an outdoor courtyard.

The building behind the front desk office, which is connected by a breezeway, is where, from left to right, the Mountain Room Lounge, Cliff Room, and Yosemite Valley Lodge Gift Shop are located.

The Mountain Room Lounge dining area consists of one large room with high ceilings and wood paneled walls. Three out of the four dining room walls are predominantly made of glass panels from floor to ceiling. The wall that is not glass, has a large mirror in the center of it, and wood paneling and shelves of liquor bottles on both sides of the mirror. This bar counter, has several bar stools and extends most of the length of this wall. Flat screen TVs hang from behind the bar and a few around the room. In the middle of the dining room is a large fire place with benches surrounding it. Tables and chairs are randomly situated throughout.

title: Mountain Room Restaurant
listingDescription: At The Mountain Room Restaurant, you will take in astounding views of the nearly 2,500 foot high waterfall. The menu offers perfectly cooked steaks, sustainably caught seafood, and mouthwatering pasta dishes. See website for hours, menu, or to make a reservation. Reservations are taken for 8 or more. Reservations can also be made by calling 209/372-1281 or 209/372-1403. Open year-round. Located at Yosemite Valley Lodge, shuttle stop #8.

images.altText: A building made of wooden beams, posts, and planks has a sign reading, "Mountain Room Restaurant," above its entrance.

bodyText:
At The Mountain Room Restaurant, you will take in astounding views of the nearly 2,500 foot high waterfall. The menu offers perfectly cooked steaks, sustainably caught seafood, and mouthwatering pasta dishes.

See website for hours, menu, or to make a reservation. Reservations are taken for 8 or more. Reservations can also be made by calling 209/372-1281 or 209/372-1403.

Hours:
Year-round
See website for hours.

Getting Here:
Located on the Yosemite Valley Lodge premises, shuttle bus stop #8. Here is a map of the Yosemite Valley Lodge area.

Accessibility:
This facility is accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby.
audioDescription:
The Yosemite Valley Lodge complex is made up of three main buildings that are situated in close proximity to each other, and form a triangular shape, around an outdoor courtyard.

The building to the west of the front desk office, connected by a breezeway, is where, from left to right, the Base Camp Eatery, Starbucks, Garden Terrace, and Mountain Room are located.

The Mountain Room entrance shares an enclosed porch with the Garden Terrace entrance. The porch is made of large timber beams and posts that rise up into a high-pitched roofed. The doors to the Mountain Room are made of heavy wooden panels. A sign to the right of the entrance reads The Mountain Room. The dining area consists of one large room with high ceilings and exposed wooden beams, wood paneled walls covered in photographs that are each emphasized with their own accent lights. The far dining room wall is made up entirely of glass panels from floor to ceiling and allows for views of Yosemite Falls.

title: O'Shaughnessy Dam
listingDescription:
The O'Shaughnessy Dam
Named for the chief engineer, the O'Shaughnessy Dam was completed in 1938. Today, this 117-billion-gallon reservoir supplies pristine drinking water to 2.7 million Bay Area residents and industrial users. It also supplies hydro-electric power generated by two plants downstream. The reservoir is eight miles long and the largest single body of water in Yosemite.

images.altText: A large body of water is seen in the distance behind a wayside exhibit.

bodyText: Named for the chief engineer, the O’Shaughnessy Dam was completed in 1938 and is 430-feet tall. Today the 117-billion-gallon reservoir supplies drinking water to about 2.5 million San Francisco Bay Area residents and industrial users. It also supplies hydro-electric power generated by two plants downstream. The reservoir is eight miles long and the largest single body of water in Yosemite.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourth of six located along this path across the O'Shaughnessy Dam. The view is looking at the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir, a large body of water that is surrounded by granite mountains. A waterfall flows to the left.

Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a colorful photo of snow capped mountains beyond a line of trees. In the foreground water flows toward the viewer.

Caption: The Tuolumne River flows gracefully through Yosemite National Park.

At the top of the panel, the header reads Water Quality at Hetch Hetchy. Text reads: The Tuolumne River supplies 85% of the water for 2.4 million people. It originates from pristine spring snowmelt as far upstream as Mt. Lyell at an elevation of 13,114 feet.

The City and County of San Francisco protects the resources entrusted to its care by continuously monitoring this watershed and working with the park to minimize pollution.

Natural occurrences such as fire and erosion can affect water quality. More than 1,000 water samples are taken annually to protect the water quality of the Hetch Hetchy System.

Photo: A person set up a monitoring station on a riverbank. Two lawn chairs, an open umbrella, large plastic jugs, and other tools are strewn about.

Caption: Water quality specialists take samples from the river in Tuolumne Meadows to test for microorganisms.

Illustration: Clouds produce precipitation, represented by little white tick marks, over snow capped peaks. Blue scraggily lines that look like veins come from the mountains and meet up with a thick blue line, representing a river, which flows through a valley, past forests and towns that are indicated by small triangles.

Caption: A watershed is an ara that is delineated by high ridges such as cliffs, hills, and mountains. Rain or snowmelt flows down from the ridges and collects in streams, rivers, and other water bodies, such as lakes and reservoirs. Watershed protection is a top priority because it affects the quality of water for people downstream and everything that lives within these boundaries.

title: Olmsted Point
listingDescription: Visit the vista famous for its picture postcard views of Half Dome, Tenaya Lake and Clouds Rest. Olmsted Point looks down on Yosemite Valley from the east - and from a very different angle. Though you might not immediately recognize Half Dome, it is one of the most prominent peaks you can see from Olmsted Point. Olmsted Point was named after famed landscape architects, Frederick Law Olmsted (best known for his design of New York's Central Park) and his son Frederick, Jr.

images.altText: A brown and white sign reads, 'Olmsted Point.' Across the street from the sign, five people walk up a domed bedrock.

bodyText:
Visit the vista famous for its picture postcard views of Half Dome, Tenaya Lake and Clouds Rest.

Olmsted Point looks down on Yosemite Valley from the east - and from a very different angle. Though you might not immediately recognize Half Dome, it is one of the most prominent peaks you can see from Olmsted Point.

Olmsted Point was named after famed landscape architects, Frederick Law Olmsted (who was best known for his design of New York's Central Park) and his son, Frederick, Jr.

Hours
Tioga Road is open to vehicles from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here
Located along Tioga Road, a little less than 10 miles (16 km) west of Tuolumne Meadows.

Rules & Regulations
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings
Bears and other wildlife may be present on or near park roads, please drive with caution.
Be aware of potential hazards on park roads, including wet and icy conditions or debris in the roadway, especially in the spring or fall.

Accessibility
There are designated accessible parking spaces available at both ends of the parking lot. There is also a bronze relief tactile model of the surrounding landscape.
audioDescription: A view to the left of the large, slightly arched, one-row, parking area shows a ridge line that peaks at Cloud's Rest and continues down to an oddly shaped dome, which is the backside of Half Dome. To the right of and behind the parking area are smooth granite domes that have large boulders randomly scattered across its surface and trees growing out of the cracks of the granite. Near the center of the parking row, is an exhibit area that has three wayside exhibits and a bronze tactile model of the surrounding landscape. The background picture of the first wayside exhibit shows a perspective from a smooth granite dome with large boulders randomly scattered about, allowing views of Cloud's Rest and the backside of Half Dome, and is titled Olmsted Point. A black and white photo of the side profile of an older man with white hair and a white beard and mustache, looking to the left, is in the bottom right corner. The photo is captioned Frederick Law Olmsted, Sr. A subtitle reads, A family legacy. Text below reads, This turnout was named in honor of famed landscape architect, Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), and his son, Frederick, Jr., when Tioga Road opened to automobile traffic in 1961. Olmsted senior was considered the father of American landscape architecture and best known for his design of New York's Central Park. He was chairman of the first commission to manage Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Grove and wrote a report recommending policy for the care and protection of Yosemite's scenery and wildlife. It is considered a classic national park treatise. Black and white photo: A man with short hair and glasses, wearing a heavy coat and a tie, sits at a table with a pen in his right hand, drawing on a map. Photo caption: Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr. Text to the right of the picture reads, Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr. (1870-1957) also worked in the field of landscape architecture. He collaborated with the National Park Service and was a member of the Yosemite Advisory Board, a group of experts who helped park managers solve problems. He maintained a lifelong commitment to conversation, contributing the guiding language in legislation establishing the National Park Service in 1916. A second exhibit panel titled, Forces of Change, shows a black and white, faded, background photo of a large peak labeled Cloud's Rest and a dome with a smaller dome attached to it, labeled Half Dome. In the forefront, a large boulder rests on a smooth granite surface. Text on the left side of the panel reads, panoramic view. Half Dome stands before you. With a pair of binoculars, you can often see a line of hikers, like ants, climbing up cables to the summit. To the left is the massive northwest face of Cloud's Rest. From its summit (9,926 feet elevation) the sheer granite face, one of the largest in the world, drops nearly 5,000 feet to lower Tenaya Creek. A brief walk to the east side of the parking area will lead to spectacular views of Tenaya Lake, and Mount Conness. Powerful geological forces shaped this landscape. Evidence emerges throughout this granite scene. Chambers of magma deep within the earth slowly crystallized 100-80 million years ago to form hard granite rock. Over time, erosion by rivers and extensive glaciers exposed and sculpted the rock. Black and white photo: Two large boulders sit on a smooth granite surface, that has cracks criss-crossing each other. A man walks on the granite surface, and is a small figure in comparison to the the two large boulders. Caption: These large boulders randomly placed on the bedrock are evidence of the most recent glaciation. The rocks either toppled down slopes onto the glacier or were plucked from the bedrock. They landed here as the ice melted away. Black and white photo: Portions of a smooth granite bedrock seems buffed and shiny as the sun shines on it.Caption: Glacial Polish - Over the last million years, major glaciers have come and gone in Yosemite. Only 20 thousand years ago the most recent glacier extended from the high peaks to the distant horizon. Like rough sandpaper smoothing wood, these glaciers polished the rock you see near here. A third wayside exhibit panel titled Experience Yosemite has a faded background picture of trees and mountains that surround a lake. The lake is labeled Tenaya Lake. Text on the left side of the panel reads, Look and listen - Within this vast granite setting are the sounds of Yosemite's year-round residents. Listen for the occasional alarm whistle of the yellow-bellied marmot, the raucous calls of the Stellar's Jay or Clark's Nutcracker, or maybe the distant rhythmic booming of the male blue grouse trying to attract a mate. Stay long enough and a golden eagle may circle above. Growing twisted and gnarled out of cracks in rocks, Sierra junipers have red, ribbon-like bark and overlapping scales for leaves. Their blue, berry-like cones have a pungent gin-like smell. Juniper berries do not readily germinate unless they pass through the digest

title: Ostrander Lake Trailhead
listingDescription: Retreat to nature and encounter the beauty and radiance of this glimmering lake.The first half of this hike gently inclines through forest and meadow where you can observe severe scars and regrowth from a 1987 lodgepole pine forest fire. A steep 1,500 foot (450 m) elevation gain opens up to views of granite domes, Mt. Starr King, and the Clark Range just prior to arriving at Ostrander Lake.

images.altText: Lake with granite peaks around it.
images.title: Ostrander Lake
images.caption: Ostrander Lake

bodyText:
Retreat to nature and encounter the beauty and radiance of this glimmering lake.

The first half of this hike gently inclines through forest and meadow where you can observe severe scars and regrowth from a 1987 lodgepole pine forest fire. A steep 1,500 foot (450 m) elevation gain opens up to views of granite domes, Mt. Starr King, and the Clark Range just prior to arriving at Ostrander Lake.

Ostrander Lake (strenuous)

  • 11.4 miles (20 km) round-trip; 8-10 hours,

  • 1,500 ft (450 m) elevation gain

Hours

The trail is only accessible when the Glacier Point Road is open, approximately late May through October or November.

When Badger Pass Ski Area is open (mid to late December through March), the Glacier Point Road is groomed for cross-country skiing beyond the ski area. See website for more information.

Getting Here

Begin at Ostrander Lake Trailhead, located along the Glacier Point Road.

Rules & Regulations

The Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call: 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat stream or spring water.

  • Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.

  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility

This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
The Ostrander Lake Trailhead is found on the south side of a dirt parking lot. The parking area is surrounded by forest, with Glacier Point Road to the north. Two trash bins and two recycle bins, along with a row of food lockers line the outskirts of the parking lot, to the left of the trailhead. A small brown structure serves as a vault toilet near the main road. At the trailhead, the dirt path leads through a forest of tall trees. Two signs are posted next to the path. The first sign is a metal sign that reads, Ostrander Lake 6.2 miles, Deer Camp 6.7 miles, Buck Camp 14.1 miles, Wawona 14.6 miles, Chiquita Pass 18.9 miles, and Fernandez Pass 22.8 miles.

The second sign is brown and reads, Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible.
Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red line diagonally slashed across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle.

title: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads
listingDescription: Some of Yosemite's most iconic natural features can be seen and experienced along these trails. Panorama Trail: This longer route to Yosemite Valley brings hikers past Illilouette, Nevada, and Vernal Falls. Combining this trail with the Four Mile Trail will make for a long, strenuous loop! Pohono Trail: This trail rewards hikers with several viewpoints of Yosemite Valley from the south rim. East to west, these views include Taft Point, Dewey Point, Crocker Point, and others.

images.altText: Wooden and metal signs at the trailhead
images.title: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads
images.caption: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads

bodyText:
Panorama Trail (strenuous)

This longer route to Yosemite Valley brings hikers past Illilouette, Nevada, and Vernal Falls. Combining this trail with the Four Mile Trail will make for a long, even more strenuous loop! Some of Yosemite's most iconic natural features can be seen and experienced along this trail.

8 miles (12.8 km) one-way; 6 hours,
3,200 ft (975 m) elevation descent

When the Glacier Point Tour is operating, the Panorama Trail can be hiked one-way during the summer by purchasing a one-way bus ticket between Yosemite Valley and Glacier Point. RESERVATIONS ARE REQUIRED. Do not start this hike without making prior arrangements. Visit any tour and activity desk for details. Tour not operating in 2023.

Pohono Trail (strenuous)

This trail rewards hikers with several viewpoints of Yosemite Valley from the south rim. East to west, these views include Taft Point, Dewey Point, Crocker Point, and Stanford Point. An optional 0.5 mile (0.8 km) side trail gains the summit of Sentinel Dome.

13.8 miles (22.2 km) one-way; 8-10 hours,
2,800 ft (975 m) elevation descent

Hours

This trailhead is only accessible from Glacier Point when the Glacier Point Road is open, approximately late May through October or November.

Getting Here

This trailhead is located at the Glacier Point parking area. From Yosemite Valley or Wawona, take the Wawona Road (Highway 41), then turn east onto Glacier Point Road.

Rules & Regulations

  • Stay on established trails
  • Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
  • Pack out what you pack in
  • The Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat stream or spring water.
  • Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility

These trails are not accessible.
audioDescription: The Panorama and Pohono Trailheads begin in a rocky area, near the Glacier Point Amphitheater. A wooden post holds four signs at the trailhead. The top sign is an orange and black metal sign that reads: No shuttle service between Yosemite Valley and Glacier Point. The second sign is a wooden sign that has the following text carved out of it: Trailhead, Panorama Trail. Illilouette Fall - 2 miles, Nevada Fall - 5.2 miles, Vernal Fall - 7 miles, and Yosemite Valley - 8 miles. Pohono Trail, Sentinel Dome - 1.5 miles, Taft Point - 3.8 miles, and Wawona Tunnel - 13.8 miles. The third sign is a brown metal sign that reads: Entering Yosemite Wilderness. Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least 6 inches deep 100 feet away from water. Bury or pack out toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate squares with a red slash line diagonally slashed across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle. The last sign reads: Hiking Half Dome? Don't forget your permit. Half Dome permit required 7 days a week.

title: Parsons Memorial Lodge
listingDescription: The Sierra Club built this lodge in memory of Edward Taylor Parsons, an early guide for the Sierra Club. Enjoy exhibits inside and see if there are any interpretive programs going on, summer only, by checking out the Yosemite Guide https://www.nps.gov/yose/planyourvisit/guide.htm

images.altText: A stone building with a wooden roof stands on a small hilltop.

bodyText: The Sierra Club built this lodge in memory of Edward Taylor Parsons, an early guide for the Sierra Club. Enjoy exhibits inside and see if there are any interpretive programs going on, summer only, by checking out the Yosemite Guide https://www.nps.gov/yose/planyourvisit/guide.htm
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the thirteenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. On top of a small hilltop is a cobblestoned structure. The building is mostly made of stacked granite stones. Vertical logs that make up the slightly pitched roof, overhang a few feet on the front side of the building. Five large structural log posts that make up the framework of the building, jut out the sides. An arched doorway with a wooden, arched door is in the center of the front, and one window is on each side of the door. A wooden bench is placed on both sides of the doorway. Large boulders scatter the area. A bronze plaque is affixed to one of the boulders near the building's entrance, which reads, Parsons Memorial Lodge has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America. 1987, National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior. The nearby wayside exhibit is titled, Parsons Memorial Lodge, and has a black and white photo on the left, two-thirds of the panel. The photo shows a line of over fifty people, most with walking sticks, hiking up a smooth, snowy, slope, in a wavy, snake-like pattern.

Caption: An early Sierra Club outing.

Panel text reads, as a guide for the early Sierra Club, Edward Taylor Parsons (1861-1914) led hundreds of people on unforgettable high mountain adventures. He also campaigned with John Muir, without success, to keep Yosemite National Park's Hetch Hetchy Valley undammed.

In 1915, the Sierra Club built this lodge in Parsons'memory. Orignally a meeting place and reading room. Parsons Lodge continues to be a refuge from afternoon thunderstorms, as well as a center for exhibits and special programs.

Photo: A middle-aged man with a full mustache and a top hat, wears a thick suit jacket over a white shirt with gloves that cover his sleeves, and knee-high boots that cover his long pants.

Caption: Edward Taylor Parsons

title: Poopenaut Valley Trailhead
listingDescription: Enjoy the wildflowers in spring as you hike down to the Tuolumne River in Poopenaut Valley. Poopenaut Valley (strenuous)2.5 miles (4 km) round-trip; 3 to 4 hours1,229 feet (375 m) elevation gainVisit the Hetch Hetchy Entrance to get more information about hikes in this area. Hours :Year-round, however, winter weather conditions may cause road closures. Call 209-372-0200 for the latest road and weather conditions,Hetch Hetchy Road Daily Hours:8am to 7pm, (April 1 to April 3

images.altText: A brown and white road-side sign reads Poopenaut Valley and has an hiker icon. Trees and a steep valley can be seen in the distance.

bodyText:
Enjoy the wildflowers in spring as you hike down to the Tuolumne River in Poopenaut Valley.

Poopenaut Valley (strenuous)
2.5 miles (4 km) round-trip; 3 to 4 hours
1,229 feet (375 m) elevation gain

Visit the Hetch Hetchy Entrance to get more information about hikes in this area.

Hours:
Year-round, however, winter weather conditions may cause road closures. Call 209-372-0200 for the latest road and weather conditions. The road is currently open only from 8 am to 5 pm.

There is no access to Hetch Hetchy trailheads by car when road is closed.

Getting Here:
Begin at a signed trailhead along the Hetch Hetchy road, four miles past the Hetch Hetchy Entrance Station. The Hetch Hetchy Road begins just outside the park on Highway 120, near the Big Oak Flat Entrance.

Rules & Regulations:
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in.
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Hetch Hetchy Entrance until 5pm, at no cost.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.

Hazards & Warnings:
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Carry sunscreen and watch for rattlesnakes and poison oak.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility:
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: A brown sign with an icon of a hiker, located on the left side of the Hetch Hetchy Road, four miles past the entrance station, marks the trail. A small roadside turnout is located on the right side of the road and has a food locker and very limited parking. It is noticable how steep the decent is from the trailhead. Hetch Hetchy Reservoir can be seen in the distance.

title: Porcupine Creek Trailhead
listingDescription:
A day hike to North Dome will reward you with exceptional views of the dome of all domes, Half Dome, and the landscape that makes up Yosemite Valley and beyond.

Wind through mixed-conifer forest for 0.7 miles (1 km) on a paved path, and cross Porcupine Creek. At each of several trail junctions, follow the signs toward North Dome. The trail passes through a small grassy meadow and descends along a ridge. Near the end of the hike, descend steep rock steps to the base of North Dome. Climb the dome's rounded summit to take in a magnificent view of Half Dome and Yosemite Valley. On the return trip you can take a short detour on a side trail, 0.3 mile (0.5 km) to an unusual natural arch, Indian Rock.



North Dome (strenuous)
10.4 mi (16.7 km) round-trip.; 5-8 hours
580 ft (180 m) elevation gain

Other hiking destinations accessible from this trailhead include the top of Yosemite Falls and Yosemite Valley via the Snow Creek Trail or the Yosemite Falls Trail.

For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.

Hours :
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here :
Begin at the Porcupine Creek Trailhead, along Tioga Road, 1.2 miles (1.9 km) east of Porcupine Flat Campground

Rules & Regulations :
- Stay on established trails
- Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
- Pack out what you pack in
- Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
- Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
- Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
- Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15.For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings :
- Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
- Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
- Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility :
This trail is not accessible.

images.altText: A brown and white roadside sign reads, "Porcupine Creek," and has an icon of a hiker and an arrow pointing left.
