audioDescription:
The Porcupine Creek Trailhead paved parking area is on the west side of Tioga Road and has two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, and a brown restroom facility near the center of the parking row. The trailhead is on the south side of the parking lot and is marked by a big wooden sign with white text.

Text that has been carved out of the wooden sign reads, Porcupine Creek Trailhead, North Dome 4.4 miles, Yosemite Falls 6.9 miles, Yosemite Valley (Mirror Lake) 8 miles, and Yosemite Valley 9.5 miles. A dirt path descends into the forest. Granite boulders are scattered about.

title: Pothole Dome Meadow
listingDescription: Gain magnificent views of Tuolumne Meadows' most iconic peaks, domes, and meadows. Pothole Dome Meadow showcases Tuolumne Meadow's most notable natural features. A trail along the western edge of the meadow curves around to the east side of Pothole Dome, an approachable hiking route that accesses the top of the dome along with its unobstructed, exciting panoramic views.

images.altText: Several people stand on top of a granite dome which gives views of a large, open meadow surrounded by pine trees. Granite peaks rise above the treeline.

bodyText:
Gain magnificent views of Tuolumne Meadows' most iconic peaks, domes, and meadows.

Pothole Dome Meadow showcases Tuolumne Meadow's most notable natural features. A trail along the western edge of the meadow curves around to the east side of Pothole Dome, an approachable hiking route that accesses the top of the dome along with its unobstructed, exciting panoramic views.

Hours 
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here 
Located along Tioga Road, a mile west of the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center.

Rules & Regulations 
Pets, bicycles, and strollers are not permitted on dirt trails.
Stay on the designated trail. Do not venture out into the meadow, which causes trampling and damages the ecosystem, which is important to the many plants and animals that thrive in this fragile environment.

Accessibility 
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: A roadside turnout with limited parking on the north side of Tioga Road hosts views of a large open meadow and surrounding peaks and domes. A trail to the west of the parking area leads around the outskirts of the meadow, to Pothole Dome, a smooth granite dome that would allow for a slightly higher panoramic view. In the distance, a forest lines the perimeter of the meadow and pointed peaks rise above the tree line. Several signs are posted at the parking area and the start of the path. The first sign in the parking area is a brown sign, outlined in white, and has white text that reads, no camping or overnight parking.The second sign is a small, white, metal sign on a wooden post located on the meadow side of long, large, logs used as barriers to separate the dirt parking from the meadow. A photo on the upper right side of the sign shows several bright, tall, wildflowers in a lush green meadow with a snow covered peak rising above the pine treeline in the distance. The sign reads, meadow restoration in progress. Trails that pass through sensitive habitats, such as Tuolumne Meadows, can have an impact that reaches far beyond the trail. We are currently working to restore this area. Please stay on the main trail shown in blue on the map. Please stay on designated trail.Photo: Two people walk off-trail through a large meadow. In the distance, mountain peaks rise above a dense forest. Map: In a square frame, the Tioga Road is indicated by a blue and white tick line that leads from the upper left corner to the bottom right corner. Above that line, sandwiched between the road and a large white area that indicates the granite of Pothole dome is a meadow, a wetland area represented by an upward-turned, banana shape filled with blue marks. A yellow star and text that reads, "you are here," along with an icon of a hiker inside a red square, which is a trailhead, are along the Tioga Road, one quarter of the way from the top. A blue solid line, which is the Pothole Dome Trail, makes its way around the left side of the banana-shaped wetland area then leads to the right, all the way to the right side of the frame. A red, solid line cuts through the meadow from Tioga Road to Pothole Dome and forks out into two paths, they are marked closed.A wayside exhibit titled Sub-Alpine Zone, is located on the parking side of long, large, logs used as barriers to separate the meadow from the dirt parking area. Text on the left side of the panel reads, the plants and animals in this zone sometimes have only two and a half months to complete a year's work. At this elevation, the snow can be on the ground well into June, only to return as early as September. Bevause this sub-alpine meadow ecosystem is so fragile, even one person crossing it can cause serious damage - especially if it is wet. By following the trail to your left on your hike to Pothole Dome, you can protect plants and animals during their active season.Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of both labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. At the start of the Pothole Dome Trail, a brown sign outlined in white has white text that reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across t

title: Ranger Patrol Cabin
listingDescription: In 1914, the U.S. Cavalry left Yosemite. The management of this huge park fell to a small group of 15 men who had served as cavalry scouts. Their duties were made more difficult by the fact that automobiles had been allowed to enter the park in August 1913. Buildings such as this were used as automobile check stations. Here drivers paid a $5 fee to enter the park and were informed of regulations.

images.altText: Wooden cabin
images.title: Ranger Patrol Cabin
images.caption: Ranger Patrol Cabin

bodyText:
After twenty-three years protecting the park, the U.S. Army was called away from Yosemite in 1914, and civilians began to assume ranger roles. It was the job of these rangers to protect the natural resources, stop forest fires, and assist visitors. Their duties were made more difficult as automobiles had recently been allowed to enter the park.

The ranger patrol cabin was built in 1915 to house rangers at Crane Flat, a busy road junction. Buildings such as this were used as automobile check stations. Here drivers paid a fee to enter the park and were informed of regulations. Along sections of the Big Oak Flat and Wawona roads, automobiles were only permitted to go east, downgrade, on odd hours and west, upgrade, on even hours. At Crane Flat and others Yosemite locations, rangers needed to live close to backcountry patrol routes and roadside stations where they assisted visitors arriving by automobile. In 1916 the National Park Service was created and the rangers living here became some of the first National Park Service Rangers.

Gabriel Sovulewski, a Polish immigrant, embodied the administrative transition from the military to the National Park Service in Yosemite. He first saw Yosemite in 1895 while on a summer deployment to the park with the U.S. Army. In 1902, he left the Army and returned to Yosemite to work as a packer and guide. In 1906, Gabriel was placed in charge of Yosemite National Park, serving as the top park official for thirty years. During that time he directed the construction of trails and buildings such as the Ranger Patrol Cabin. Gabriel Sovulewski remained in Yosemite for the rest of his life, and is buried next to his wife, Rose in the Yosemite Cemetery.
audioDescription:
This long log cabin has a brown wooden door just right of center. There are two windows on the left side of the door and one window on the right. There is a stone chimney on the left side of the structure, and a wooden stump stool in the front. An exhibit sign reads:

Ranger Patrol Cabin
In 1905, California ceded Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias for inclusion in Yosemite National Park. The ceded land was accepted by the federal government in 1906, adding 31,104 acres to the Park. Thus, after 16 years, the Valley and Grove became part of Yosemite National Park.

In 1913, the army stopped coming to the Yosemite, but the National Park Service had not as yet been established. In the intervening three years, fifteen civilian rangers, most of whom were formerly army scouts, were hired to protect the Park and its visitors - a big change from 150 cavalry men the previous year.

They were provided with three patrol cabins. This one, built at Crane Flat, incurred the following costs: Materials were $250.98 and Labor equalled $685.36...a wise use of your tax dollar in the early 1900's. These civilian rangers were absorbed into the fledgling National Park Service, created in 1916 to administer or unique national preserves.

title: Rangers' Club Architecture

images.altText: A two-story, U-shaped building with a steeply pitched roof, dormers, and a central courtyard
images.title: Rangers' Club
images.caption: Rangers' Club

bodyText:
The Rangers' Club was the first structure build in the National Park Service Rustic architecture style. Stephen T. Mather, the first director of the National Park Service, employed park rangers to guide tourists and protect the park from poachers. In 1920, Mather hired architect Charles Sumner to construct a home for members of his newly organized ranger force, paying $39,380 for the building out of his own pocket. It was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1985 for significance in the development of the Rustic style and is still in use today as a home for seasonal rangers.

Sumner designed a large, modified chalet with wood shingles and steeply pitched roofs. Instead of leaving simple corners, every edge of the building is defined with heavy log pilasters, strengthening the connection between the building and surrounding forest edges. The steep roofs shed the winter snows and emphasized the structure's verticality—an homage to the surrounding mountains.

Rangers’ Club is a private residence, do not approach the building or disturb the residents.
audioDescription: The Rangers’ Club is a somewhat large two-story, U-shaped building with many ornate details. The first story of the building is covered in wood shingles painted a dark, muted shade of red. The upper story features wood paneling painted the same color, with ornate details at the lower terminus of each wood panel. The grey roof shingles are very clearly visible on the second story of the building, as the building has an extremely steeply pitched roof. Dormer windows feature throughout the outer faces of the building. All the windows are vertically oriented, multi-paned, and the frames are painted a contrasting light tan. Both wings of the building have an exterior wooden staircase leading up to a second-story door on the ends of the wings. The central courtyard surrounds a large mature dogwood. There is a tall stone chimney at the center of the building just behind the dogwood.

title: Reservaciones de Vehículos
listingDescription: En 2021, el funcionamiento del parque seguirá viéndose afectado por la pandemia de la COVID-19. Desde el 21 de mayo hasta el 30 de septiembre de 2021, será necesario contar con una reservación para ingresar a Yosemite con un vehículo. El permiso deberá estar a la vista sobre el tablero del auto en todo momento durante su visita al parque.

images.altText: Graphic showing dates reservations are required in 2024
images.title: Reservaciones para el ingreso al parque
images.caption: Reservaciones para el ingreso al parque en 2024

bodyText:
Reservaciones para el ingreso al parque en 2024

Será necesario contar con una reservación para ingresar a Yosemite con un vehículo desde la primavera hasta el otoño de 2024.

  • Del 26 de febrero al 12 de abril: No será necesario contar con una reservación para ingresar con un vehículo a Yosemite.
  • Del 13 de abril al 30 de junio: Será necesario contar con una reservación de 5 a. m. a 4 p. m. los sábados, domingos y feriados (del 27 de mayo al 19 de junio).
  • Del 1 de julio al 16 de agosto: Será necesario contar con una reservación de 5 a. m. a 4 p. m. todos los días.
  • Del 17 de agosto al 29 de septiembre: Será necesario contar con una reservación de 5 a. m. a 4 p. m. los sábados, domingos y feriados (del 2 de septiembre al 14 de octubre).

Formas de conseguir una reserva

Reservaciones de hora pico

En su mayoría, las reservaciones, para todas las fechas desde el 13 de abril hasta el 27 de octubre de 2024, estarán disponibles en Recreation.gov el 5 de enero. Las reservaciones adicionales estarán disponibles siete días antes de la fecha de llegada (por ejemplo, debe hacer la reservación el 20 de octubre para llegar el 27 de octubre). Las reservaciones disponibles con una semana de anticipación serán una combinación de reservaciones válidas para días completos o reservaciones válidas para llegada únicamente por la tarde.

Las reservaciones se encontrarán disponibles todos los días a partir de las 8 a. m. (hora del Pacífico). Las reservaciones se toman casi de forma inmediata. Asegúrese de tener una cuenta de Recreation.gov e iniciar sesión para conseguir pronto una reservación a las 8 a. m. (hora del Pacífico).

La reservación tiene un cargo no reembolsable de $2 (esto no incluye el precio de la entrada al parque de $35 por auto).

Cada usuario puede realizar una sola reservación por cada período de tres días. Por ejemplo, si un usuario realiza una reservación para llegar un viernes (válida de viernes a domingo), no podrá realizar una segunda reservación para llegar ese viernes, sábado o domingo. El titular de la reservación debe estar en el vehículo y mostrar una identificación con fotografía en la estación de entrada.
Las reservaciones de hora pico serán válidas durante tres días consecutivos (incluida la fecha de llegada).

Si no tiene acceso a una computadora, puede llamar al 877/444-6777 para realizar una reservación.

Campamento, alojamiento o alquiler vacacional en el parque

Si cuenta con una reservación para alguna de las siguientes opciones, no necesita una reservación adicional. Al llegar, tendrá que abonar la entrada de $35 por auto (pago únicamente con tarjeta de crédito), a menos que cuente con un pase anual o vitalicio. Su reservación para alojarse o acampar dentro del parque, para un permiso Half Dome o para un permiso de naturaleza (wilderness permit) le permite ingresar al parque las 24 horas del día mientras dure su reservación o durante tres días consecutivos (lo que dure más).

  • Una zona de acampada en el Parque Nacional Yosemite

  • Curry Village, Housekeeping Camp, Yosemite Valley Lodge, Hotel Ahwahnee, Hotel Wawona, White Wolf Lodge y Tuolumne Meadows Lodge

  • Alojamiento privado o alquiler vacacional en Wawona, Yosemite West o Foresta

  • Permiso de naturaleza (wilderness permit) en Yosemite

Las reservaciones para alojamientos o alquileres vacacionales que se encuentren fuera del parque y en comunidades distintas a las tres mencionadas no cuentan con acceso a Yosemite.

Permisos de naturaleza (wilderness permit) o Half Dome

Si cuenta con una reservación para un permiso de naturaleza (para mochileros) o un permiso Half Dome, no necesita tener una reservación adicional. Al llegar, tendrá que abonar la entrada de $35 por vehículo (pago únicamente con tarjeta de crédito), a menos que cuente con un pase anual o vitalicio. Su reservación le permite ingresar al parque las 24 horas del día mientras dure su reservación o durante tres días consecutivos (lo que dure más).

Si cuenta con un permiso de naturaleza (wilderness permit), podrá ingresar al parque un día antes de la fecha que figura en su permiso de naturaleza para alojarse en una zona de acampada para mochileros.

El permiso Half Dome no sirve como permiso para acampar en Yosemite.

Tránsito regional o Visitas grupales

Si ingresa al parque en un autobús del Sistema de transporte regional del área de Yosemite (YARTS) o con una visita grupal autorizada, no necesita tener una reservación o permiso adicional.

Visita sin reservación

Si no tiene una reservación, puede visitar Yosemite de todos modos. Debe llegar a una estación de ingreso (que no sea Hetch Hetchy) antes de las 5 a. m. o después de las 4 p. m. Si tiene previsto realizar una visita después de las horas pico, le pedimos que no llegue antes de las 4 p. m. Se citará a los vehículos que bloqueen carreteras.

Si ingresa en horas no pico en su primer día, de todos modos, debe ingresar antes de las 5 a. m. o después de las 4 p. m. en los días posteriores, incluso si tiene un recibo de la estación de ingreso.

Puede visitar el área de Hetch Hetchy del parque cuando esté abierta (del amanecer hasta el atardecer) sin una reservación.

Previsión a futuro

Yosemite lleva décadas lidiando con problemas de tráfico, incluyendo embotellamientos. Queremos aprovechar lo aprendido en los últimos tres veranos, en los que se ha controlado el acceso.Estamos desarrollando el plan de gestión de acceso de visitantes para contar con un enfoque que brinde una experiencia increíble a los visitantes y al mismo tiempo proteja los recursos naturales y culturales de Yosemite.
audioDescription: This is not a true site to visit. The information in this site is used to convey information about entrance reservations.

title: Sentinel Beach Picnic Area
listingDescription: Savor the moment while standing amidst the magnificent landscape before you, a landscape showcasing views of Sentinel Rock and surrounding cliff faces. Picnic tables and grills are conveniently located at this scenic spot along the Merced River that offers views of Sentinel Rock and surrounding cliff faces. Hours :This picnic area is available from dawn to dusk. Getting Here :Sentinel Beach Picnic Area, is located on Southside Drive, several miles east of Bridalveil Fall. R

images.altText: A brown and white roadside sign reads, "Sentinel Beach, Yellow Pine," and has an arrow pointing left and an icon of a picnic table.

bodyText:
Savor the moment while standing amidst the magnificent landscape before you, a landscape showcasing views of Sentinel Rock and surrounding cliff faces.

Picnic tables and grills are conveniently located at this scenic spot along the Merced River that offers views of Sentinel Rock and surrounding cliff faces.

Hours:
This picnic area is available from dawn to dusk.

Getting Here:
Sentinel Beach Picnic Area, is located on Southside Drive, several miles east of Bridalveil Fall.

Rules & Regulations:
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings:
For your safety and that of wildlife:
Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.
Yosemite's water can be deceptively dangerous and unforgiving. Visitors are strongly urged to enjoy swift-moving or high water from a safe distance, especially in the spring.

Accessibility:
The Sentinel Beach Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible vault toilets, and grills. Parking is nearby.
audioDescription: The Sentinel Beach Picnic Area is on a dirt road that is located on the left side of Southside Drive, the eastbound, one-way road leading into Yosemite Valley. The dirt road almost immediately splits into two roads. The road to the right leads into a dense forest that has cleared areas that have picnic tables and permanent standing grills. There are no designated parking spots. The dirt road loops around, passing vault toilets and trash and recycle bins along the way, before meeting up with the main road again. In the picnic area, an obvious path leads out of the forest and onto an open sandy and pebbled beach, along the Merced River. The massive granite walls rise above the trees that line the riverbanks.

title: Sentinel Bridge
listingDescription: Sentinel Bridge provides breathtaking views of Half Dome directly, or of its reflection in the waters of the Merced River, especially during the alpenglow.Sentinel Bridge is located in the footprint of where the old Yosemite Village once stood. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :located on the eastern side of Yosemite Valley, on Sentinel Drive, near Cook's Meadow, and can be accessed at shuttle stop 11. Accessibility :Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby. The

images.altText: Three people stand on a bridge looking at Half Dome.

bodyText:
Sentinel Bridge provides a breathtaking view of Half Dome and its mirrored reflection in the Merced River, especially during the alpenglow.

Sentinel Bridge is located in the footprint of where the old Yosemite Village once stood.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
located on the eastern side of Yosemite Valley, on Sentinel Drive, near Cook's Meadow, and can be accessed at shuttle stop 11.

Accessibility:
Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby. There is a pedestrian path that leads from the bus stop and parking area, across the street, to a paved sidewalk leading onto the bridge.
audioDescription: Sentinel Bridge is a great place to experience Half Dome. Many photographers enjoy gathering here to take pictures of Half Dome and its reflection in the Merced River, especially when the colors of sunset play on its rock face. The bridge is completely made of stone and is slightly arched. Wayside exhibits are affixed to the metal railing that is adhered to the rock barrier-walls on each side of the bridge. On the east side of the bridge, tall trees line the banks of the river and Half Dome rises over the tree line. The wayside exhibit is titled, The Story of Half Dome, and has a orange-toned, faint, background photo of textured granite rock. Text reads, millions of years ago the granite block of Half Dome was larger, but there never was a matching half. Undercut by glaciers near the base, slabs of rock fell away from a broad vertical crack in the granite, leaving a sheer face. Remnants of the missing rock still project from Half Dome's rim. There are more granite domes here than in any other place in the world. Massive granite domes from when large curved layers of rock "exfoliate" or slab off. Illustrated brochure: A side profile of Half Dome, with dark shadows in the front and low laying clouds floating below its face. In the background, some grey peaks cross the skyline and the sky is a bright orange and yellow. The text reads Yosemite Valley, on top, and Southern Pacific, on bottom.Caption: c. 1910Black and white postcard: Half Dome and trees surrounding it have an almost symmetrical reflection in the Merced River. Caption: Half Dome from Sentinel Bridge, postcard, c. 1940. Since the mid-19th century, countless images of the park's most famous dome, Half Dome, have been circulated. Its profile has become an enduring and instantly recognizable symbol of Yosemite. A section on the left side of the panel has a header that reads, An Ahwahneechee Tale of Half Dome. Text below it reads, long ago, two travelers, Tissiak and her husband, Tokoyee, fought with each other. He became so angry that he began to beat her; enraged, she hurled her basket of acorns at him. As they stood facing each other, they were turned to stone for their wickedness. The acorn basket (Basket Dome) lies upturned beside Tokoyee (North Dome) and the rock face of Tissiak (Half Dome) is stained with her tears. Photo: Half Dome is illuminated with the orange light of the alpen glow. Behind Half Dome, other mountains a lit as well, and the sky is full of dark clouds. Across the street, on the opposite side of the bridge, another wayside exhibit is affixed to the bridge barrier-wall. The wayside exhibit is titled, River of Mercy, and has a orange-toned, very faint, background photo of an old map of Yosemite Valley. Text reads, early Spanish explorers named the Merced River for Our Lady of Mercy. In Yosemite Valley, later settlers saw the Merced and its tributaries as troublesome as well as merciful. They channeled the wild river, dynamited the glacial moraine at the Valley entrance to lower the water table, and diverted water to quench the thirst of livestock and to power a sawmill. Black and white photo: The banks of a river have receded, and about three feet of roots of two tree stumps are exposed. The river flows nearby.Caption: Overuse damages the riverbanks and riparian life. Black and white photo: A woman in white, water-resistant pants with suspenders, a white t-shirt, boots, and a ponytail inserts a pole into the muddy ground on the banks of a river. Another woman with a t-shirt and gloves, bends down on her knees, and inserts a pole in the ground in the same spot. The river flows nearby. Caption: Volunteers assist park resource managers in revegetating riverbanks.Human alterations have harmed the riparian (river-related) habitat. Introduced fish species gradually outnumbered the native rainbow trout. Human feet have trampled the riverbanks and destroyed streamside plants. Restoration efforts such as replanting, fencing, and elimination of fish stocking are returning the river to a more natural state. A section on the left side of the panel has a header that reads, A Wild and Scenic River. Text below it reads, the Merced River watershed begins in the southeastern portion of the park, primarily in the high country of the Clark and Cathedral Ranges. The river plunges over Nevada and Vernal Falls, then meanders across the flat Yosemite Valley floor. Leaving Yosemite Valley, it winds down the Merced Canyon into the San Joaquin Valley far below. In 1987, recognizing the Merced's pristine beauty, Congress designated its upper reaches in and below the park as a National Wild and Scenic River. Black and white Photo 1: A mountain landscape with sloping hills and pine trees is covered in snow. Snowcapped peaks are in the distant background.Caption: The Merced's pristine waters originate in the melting snows of Yosemite's high country.Black and white Photo 2: A mountain lake glistens and is framed by tree branches. Large granite rock formation

title: Sentinel Bridge Parking Area
listingDescription: Delight in a leisurely stroll onto Sentinel Bridge and gain an astounding view of Half Dome, especially in the evening when the reddish-orange alpenglow is brought on by the setting sun. Views of the Merced River, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls through Cook's Meadow, are just a few of the benefits of parking here.

images.altText: A line of cars are parked in a parking lot next to an open meadow that showcases a view of a tall waterfall.

bodyText:
Delight in a leisurely stroll onto Sentinel Bridge and gain an astounding view of Half Dome, especially during the alpenglow, when a reddish-orange glow is brought on by the setting sun.

Views of the Merced River, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls through Cook's Meadow, are just a few of the benefits of parking here.

Half Dome
The profile of Half Dome has become a recognizable symbol of Yosemite. Millions of years ago, the granite block of Half Dome was larger, but there was never a matching other half. Passing glaciers undercut the base, and slabs of rock fell away, leaving a sheer face.

Merced River
The Merced River is a National Wild and Scenic River. Its waters originate in the melting snow of Yosemite's high country in the southeastern portion of the park. The river plunges over Nevada and Vernal Falls, then meanders across the flat Yosemite Valley. It continues its journey down the Merced River Canyon and spills into the San Joaquin Valley. Early Spanish explorers named the Merced River for Our Lady of Mercy.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
Located on Sentinel Drive, just over the Sentinel Bridge, and before Yosemite Village Day Use Parking.

Rules & Regulations:
Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.
You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility:
There are designated accessible parking spaces available.
audioDescription:
The Sentinel Bridge Parking area is a prime spot to experience Yosemite Falls. The north side of the parking lot is lined with a wooden fence that separates the sidewalk from the large open meadow that shows views of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. Bus stop #11 stands at the southeast side of the parking lot. Four benches, a green recycle bin, brown trash bin, and a small, wood, shelter are all by the bus stop. Further south from the bus stop, a crosswalk leads across the street to the Sentinel Bridge. A few wayside exhibits are located in the parking lot, along the meadow.

The first exhibit panel is titled Ecotones: Life on the Edge, and has a faint background photo of a small patch of meadow, containing long grasses and sedges, surrounded with pine trees. Panel text reads, the zone where two habitats merge is called an ecotone. The meadow/forest ecotone is visible here. The water-saturated meadow gives way to the oaks and towering conifers, which can't survive in flood-prone areas. The greatest diversity of wildlife exists in these transition areas where a variety of food and shelter is present.

The Changing Landscape - By the 1860s, hotel owners were converting meadows to pastures, gardens, orchards, and hay fields. They suppressed fires because they threatened wooden buildings. They also channeled the Merced River to control flooding and drained boggy areas of the Valley.

Black and white photo: Black and white spotted cows graze in an open meadow with towering cliffs surrounding them.

Caption: Yosemite Valley, 1918.

Meadows in Peril - Only a century ago the meadows of Yosemite Valley were far more extensive than they are today. With the right balance of water, fire, and soil conditions, a meadow can survive indefinitely. But with the altercation of the water table and fire cycle in the Valley, the natural balance was lost.

Black and white comparison photo 1: An aerial view of a meadow below the iconic Half Dome shows larges patches of open meadows with trees scattered here and there.

Caption: Yosemite Valley Meadows, 1899

Black and white comparison photo 2: An aerial view of a meadow below the iconic Half Dome shows dense stands of trees with only a few small patches of meadow showing.

Caption: Yosemite Valley Meadows, 1991

Next to the first wayside exhibit, a second one is titled Meltdown, and has a faint background photo of a waterfall coming over a tall, granite rockface. Panel text reads, the high-country snowpack is Yosemite's reservoir. As the snow melts in the spring, torrents of water cascade over Yosemite Falls (on the cliff before you) and over dozens of other waterfalls.

Upstream, shallow soil on granite slopes absorbs very little water, Once the snow is gone, usually by late summer, most of Yosemite's waterfalls quickly dwindle.

Black and white comparison photo 1: A close up view of a wet rock face.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Autumn

Black and white comparison photo 2: A thin stream of water falls over a large granite rock wall. White ice has built up on the rock face on both sides of the thin waterfall. At the bottom of the fall, a pile of snow has built up.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Winter

Black and white comparison photo 3: Two waterfalls are stacked on top of each other. The upper fall is full of water and the lower fall has a slightly more narrow, shorter, stream of water.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Spring

Black and white comparison photo 4: The two waterfalls that are stacked on top of each other have dwindled down to a think, hair-like strand of a waterfall.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Summer

Quote: "You should stop a while...a little below the head of the fall beside the enthusiastic throng of starry, comet-like waters to learn something of their strength, their marvelous variety of forms, and above all their glorious music, gathered and composed from the snow-storms, hail-, and rain- and wind-storms that have fallen on their glacier-sculptered, domey, ridgy basin." - John Muir, The Yosemite, "How Best to Spend One's Yosemite Time"

Lost Arrow - Seasonal changes affect more than just the waterfalls. Water seeping into cracks and fissures in the cliff face freezes and expands in winter, wedging off blocks of stone. This action constantly reshapes Yosemite Valley. Lost Arrow, the isolated granite pinnacle to the right of Yosemite Falls, was once a part of a solid wall of rock.

Black and white photo: A granite spire is shown from above, rising up like a tower.
Caption: Lost Arrow from above

A nearby sign reads, flood water level, 11pm, January 2, 1997. A double-sided arrow points from left to right. The sign itself stands over six feet high.

title: Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Trailhead
listingDescription: Get a 360-degree view of the park at Sentinel Dome and/or hike to an expanse on the south rim of Yosemite Valley, getting a close view of El Capitan and Yosemite Valley, at Taft Point.

images.altText: Brown metal trailhead sign with arrow alongside road
images.title: Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Trailhead
images.caption: Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Trailhead

bodyText:
Sentinel Dome (Moderate)

This wide trail leads mostly across open granite with little shade. Scramble up Sentinel Dome's granite slope to enjoy a breathtaking 360-degree view of the park. Consider taking this hike at sunset or during a full moon, but remember to bring a flashlight with fresh batteries!

1.8 miles (2.9 km) round-trip; 2 hours,
400 ft (125 m) elevation gain

Taft Point (Moderate)

Enjoy magnificent views of Yosemite Valley, including El Capitan and Yosemite Falls. Near Taft Point, you'll see The Fissures-narrow fractures in the granite called joints. Watch out for drops of up to 2,000 feet at these fractures!

2.2 miles (3.5 km) round-trip; 2 hours,
200 ft (60 m) elevation gain

The Sentinel Dome and Taft Point trails can be combined into a loop hike.

Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Loop (moderate)

4.9 miles (7.9 km) loop; 3-4 hours,
1,000 ft (300 m) elevation gain

Hours

  • These trails are only accessible when the Glacier Point Road is open, approximately late May through October or November.
  • When Badger Pass Ski Area is open (mid to late December through March), the Glacier Point Road is groomed for cross-country skiing beyond the ski area.

Getting Here

Located along the Glacier Point Road. From Yosemite Valley or Wawona, take the Wawona Road (Highway 41), then turn east onto Glacier Point Road.

Rules & Regulations

  • Stay on established trails
  • Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
  • Pack out what you pack in
  • The Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat stream or spring water.
  • Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility

These trails are not accessible.
audioDescription: The Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Trailhead begins down a boulder-lined dirt path that leads from the parking lot. The path then comes to an intersection, where it splits to the left and right. A wooden post at the dirt intersection has two signs bolted to it. The top sign is a small wooden sign with the words Taft Point 1.1 miles with an arrow pointing to the left, carved out of it. It also reads, Sentinel Dome 1.1 miles, with an arrow pointing to the right. A faded metal sign below shows the icon of a dog and has a red line slashed diagonally through the icon. The area is sandy with chinquapin bushes around as well as tall pine trees.

title: Soda Springs
listingDescription: Let your senses take over and take in the sight, sound, and smell of Soda Springs, then read the wayside exhibit about drinking the water. Is it drinkable?

images.altText: Bubbles rise up to the surface of a small puddle of water.

bodyText: Let your senses take over and take in the sight, sound, and smell of Soda Springs, then read the wayside exhibit about drinking the water. Is it drinkable?
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the eleventh stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. The meadow transitions into a waterlogged area. Many rocks are scattered about and have turned a rusty color and have a chalky, white, residue around them. A log enclosure that has an open top and an open door, protects the main hub of the springs. Inside the enclosure, air bubbles are constantly working their way to the surface of a small puddle, bubbling up around small rocks. The wayside exhibit is titled, Soda Springs, and has a black and white photo of four men at the springs, on the right, two-thirds of the panel. The man on the far left is on his hands and knees and has his face down to the ground. The next man to the right is facing away from the camera and has a bucket in his left hand and a ladle in his right. The next man to the right is kneeling down on his right knee, with his left knee propped up and his left arm resting on it. He is holding a cup in his right hand, ready to scoop up some water from the spring. The man on the far right stands with his left hand in his pant pocket and his right hand holding a cup, looking down, watching the spring bubble. Trees and peaks are in the distant background.

Caption: Early visitors to Soda Springs, 1872. Jean Baptiste Lembert built the enclosure you see today to protect these springs from grazing animals, c. 1885.

Panel text reads, can I drink the water? For thousands of years animals and people have visited these springs. Deer and birds obtain needed minerals. People enjoy the taste of the spring water.

These small, carbonated mineral springs are a mystery - even geologists cannot explain why they are here. Although the bubbling water comes out of the ground pure and clean, there is a possibility that people or animals have contaminated the water.

title: Soda Springs and Parsons Memorial Lodge Trailhead
listingDescription: Explore the mystery that is Soda Springs and delve into the history of Parsons Lodge on this delightful walk through Tuolumne Meadows. Walk along the gravel road and pass the locked gate (signed Glen Aulin and Soda Springs). Soda Springs-cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground-is protected within a log enclosure. Historic Parsons Memorial Lodge offers exhibits (limited hours-see Yosemite Guide for schedule). A path to the bridge below the lodge continues to the Tuol

images.altText: A stone building that has a wooden roof stands on top of a small hill and is surrounded by trees.

bodyText:
Explore the mystery that is Soda Springs and delve into the history of Parsons Lodge on this delightful walk through Tuolumne Meadows.

Walk along the gravel road and pass the locked gate (signed Glen Aulin and Soda Springs). Soda Springs-cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground-is protected within a log enclosure. Historic Parsons Memorial Lodge offers exhibits (limited hours-see Yosemite Guide for schedule). A path to the bridge below the lodge continues to the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center.

Soda Springs and Parsons Memorial Lodge (easy)
1.5 miles (2.4 km) round-trip; 1 hours
0 ft (0 m) elevation gain

For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.

Hours:
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here:
Begin at Lembert Dome parking area.

Rules & Regulations:
Stay on established trails
Pets, bicycles, or strollers are not allowed on this trails
Pack out what you pack in
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings:
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility:
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: The trailhead to Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge is located along a dirt road that has limited, undefined, roadside parking. Five food storage lockers, a green recycle bin, and a brown trash bin sit on a slab of cement, along the road, near a closed metal gate. A sign on the gate shows two illustrations. The first illustration is an icon of a dog inside a white, square outline, and a red diagonal line slashing through it. The second illustration is an icon of a bicycle inside a white, square outline, and a red diagonal line slashing through it. To the right of the closed gate is a walkway to get to the trail, which also appears to be a dirt road. Next to the walkway is a wooden sign that reads, Soda Springs, Parsons Lodge, and Glen Aulin Trail, which all have a white arrow pointing forward in front of each name. Text continues to read, pets and firearms prohibited. Tall trees line the parking area and the beginning of the trail.

title: Soda Springs, Glen Aulin, Waterwheel Falls Trailhead
listingDescription:
Hike through meadow and forest on this scenic trail that leads you to Glen Aulin and beyond.

Soda Springs
Soda Springs-carbonated, cold water bubbling out of the ground-is protected within a log enclosure. A side path leads to the nearby historic Parsons Memorial Lodge, which offers exhibits in the summer. (limited hours-see Yosemite Guide for schedule).

Glen Aulin
Follow the Tuolumne River as it drops to Glen Aulin. Tuolumne Fall and White Cascade are four miles from the trailhead. Beyond Glen Aulin are California Fall (13 miles roundtrip), LeConte Fall (15 miles roundtrip), and Waterwheel Falls (18 miles roundtrip). The return hike follows the same route.



Soda Springs (easy)
1 mile (1.6 km) round-trip; 30 minutes
No elevation gain

Glen Aulin (moderately strenuous)
10.4 miles (16.7 km) round-trip; 6-8 hours
800 ft (244 m) elevation gain

Waterwheel Fall is also accessible via this trailhead. For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.

Hours :
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here :
The trailhead is located along Tioga Road, approximately a quarter mile east of the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center, across from the dump station.

Rules & Regulations :
- Stay on established trails
- Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
- Pack out what you pack in
- Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center.
- Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
- Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
- Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings :
- Stay off domes during thunderstorms!
- Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
- Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
- Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.


Accessibility :
The first quarter mile of the dirt trail is flat, with small paved sections, however, is not considered accessible.

images.altText: Two people walk past a metal sign that lists the hiking destinations of the trail they're on.

audioDescription:
To the north of Tioga Road, a sandy trail leads into the vast expanse of the open Tuolumne Meadows. At the trailhead, a metal sign reads Soda Springs - 0.5 miles, Glen Aulin - 5.2 miles, and Waterwheel Falls - 8.7 miles. Two smaller signs are bolted to the metal post below the latter sign. The top sign shows an icon of a bicyclist inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through it. The lower sign shows an icon of a dog inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through it.

The sandy path is lined with several tall trees. As you get further into the middle of the meadow, an unobstructed view of the granite peaks and domes that surround the area start to show. Small signs on little wooden stakes are driven into the ground. The signs read, give plants a chance! Please stay off! The sign has an illustration of a hiking boot, hovering over four little plants, as if its ready to step on them, inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through it.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Glacier-Carved Landscape
listingDescription: You're standing where glaciers once passed through. Look for evidence of glaciers and read the wayside exhibit to learn more.

images.altText: Several large boulders randomly sit on an expanse of granite bedrock, which is streaked with lines and cracks.
images.caption: Glacial Erratics and striations can be seen on the granite bedrock near Olmsted Point.

bodyText: You're standing where glaciers once passed through. Look for evidence of glaciers and read the wayside exhibit to learn more.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the second stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Trees start to thin out as this area begins to open into a meadow. Large granite boulders are randomly sitting throughout the meadow. Granite peaks are peaking through the trees to the west. The wayside exhibit is titled, A Glacier-Carved Landscape, and has an illustration of the surrounding area covering the upper two-thirds of the panel. Two domes that overlap each other are in the foreground. The front dome shows the close-up detail of the granite's patchy surface...some areas are textured and gritty, shown by different variances of speckled grey, while other patchy areas are white to indicate its smoothness. The white, smooth areas are labeled, glacial polish and striations. The next dome, a little further in distance, is white and smooth. There are about 13 large round boulders that sit atop its surface, which are labeled erratics. Beyond the domes is a large, flat, open space - the meadow. Beyond the meadow, the terrain slopes upward into a range of high peaks. A sharp, pointed, craggy peak is labeled Cathedral Peak.

Panel text reads, imagine a time when it was colder and snow did not melt in summer. The accumulated snow turned to ice. As the ice deepened, its weight caused it to flow as a glacier down the canyon to the west. Glaciers formed here many times in the past two million years. As recently as 20,000 years ago, glaciers covered all but the highest jagged peaks around you.

Look for evidence of glaciers such as erratics (boulders moved by glaciers), glacial polish, and striations in the bedrock. Only sharp peaks, such as Unicorn and Cathedral, poked above the 2,000 feet of glacial ice.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Place for People
listingDescription: For thousands of years, the trade routes of local Native Americans passed through this area. What did they trade and who traded with who? Read this wayside exhibit to learn more.

images.altText: Sunlight hits bowl-shaped depressions that were pounded into granite rock.

bodyText: For thousands of years, the trade routes of local Native Americans passed through this area. What did they trade and who traded with who? Read this wayside exhibit to learn more.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the ninth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Tall trees stand nearby to the left. To the right, an open meadow shows off the sharp, pointed, granite peaks that rise above the distant forest. A narrow river snakes its way through the center of the meadow, from left to right. The wayside exhibit is titled, A Place for People. On the right, two-thirds side of the panel, there is a colored photo of an older woman with glasses, wearing a scarf around her head. She is wearing a red, button-down dress with white polka-dots, and a blue and white floral apron around her waist. She is on her knees on a large rock, leaning forward, with both hands grasping a pestle that is pressed down into a pile of acorns inside a shallow hole in the rock.

Caption: Acorns were an important food source for both the Sierra Miwok and the Mono Lake Paiute people. The acorns were pounded into flour in bedrock mortars; some of these mortars can be found near Lembert Dome and elsewhere in Tuolumne Meadows. Photo right: Maggie Howard, Mono Lake Paiute, 1942.

Panel text reads, for thousands of years, when the snow melted and the deer returned, Native Americans traveled here. During the 1800s, the Mono Trail crossed Tuolumne Meadows, linking Sierra Miwok people from the west and Mono Lake Paiute from the east. For a lengthy period, they traded pine nuts and obsidian from the Mono Basin for acorns and shell beads from west of the Sierra.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Short Growing Season
listingDescription: Tuolumne Meadows is often covered in snow from approximately October or November to late May, giving plants and animals only a short window of time to prepare for winter again. Read the wayside exhibit to learn about Tuolumne Meadows' short growing season.

images.altText: Trees surround the perimeter of a meadow. Two tall peaks rise above treeline in the distance.

bodyText: Tuolumne Meadows is often covered in snow from approximately October or November to late May, giving plants and animals only a short window of time to prepare for winter again. Read the wayside exhibit to learn about Tuolumne Meadows' short growing season.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fifth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. This particular part of the meadow has a bunch of trees enclosing the view. Different types of sedge and grasses grow, as well as some small saplings. Granite boulders are randomly scattered. The wayside exhibit is titled, A Short Growing Season, and has an illustration of a meadow on the bottom two-thirds of the panel. Short grasses grow in different sized, connected, ring-shapes, throughout the meadow. A line of trees and mountainous terrain are along the back edge of the meadow.

Panel text reads, few types of plants can survive where the growing season is so short. Almost all of Tuolumne's plants are perennial; most annuals cannot grow here. They do not have enough time each summer to sprout, flower, and seed. The dominant grass-like plant is shorthair sedge. By late summer, the meadow turns amber as the sedge matures and becomes dormant.

Illustration: A wispy, tuft of hair-like grasses grow upward, some with small oval-shaped growths at the ends. The roots are short, brown, and just as hairy looking.

Caption: Meadow soils are shallow and fragile. Unauthorized trails compact the soil and the ruts can last for centuries. Please stay on designated trails.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - A Summer Home
listingDescription: Jean Baptiste Lembert enjoyed this view back in the 1800s. How did he suvive the Tuolumne Meadows winters? Read this wayside exhibit for more information.

images.altText: A dirt road that doubles as a walking trail leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

bodyText: Jean Baptiste Lembert enjoyed this view back in the 1800s. How did he suvive the Tuolumne Meadows winters? Read this wayside exhibit for more information.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the eighth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour and is located at a fork in the path/road. The path to the left leads into the open meadow that allows views of surrounding peaks and domes. The path to the right goes slightly uphill and into a stand of pines. A little way up the path is a metal trail marker that reads, Soda Springs .1 mile, Parsons Lodge .15 mile, Glen Aulin 5.4 miles, and Pacific Crest Trail. The wayside exhibit is titled, Summer Home, and has a black and white photo of an old log cabin on the right, two-thirds of the panel. The small, rugged cabin has a roof made of wooden shingles, no door, and airy spaces between the logs. A large pile of boulders sit next to the cabin.

Caption: The old Tioga Road leads off to the left. Continue to the right to Soda Springs.

Panel text reads, Jean Baptiste Lembert (1840-1840), one of the many people drawn to this landscape, claimed 160 acres around Soda Springs in 1885.

He raised angora goats and gathered insect specimens for the Smithsonian and other museums. Like the native people, Lembert moved to lower elevations in the winter.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Baptism in Nature's Warm Heart
listingDescription: Immerse yourself in the meadows and think about all the people who have crossed through this area. To learn more read the wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A black and white photo shows an elderly man sitting on a boulder. He white hair and a long beard.

bodyText: Immerse yourself in the meadows and think about all the people who have crossed through this area. To learn more read the wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the first stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. A dense stand of pines surround the area as the dirt path, which also appears to be a dirt road, transitions into an open meadow. A metal sign with text cut out of it reads, PCT and John Muir Trail, with upward pointing arrows. The wayside exhibit is titled, Baptism in Nature's Warm Heart and has a photo of an older man, with a white beard and mustache, on the left side of the panel. The man is wearing a long-sleeved white shirt, a black vest, and dark pants. He is sitting on a rock, with his legs dangling and crossed, his arms reached out, crossed, and leaning on a walking stick, looking off into the distance, to the right.

Quote: "This is the most spacious and delightful high pleasure-ground I have yet seen...and though lying high in the sky, the surrounding mountains are so much higher, one feels protected as if in a grand hall." - John Muir

The panel text reads, thousands of people - Native Americans, pioneers, sightseers, and rangers - have traveled through Tuolumne Meadows and returned often. It was here that conservationist John Muir introduced his friends to the mountain wilderness and began the discussion that created Yosemite National Park.

You, too, can stroll down the old Tioga Road into the heart of Tuolumne Meadows toward Soda Springs and immerse yourself in these high meadows.

Black and white photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads through a forest.

Black and white photo: Two Caucasion children wearing hooded jackets sit on a rock and look at the camera.

Black and white photo: A close-up photo of a Caucasion man wearing a ranger hat, looking off into the distance toward the right.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Birth of A Park
listingDescription: It took a discussion around a campfire here, and two magazine articles to convince the American public that this area was worth preserving. Learn more about this area on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

bodyText: It took a discussion around a campfire here, and two magazine articles to convince the American public that this area was worth preserving. Learn more about this area on this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the twelvth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. The marshy, waterlogged area of Soda Springs, seen just down the dirt path to the left, transitions back into a meadow with tall grasses. A narrow river flows to the right, and pointed granite peaks can be seen above the distant treeline. The wayside exhibit is titled, Birth of a Park, and has a black and white photo of a man and two women sitting on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads through a forest, on the right, two-thirds of the panel.

Caption: Visitors to Tuolumne Meadows on the old Tioga Road, c. 1890

Panel text reads, around a campfire here in 1899, John Muir and publisher Robert Underwood Johnson discussed ways to protect this area. Johnson printed two articles by Muir in his Century Magazine, proposing to the American public that this land be preserved for all time. One year later Yosemite National Park was born.

In 1892, Muir founded the Sierra CLub to encourage others to explore, protect, and cherish their new park.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Eloquent Spokesman
listingDescription: Throughout Yosemite, you'll see quotes by John Muir that express his observations, experiences, and spiritual connection with the area. Read this wayside exhibit to learn more about John Muir and how this scenery you're looking at now, inspired him.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

bodyText: Throughout Yosemite, you'll see quotes by John Muir that express his observations, experiences, and spiritual connection with the area. Read this wayside exhibit to learn more about John Muir and how this scenery you're looking at now, inspired him.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the tenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. An open meadow with no trees directly obstructing the view. A river snakes through the meadow and a granite mountain range rises over the distant forest, spanning the panoramic view from left to right. The wayside exhibit is titled, Eloquent Spokesman. A sketch of two large masses, side by side, one in front of the other with the front edges slanting downward, and multiple arrows pointing left. At the front of the masses are five trees. Cursive scribblings accompany the sketch.

Caption: One of Muir's journal pages, 1872. His observations of glacial evidence led to new theories about Yosemite's origins.

Black and white photo: an older man, with a white beard and mustache, is wearing a long-sleeved white shirt, a black vest, and dark pants. He is sitting on a rock, with his legs dangling and crossed, his arms reached out, crossed, and leaning on a walking stick, looking off into the distance, toward the right.

Caption: John Muir, 1907

Quote: "In every walk with nature one receives far more thane he seeks." - John Muir, 1877

Panel Text reads, John Muir (1838- 1914), first came to these meadows in 1869 as a sheepherder. He was so moved by Tuolumne that he returned here throughout his life, often with friends. Muir wrote about how the mountains changed him.

At first he was overwhelmed by the beauty and grandeur. Then he wanted to explore the mysteries of the geology and biology. In time, he experienced a spiritual connection that inspired him to protect the mountains he loved.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - McCauley Cabin
listingDescription: The McCauley brothers built this cabin in the 1890s and has since exchanged ownership between the Sierra Club, and the National Park Service. Learn a bit more about the history of this cabin on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wood cabin sits on a hilltop above a meadow. Pointy granite peaks can be seen in the distance.

bodyText: The McCauley brothers built this cabin in the 1890s and has since exchanged ownership between the Sierra Club, and the National Park Service. Learn a bit more about the history of this cabin on this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourteenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. A rustic log cabin sits on a small hilltop, overlooking Tuolumne Meadows, the river, and the granite landscape that surrounds it. The front of the cabin has a wooden door with a window, offcentered to the right, and a window with shutters on each side end of the building. There are now windows in the back. The nearby wayside exhibit is titled, The McCauley Cabin, and has a black and white photo on the left, two-thirds of the panel. The photo shows a man, a woman, and two young blonde girls standing in front of them. The young girl to the left is shorter than the girl on right, who is wearing checkered pants. A log cabin home is in the background, with boulders and trees surrounding it.

Caption: The campground caretakers stayed in the McCauley Cabin. As a young girl, Margaret Eissler (in checkered pants) lived here with her family for six summers (1956-1961). Her childhood experience instilled a love for Tuolumne Meadows that influenced all aspects of her life. She later returned as a ranger-naturalist.

Panel text reads, Following Jean Baptiste Lembert's death, the McCauley brothers bought his land for pasture in 1897 and built this cabin. When the land was again put up for sale, Sierra Club members raised money to purchase it in 1912 to keep it uncommercialized.

The Sierra Club opened a small campground, and summer after summer campers returned here to renew their connection with these meadows and mountains. In 1973, the National Park Service bought the Sierra Club property.

Tuolumne Meadows has found its way into many people's hearts. Follow the river. Take some time to explore. Discover for yourself the wonders of these high meadows.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Meadow Dwellers
listingDescription: To escape the harsh winters, deer and most birds migrate, while marmots and ground squirrels hibernate. How do other local animals adapt to the winter? Learn more on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

bodyText: To escape the harsh winters, deer and most birds migrate, while marmots and ground squirrels hibernate. How do other local animals adapt to the winter? Learn more on this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the sixth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. The meadow has several trees that obstruct the open view. Small patches of grass grow mixed with small patches of bare, granitic sand. Granite rocks and boulders are randomly scattered. The wayside exhibit is titled, Meadow Dwellers, and has an illustration of a cross-section of a meadow on the top two-thirds of the panel. The illustration projects four layers of a meadow during the winter - an underground layer, a thin layer of air between the ground and the snow, a large layer of snow, and then what is above the snow. The left side of the illustration shows a large tree with its roots spreading out beneath the ground. Perched on one of the tree branches is a small, chipmunk-like animal, with a long, fuzzy, curled tail, labeled chickaree. To the bottom left of the tree is a small, mouse-like animal walking in the air pocket between the ground and snow layer; it is labeled a shrew. Below the ground, in the midst of the trees' roots is a grey squirrel, curled into a ball, sleeping in a pocket that has a tunnel leading to the grounds surface. It is labeled Belding Ground Squirrel. To the right of the tree are two large boulders that are half underground and half above ground. A tunnel leads underground into a pocket beneath a large boulder where an animal with a long, slender body rests on its haunches; it is labeled pocket gopher. A mouse nestles in an airpocket between the ground and snow, next to one of the large boulders. Above the snow layer, a coyote has his head tilted up with its mouth open, as if its howling, and a longtail weasel slithers down the snow. A mountain range is in the background.

Caption: There is an air layer called the subnivean zone bewteen the snow and ground where small creatures live during the long winter.

Panel text reads, when you look for wildlife here, think small. Birds and rodents are abundant. Deer and bears are here, though seldom seen. To escape the harsh winters, deer and most birds migrate, while marmots and ground squirrels hibernate. Mice, shrews, and gophers remain active under the snow, where they are hunted by small predators like weasels.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Meadow in the Sky
listingDescription: Each winter the Tioga Road closes for seven or eight months. Only a few hardy skiers experience winter in Tuolumne Meadows. Learn about how this meadow changes over the winter season on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a dirt trail that leads around the outskirts of a meadow.

bodyText: Each winter the Tioga Road closes for seven or eight months. Only a few hardy skiers experience winter in Tuolumne Meadows. Learn about how this meadow changes over the winter season on this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the seventh stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Facing south, several trees pop up in an otherwise open meadow full of tall grasses. The granite peaks on the opposite side of the meadow are now more visible. The wayside exhibit is titled, Meadow in the Sky, and has a colored photo of an open landscape, blanketed in thick snow, leading to and showcasing snow-capped, pointed mountain peaks. Pine trees are on the left and right of the open area. The sky is clear and blue.

Panel text reads, these meadows stretch along the Tuolumne River for ten miles. At 8,600 feet, winter lasts for eight months, forcing the plants and animals to adapt to deep snow and a short growing season.

The climate is typically Mediterranean; winters bring ninety percent of the precipitation and summers are dry and warm. The meadows change visibly from week to week as they adjust to a compressed spring-summer-fall season.

Each winter the Tioga Road closes for seven or eight months. Only a few hardy skiers experience winter in Tuolumne Meadows.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Meadows
listingDescription: Take a look at the vast meadow before you. Meadows are always changing. To learn more about how and why, read the wayside exibit about meadows.

images.altText: A small pine tree grows in a dry, brown meadow.
images.caption: A small pine tree grows in a dry meadow.

bodyText: Take a look at the vast meadow before you. Meadows are always changing. To learn more about how and why, read the wayside exibit about meadows.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Facing south, a meadow containing tall grasses, several mature pines and a few small saplings spans outward. Granite peaks on the opposite side of the meadow are now more visible. The wayside exhibit is titled, Meadows, and has an illustration of a cross-section of the Tuolumne Meadows area covering the upper two-thirds of the panel. The bottom quarter of the illustration depicts a white wave that starts at a small hill on the left, slopes down into a slump, then slopes back up into another small hill. Beneath the ground, the white wave, which represents granite bedrock is broken up into multiple wavy parallel lines. On top of both the left and right hill is a tree with roots that vein down and outward through the layers of granite, beneath the ground surface. In the downward slump, or basin, between the two hills, an open green meadow is shown. A few granite peaks rise above a tree line in the background.

Panel text reads, after the glaciers melted 10,000 years ago, shallow, broad depressions in the bedrock began to fill with sand. Because granite basins hold spring snowmelt, these areas are too wet for trees. Sedges and grasses thrive in these saturated low spots, creating meadows. Meadows are always changing. As they get drier, trees invade the edges and high areas. In wetter times, the trees die and the meadows expand.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Picket Pins
listingDescription: As you stand here, can you hear the sounds of nature? Birds? Picket Pins? To learn more about "picket pins," otherwise known as Belding ground squirrels, read the wayside exhibit, then keep your ears and eyes open to see if you cross paths with one.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along the dirt trail that leads on the outskirts of a meadow.

bodyText: As you stand here, can you hear the sounds of nature? Birds? Picket Pins? To learn more about "picket pins," otherwise known as Belding ground squirrels, read the wayside exhibit, then keep your ears and eyes open to see if you cross paths with one.
audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the third stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. Facing south, several trees pop up in an otherwise open meadow full of tall grasses. The granite peaks on the opposite side of the meadow are now more visible. The wayside exhibit is titled, Picket Pins, and has a black and white photo of a squirrel covering the right half of the panel. The squirrel is facing toward the left, standing straight as an arrow with its arms hanging down in front of it.

Caption: The nickname "picket pin" likens the straight posture of the alert squirrel to the metal pin once used to picket horses in meadows.

Panel text reads, the most commonly seen and heard meadow dwellers are teh Belding ground squirrels, or "picket pins." They stand up and watch for danger, then whistle to warn the others.
Adult females and juveniles live in extended family groups, while adult males live alone at the edge of the meadows. In late summer, only the young are still active; the adults are already hibernating.

title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - Tuolumne River Bridge
listingDescription: Finish off your tour by standing on this bridge and taking in the panoramic view of the meadows, peaks, domes, and river, and reflect on the natural and cultural history that made this moment possible.

images.altText: A bridge crosses over a river that flows through a meadow.

bodyText: Finish off your tour by standing on this bridge and taking in the panoramic view of the meadows, peaks, domes, and river, and reflect on the natural and cultural history that made this moment possible.
audioDescription: This is the fifteenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. A wooden bridge with knee-high wood railings, crosses over the glistening Tuolumne River as it narrowly meanders through the meadows. Standing on the bridge, looking west, a granite mountain range with several pointed peaks, the Cathedral Peak, Unicorn Peak, and Eichorn Peak, panoramically extends across the landscape, beyond the distant treeline. Looking east, a distinct granite dome, Lembert Dome, is not to far off. Beyond the dome, further in the distant, beyond treeline, are more mountains. Looking down, the water is clear and the bottom of the river, which has smooth rocks and pebbles, can be seen.

title: South Entrance
listingDescription: Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park. The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.

images.altText: Three small wooden buildings at the entrance with the American flag on a pole
images.title: South Entrance
images.caption: South Entrance

bodyText:
Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park.

The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.

Entrance Fees

(valid for seven days with receipt)

  • Private vehicle: $35 (no per-person fee)
  • Motorcycle: $30 (no per-person fee)
  • Individual (walk-in, bicycle, horse, in a bus): $20 per person, aged 16 or older

Passes

  • Yosemite Pass: $70
    Valid for one year in Yosemite.
  • Interagency Annual Pass: $80
    Valid for one year at all federal recreation sites.
  • Interagency Senior Pass: $80
    (Lifetime) For U.S. citizens or permanent residents 62 and over.
  • Interagency Annual Senior Pass: $20
    For U.S. citizens or permanent residents 62 and over.
  • Interagency Access Pass (Free)
    (Lifetime) For permanently disabled U.S. citizens or permanent residents.
  • Interagency Military Pass (Free)
    (Annual) For active duty U.S. military and dependents.
  • Interagency 4th Grade Pass (Free)
    (Annual) For fourth graders and their families. Must present paper voucher. For paper voucher and more information visit

See website for more details.

Hours

Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year (conditions permitting).

Getting Here

From Highway 99 in Fresno, take Highway 41 north into Yosemite National Park.

Traffic Warnings

From spring through fall, you are likely to experience congestion in Yosemite Valley and at park entrances. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive early in the morning or in the late afternoon to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.
audioDescription: As you approach the entrance station, the road splits into three separate, inbound lanes. There is one outbound lane. Each inbound lane has a ranger-managed booth on its left side. The American flag waves on a tall flagpole at the entrance station.

title: Summit Meadow
listingDescription: In the summer, an explosion of color lure people toward this sub-alpine meadow to delight in the spectacular display of wildflowers.

images.altText: Grassy meadow with purple wildflowers in bloom
images.title: Summit Meadow
images.caption: Summit Meadow

bodyText:
In the summer, an explosion of color lure people toward this sub-alpine meadow to delight in the spectacular display of wildflowers.

Hours

Open to vehicles from approximately late May through October or November.

Getting Here 

Located along the Glacier Point Road, about 10 miles east of the Chinquapin intersection and the Wawona Road (continuation of Highway 41).

Rules & Regulations

To protect fragile meadow ecosystems, please stay out of the meadow.

Accessibility

There are no designated accessible parking spaces. The meadow can be viewed from the paved parking area.
audioDescription: The forest opens up into a large meadow along the south side of Glacier Point Road. In the summer, a full display of wildflowers carpet the meadow. In the fall, the plush, green meadow turns light brown. The far side of the meadow is lined with forest. A paved roadside turnout offers limited parallel parking. A few clusters of tall trees are near a wooden fence that zigzags between the parking area and the meadow. A small yellow sign bolted to the wooden fence reads, give plants a chance, please stay off. An illustration of a foot, ready to step on small flowers and plants is inside a red circle with a line slashed diagonally through the circle. A green recycle bin and a brown trash bin are near the parking turnout. A small, brown, structure that houses a vault toilet is at the west end of the parking area.

title: Sunrise Lakes Trailhead
listingDescription: If you're seeking a challenge with a picturesque payoff, Sunrise Lakes won't disappoint. Indeed, a beautiful place to see a sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it. There is also a High Sierra Camp located at Sunrise, whose origin dates back to 1916, the earliest days of the National Park Service.

images.altText: A brown and white sign reads, "Sunrise," and has an icon of a hiker and an arrow pointing right.

bodyText:
If you're seeking a challenge with a picturesque payoff, Sunrise Lakes won't disappoint.

Indeed, a beautiful place to see a sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it. There is also a High Sierra Camp located at Sunrise, whose origin dates back to 1916, the earliest days of the National Park Service.

Sunrise Lakes (strenuous)

10.4 mi (16.7 km) round-trip; 6-8 hours
1,300 ft (396 m) elevation gain

Other hiking destinations accessible from this trailhead include Clouds Rest, Half Dome, and Yosemite Valley.

For hiking and trail information, please visit a wilderness center or visitor center.

Hours

Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here

Begin at the Sunrise Lakes Trailhead parking area, just west of Tenaya Lake, on Tioga Road.

Rules & Regulations

  • Stay on established trails
  • Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
  • Pack out what you pack in
  • Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center.
  • Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
  • Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
  • No oversized vehicles on road to parking area.
