  • Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
  • Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility

This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: The Sunrise Trailhead is found on the south side of a small, paved, loop driveway and parking area, along the south side of Tioga Road. The turn-off to the parking area is marked with a brown and white sign that shows a white icon of a person hiking inside a white square outline. The parking area is surrounded by trees, with Tioga Road to the north. A brown dumpster, six food lockers, and a small structure containing a vault toilet, line the outskirts of the parking lot. At the trailhead, the dirt path leads through tall trees. Three signs are posted next to the path. The first sign is a metal sign that reads, Sunrise H.S.C. 5.2 miles, Clouds Rest 7.4 miles, and Half Dome 12.5 miles. The second sign is brown and reads, Entering Yosemite Wilderness - Wilderness Permit is required for all overnight use. Please store food properly. Help protect the wild animals by keeping them wild. Wood fires are prohibited above 9,600 feet to protect fragile alpine areas. Please do not construct new fire rings. The use of gas stoves is encouraged in all areas. Select an existing campsite 100 feet or more (40 steps) from water, trails, and dry water courses. Help protect water quality by not washing anything in lakes and streams. Bury human waste at least six inches deep 100 feet from water. Must pack out all toilet paper. Shortcutting is dangerous and contributes to erosion. Please stay on established trails. Maximum group size is 15 people, or 8 maximum for off trail travel. Stock groups are limited to travel on trails only. All stock must be picketed 100 feet from water. Please scatter or bury all manure. Pack out all you pack in. Pick up extra trash when possible. Three illustrations show three icons in three separate boxes with a red slash line diagionally across the boxes. The first icon is of a dog, the second of a bicycle, and the third of a person shooting a rifle. The third sign is a small sign that reads, Hiking to Half Dome? Don't forget your permit. The sign has the silhouette of a man with a backpack climbing up a dome with the aid of cables.

title: Swinging Bridge Picnic Area
listingDescription: Experience a view like none other while standing on the Swinging Bridge. Get a glimpse of Yosemite Falls and its reflection in the Merced River during the day or by full moon at night. The first thing you may notice about Swinging Bridge is that it does not swing. Multiple years of high flood waters took its toll on the previous swinging bridge, until it was finally replaced with a permanently fixed bridge after being damaged in the 1964 flood. Picnic tables and grills are co

images.altText: People walk over the swinging bridge while people play in the water below it. A tall, very thin waterfall is in the distance.

bodyText:
Experience a view like none other while standing on the Swinging Bridge. Get a glimpse of Yosemite Falls and its reflection in the Merced River during the day or by full moon at night.

The first thing you may notice about Swinging Bridge is that it does not swing. Multiple years of high flood waters took its toll on the previous swinging bridge, until it was finally replaced with a permanently fixed bridge after being damaged in the 1964 flood.

Picnic tables and grills are conveniently located at this scenic spot along the Merced River that offers views of the Yosemite Falls.

The bridge was replaced after being damaged in the 1964 flood

Hours:
This picnic area is available from dawn to dusk.

Getting Here:
Swinging Bridge Picnic Area, is located on Southside Drive, several miles east of Bridalveil Fall.

Rules & Regulations:
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings:
For your safety and that of wildlife:

Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.
Yosemite's water can be deceptively dangerous and unforgiving. Visitors are strongly urged to enjoy swift-moving or high water from a safe distance, especially in the spring.

Accessibility:
The Swinging Bridge Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible vault toilets, and grills. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
audioDescription: The Swinging Bridge Picnic Area has a small parking lot. A green recycle dumpster and brown trash dumpster are in the lot. A paved path leads from the parking area to the Swinging Bridge, a permanent wooden bridge with wood railing barriers on each side, crossing over the Merced River. A small yellow sign affixed to the wooden railing reads, diving or jumping from bridge prohibited. Beyond the bridge is a meadow that allows for open views of the 2,000-foot plus rock walls that line both sides of the Valley at this point. Along the paved path as you walk to the bridge, near the parking lot, a brown facility holds four separate vault toilets. On the right side of the path, a heavily shaded area has picnic tables and permanently placed grills, situated among the tall trees that grow in the area. The terrain slopes down a slight hill to the riverbank. A metal sign posted near the river reads, no ground fires, and shows an icon of a campfire, with a red diagonal line slashed through it. A sandy beach area is located across the river.

title: Tenaya Lake
listingDescription: Caught between immense granite domes and clear Sierra Nevada sky, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite's frontcountry. Because of its remarkable scenic qualities, its inviting blue water, and its proximity to Tioga Road, Tenaya Lake is one of the most popular destinations for summer visitors in Yosemite. It is quite popular for picnicking, swimming, and canoeing. Tenaya Lake was named after Chief Tenaya, who was the last chief of the Yosemite Indians.

images.altText: Lake with granite cliffs at its edge
images.title: Tenaya Lake
images.caption: Tenaya Lake

bodyText:
Caught between immense granite domes and clear Sierra Nevada sky, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite's frontcountry. Because of its remarkable scenic qualities, its inviting blue water, and its proximity to Tioga Road, Tenaya Lake is one of the most popular destinations for summer visitors in Yosemite. It is quite popular for picnicking, swimming, and canoeing.

Tenaya Lake was named after Chief Tenaya, who was the last chief of the Yosemite Indians.

Hours

Tioga Road is open to vehicles from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here

Located along Tioga Road a little less than 7 miles (11 km) west of Tuolumne Meadows.

Rules & Regulations

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Bears and other wildlife may be present on or near park roads, please drive with caution.
  • Be aware of potential hazards on park roads, including wet and icy conditions or debris in the roadway, especially in the spring or fall. 

Accessibility

The east end of Tenaya Lake has designated accessible parking spaces, an accessible vault toilet, and an accessible path that leads to open views of Tenaya Lake.
audioDescription: A large body of water is surrounded by granite domes and peaks. Granite bedrock leads into the lake along most of the shoreline. The east end of the lake has a sandy beach. Large clusters of tall trees surround the perimeter of the lake and partially lead up the granite slopes before thinning out at their peaks. A road follows the northern edge of the lake.

title: Tenaya Lake Picnic Area
listingDescription: Enjoy this magnificent high-country lake surrounded by granite domes, lodgepole forests, and Yosemite's vast wilderness. Picnic tables are available at this pleasant spot near Tenaya Lake. Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations not accepted).

images.altText: A sandy beach meets the waters' edge of a lake. Large granite domes emerge from the treeline of a surrounding forest.

bodyText:
Enjoy this magnificent high-country lake surrounded by granite domes, lodgepole forests, and Yosemite's vast wilderness.

Picnic tables are available at this pleasant spot near Tenaya Lake.

Hours
Tioga Road is open to vehicles from late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here
Located along Tioga Road a little less than 7 miles (11 km) west of Tuolumne Meadows.

Rules & Regulations
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings
For your safety and that of wildlife:

Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
Keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility
The Tenaya Lake Picnic Area features a few accessible picnic tables with extended tops, an accessible restroom, and an accessible path that leads to great views of Tenaya Lake. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
audioDescription: On the east side of a large paved parking area are two wooden picnic tables, a food locker, a brown facility holding four vault toilets, and a wayside exhibit, placed among tall trees. In the east corner of the parking lot are two large brown trash dumpsters, and one large green dumpster for recycling. The wayside exhibit panel is blue and is bolted to a frame made of thick wooden posts, and is titled, welcome to Tenaya Lake. Half of the panel background is a two-toned picture of a lake that is surrounded by domes and peaks. The other half of the panel is a map. The caption reads, caught between immense granite domes and the clear High Sierra sky, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite National Park. Here, at its eastern end, Tenaya Creek forms a series of braided streams before flowing into the lake. Text reads, if you have a few hours, stroll the flat, paved trail (less than a quarter-mile, round-trip). You'll be rewarded with glimpses of the glacially carved peaks and domes and a spectacular view of the lake emerging through the trees. If time permits, take a picnic to one of the tables on the beach and enjoy a lazy High Sierra afternoon exploring or relaxing in the smooth granitic sand. While hardy souls may be tempted to jump in, remember...Tenaya Lake is fed by snowmelt and stays quite cold!If you have half a day, don't miss the boardwalk, a picnic, or the beach, but (if conditions permit) cross the Tenaya Creek inlet at the southeast end of the beach and follow the trail west along the shore of the lake. This mostly-level stroll takes you toward the Sunrise Lakes Trailhead, joining back with the Tioga Road. Here, you can retrace your steps back or hop on the free shuttle at Stop #10, and ride one stop back to your car (stop #9). It is possible to walk all the way around the lake (2.8 mi/5.2 km), but requires walking along the shoulder of busy Tioga Road. A full-day hike to Tuolumne Meadows - Pick up a trail heading east from Tenaya Lake. This 9-mile one-way hike parallels the Tioga Road, leading to Tuolumne Meadows. At Tuolumne Meadows, pick up the free shuttle for the short ride back to Tenaya Lake. Shuttle Information - The free Tioga Road shuttle runs between Tuolumne Meadows and Olmsted Point. Shuttle schedule changes seasonally and as conditions permit. Check local postings for current schedule. During times of high water, unbridged river or creek crossings can be hazardous. Take extra time and use good judgement when crossing rivers and creeks. Check the weather! Be especially aware of the potential for thunderstorms. If you are hiking, take a map and compass. Tell someone where you are going and when you'll be back. Avoid exhaustion and dehydration. Carry plenty of water and high-energy snacks. The altitude at Tenaya Lake is just over 8,000 feet above sea level. Signs of altitude sickness can include nausea, dizziness, and headache. Descending to a lower elevation can help alleviate symptoms. Scrambling or climbing on rocks can be dangerous. Remember, coming down can be much harder than going up, and wet rocks are slippery. Be prepared to pack out what you pack in; garbage and recycling receptacles are located near the parking area. Map: The map shows Tenaya Lake, indicated by a large, blue, oval shape, slightly tilted, in the center of the map. A white line extends diagonally across the map, from the bottom left to the top right, passing by the north shore of Tenaya Lake. A trail, indicated by red dotted lines, passes by the south shore of the Tenaya Lake and partly follows a few creeks, indicated by a blue solid line, before splitting off into different trails to the left and right. To the left of the lake, icons indicate the start of hiking trails, restrooms, and parking. To the right of the lake, a red dot indicates you are here, and icons indicating trailheads, parking, restrooms, and picnic areas are shown. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. A flat dirt path leads into the forest with several wayside exhibits along the way to the Tenaya Lake shoreline. The first wayside exhibit is titled, disappearing wetlands. Text reads, wetlands like this one have likely been here for the last 10,000 years, providing homes and food for a great variety of plant and animal species. In Yosemite, wetland areas make up only about 3% of the landscape, but are estimated to harbor up to one-third of all the plant species in the Park. They also capture, store, and release melting snow, extending the availability of life-giving water during the dry summer months. Here in the Sierra Nevada Mountains and across the globe, wetlands are disappearing rapidly. Effects from trampling, development, and climate change threaten to alter the delicate wetland ecology forever. In Yosemite National Park, park managers work to prevent loss of wetlands by preserving and restoring wetland areas and building boardwalks to help minimize damage from visitors. Photo:

title: The Ahwahnee
listingDescription: Known for its stunning interior design and architecture, The Ahwahnee was specifically designed to highlight its natural surroundings, featuring Yosemite Falls, Half Dome, and Glacier Point.The hotel holds a historic heritage as it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is a National Historic Landmark. The destination of queens and presidents alike, this dis

images.altText: A sheer cliff face serves as a backdrop behind a building made of stone and wooden planks.
images.title: The Ahwahnee
images.caption: The Ahwahnee at dusk.

bodyText:
Known for its stunning interior design and architecture, The Ahwahnee was specifically designed to highlight its natural surroundings, featuring Yosemite Falls, Half Dome, and Glacier Point.

The destination of queens and presidents alike, this distinctive Yosemite hotel offers a perfect balance of history, hospitality and elegance.

The Ahwahnee offers hotel rooms, suites, parlors, and cottages. There is a gift shop with a focus on local artisans, a sweet shop, a bar, and a heated outdoor swimming pool on the premises. The Ahwahnee Dining Room serves breakfast, lunch, dinner and Sunday brunch. See the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for hours.

See website for more information about the rooms, to check availability, to book a room, and to get an idea of things to do in The Ahwahnee area.

With one glimpse of The Ahwahnee, you'll be transported back in time, to an era of elegance and new possibilities. Commissioned in the 1920s in the pursuit of drawing more affluent visitors to Yosemite National Park, The Ahwahnee is a testament to the vision and perseverance of American ingenuity. More than 5,000 tons of stone, 1,000 tons of steel, and 30,000 feet of lumber were transported through the mountains to create the hotel. Read more about its history.

Hours

Year-round
The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.
Check-in: 4 pm
Check-out: 11 am

Getting Here

You can reach Yosemite Valley via Highways 41, 140, and 120. Follow signs for The Ahwahnee, located in eastern Yosemite Valley. Parking is valet only. The Ahwahnee is also serviced by the Valleywide Shuttle, stop #3.

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all accommodations and buildings in Yosemite.
  • There are no pets allowed on property.

Hazards & Warnings

Bears have broken into cars, sometimes when only a candy wrapper or closed cooler was in view. If staying overnight, remove all scented items, food related or others and store in your room or bear-proof storage lockers.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Select rooms and cottages are accessible. Valet parking is available, and designated accessible parking spaces are located in the parking lot. An accessible path of travel connects the hotel with the cabins.
audioDescription: The Ahwahnee is a 5-plus story building with wooden plank siding and cobblestone columns. Turquoise shutters are on each side of all windows, and several cobblestone chimneys stand atop its roof. Tables with green umbrellas line the patio behind the building. The granite landscape rises up behind the building.

title: The Ahwahnee Architecture

images.altText: A sheer granite rock wall rises up behind a building made of stone and wooden planks.
images.title: The Ahwahnee
images.caption: The Ahwahnee at dusk.

bodyText:
Designed by Gilbert Stanley Underwood, the Ahwahnee opened in 1927. As an experiment in construction methods, it was built with relatively fireproof materials. Instead of wood, concrete and granite was textured and stained to resemble redwood. The stately building combines rustic and art deco influences. The massing of a central tower and two wings, forming a “Y” shape, is unusual compared to other rustic-era park lodges. The vertical granite buttresses, piers, and chimneys reflect the granite cliffs of Yosemite Valley.

In the original design, visitors would enter through the modern-day bar area. Shortly before the opening date, staff noticed that this entrance caused vehicle fumes to fill the hotel. Instead, contractors quickly constructed the covered walkway and porte-cochere entrance in use today.

Drs. Phyllis Ackerman and Arthur Pope, renowned art historians, decorated the interior primarily with a bold array of American Indian art of the day. Ansel Adams aptly described the decor as a “miracle of color and design.”

The Ahwahnee dining room represents a particularly grand example of rustic influences, with its massive ceilings and opulent but organic details. To preserve the building’s rich heritage, many recent projects have restored existing features and improved building safety to modern standards.

title: The Ahwahnee Bar
listingDescription: The perfect place to unwind after an exciting day outdoors, the bar offers a relaxing atmosphere as well as outdoor seating with wonderful views of Yosemite National Park.The Ahwahnee Bar offers a cozy place to enjoy a beverage, an appetizer, or a light meal. Open Year-round, see website for hours. Located on the first floor of The Ahwahnee in eastern Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: Person working behind bar with backlit bottles on shelves
images.title: The Ahwahnee Bar
images.caption: The Ahwahnee Bar

bodyText:
The perfect place to unwind after an exciting day outdoors, the bar offers a relaxing atmosphere as well as outdoor seating with wonderful views of Yosemite National Park. The Ahwahnee Bar offers a cozy place to enjoy a beverage, an appetizer, or a light meal.

Hours

Year-round,
See website for hours.

Getting Here

Located on the first floor of The Ahwahnee in eastern Yosemite Valley. The Ahwahnee is also serviced by the Valleywide Shuttle, stop #3.

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all buildings in Yosemite.
  • There are no pets allowed on property.

Accessibility

Valet parking is available, and designated accessible parking spaces are located in the parking lot.
audioDescription: As you walk into The Ahwahnee Bar, the left and right walls are mainly floor-to-ceiling windows with views looking outside. Stone columns are in each corner of the room. The back wall, which contains the entrance to the bar, are three panels of floor-to-ceiling windows, separated by stone columns, with views looking into the hotel lobby. The fourth wall contains the bar. Four stone columns and dark wood paneling cover this wall. The bar has a counter with chairs around it. Behind the bar, four recessed shelves are lined with wine glasses and assorted bottles of liquor and is lit with overhead lighting. Different sized tables are placed throughout the bar, with varied colorfully upholstered chairs in green, red, orange, and blue. Rustic light fixtures with pine trees cut out of them hang from the ceiling.

title: The Ahwahnee Dining Room
listingDescription: With towering 34-foot high ceilings, enormous pine trestles and granite pillars, the chandelier-lit Ahwahnee Dining Room is as spectacular as it is inviting. The Ahwahnee Dining Room offers the finest dining in all of Yosemite National Park and is open year-round. During the fall and winter season, the dining room hosts events such as the Vintners' Holidays, Bracebridge Dinner, and Chefs' Holidays.

images.altText: Tables and people dining in the dining room at The Ahwahnee
images.title: The Ahwahnee Dining Room
images.caption: The Ahwahnee Dining Room

bodyText:
With towering 34-foot high ceilings, enormous pine trestles and granite pillars, the chandelier-lit Ahwahnee Dining Room is as spectacular as it is inviting. The Ahwahnee Dining Room offers the finest dining in all of Yosemite National Park.

As a destination dining spot, The Ahwahnee Dining Room is open year-round to all Yosemite visitors. During the fall and winter season, the dining room hosts events such as the Vintners' Holidays, Bracebridge Dinner, and Chefs' Holidays, so a la carte seating will be limited. During your stay at The Ahwahnee, we strongly recommend that you book all your dining reservations in advance.

To find available dining times, please call us at (209) 372-1489 from 9am to 8pm, or utilize our online booking system .

Dinner Attire

Proper attire is kindly requested for dinner. For dinner, we require gentlemen to wear long pants and a shirt with a collar, and ask that women wear a dress, skirt, or long pants with a blouse. Please refrain from wearing shorts, T-shirts, tank tops, flip-flops, and baseball caps. Children over the age of four are asked to dress for the occasion as well. Breakfast, brunch, and lunch are always casual.

Hours

Year-round
See website for hours.

Getting Here

Located on the first floor of The Ahwahnee in eastern Yosemite Valley. The Ahwahnee is also serviced by the Valleywide Shuttle, stop #3.

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all buildings in Yosemite.
  • There are no pets allowed on property.

Accessibility

Valet parking is available, and designated accessible parking spaces are located in the parking lot.
audioDescription: The Ahwahnee Dining Room is a grand space with towering cathedral ceilings, enormous pine trestles, floor-to-ceiling windows, and granite pillars. Wrought iron Chandeliers, each with 18 candlestick lights, hang from the ceiling in two rows, down the sides of the dining room. Wall sconces, each with five candlestick lights, surround the room. Round tables with white linen tablecloths and high-back dining chairs are placed throughout the room. Native American tapestries hang on the windowless walls and Native American designs are painted along the ceiling border. A black grand piano is placed near the dining room entrance.

title: The Ansel Adams Gallery
listingDescription: Visit The Ansel Adams Gallery to explore the works of Ansel Adams, contemporary artists, or to sign up for half-day photography classes, workshops , or camera walks. From its origin in 1902 in a tent in the California Wilderness, Best's Studio, now operating as The Ansel Adams Gallery, has evolved into a center that celebrates the arts and grandeur of our environment.

images.altText: A single story building with a large covered porch and log details extending at its corners
images.title: The Ansel Adams Gallery
images.caption: The Ansel Adams Gallery

bodyText:
Visit The Ansel Adams Gallery to explore the works of Ansel Adams, contemporary artists, or to sign up for photography classes, workshops, or camera walks. 

From its origin in 1902 in a tent in the California Wilderness, Best's Studio, now operating as The Ansel Adams Gallery, has evolved into a center that celebrates the arts and grandeur of our environment. The Ansel Adams Gallery strives to cultivate aesthetic appreciation and a concern for our natural world by offering visitors a unique variety of handcrafts, books, fine arts, and an extraordinary collection of Ansel Adams original photographs. Welcome!

Photography Education

- Half-day Classes
- Camera Walks

Hours

Year-round: 9 am to 5 pm daily, with extended hours in the summer.
Thanksgiving and Christmas Eve: 10am to 3pm
Christmas Day: Closed

Getting Here

Located in the heart of Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, between the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center and post office, near shuttle stop 5.

Accessibility

The gallery's main floor is accessible by ramp at the front. The upper level is accessible by an outside path (with a short slope of 8 percent) or by steps inside.
audioDescription: The Ansel Adams Gallery is a one-story, light grey building with wooden shingled siding. A covered porch, supported by large beams and posts extends around half the building. Large picture windows showcase the the items inside. Wooden signs cross the top of the entire porch. One sign reads: art, photographs, handcrafts, since 1902, while another reads film processing, gifts, postcards, books, and another reads quality designs, postcards, handcrafts, film, indian arts, posters. Two wooden signs dangle off a large porch beam by chains, and both read The Ansel Adams Gallery. Potted plants line the porch as well as wooden benches. Two sets of steps access the raised porch as well as a ramp on the side of the building.

title: The Ansel Adams Gallery Architecture

images.altText: A single story building with a large covered porch and log details extending at its corners
images.title: The Ansel Adams Gallery
images.caption: The Ansel Adams Gallery

bodyText:
The Ansel Adams Gallery building was constructed in 1925, originally operated as Best’s Studio. The name was changed to its current name in 1972 and is still operated as a family business. Originally a rustic design constructed alongside other village buildings, the studio was significantly modified in 1970.

The addition of the modernist porch and facade mostly obscures the original stone pillars and other rustic details. Though the original character of the building has been obscured, it remains one of the only buildings in Yosemite with both rustic and modernist elements.

title: The Cascades Picnic Area
listingDescription: During the spring, torrents of water from melted snow thunder over a precipice to form The Cascades waterfall. Bring a picnic and enjoy it while listening to the water of The Cascades and the Merced River.Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot near the Cascades waterfall and along the Merced River. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :Located on El Portal Road (Highway 140), between the Arch Rock Entrance and Yosemite Valley. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas

images.altText: A large rock formation rises above the trees that surround a picnic table and fire pit. A rivers' edge is nearby.

bodyText:
During the spring, torrents of water from melted snow thunder over a precipice to form The Cascades waterfall. Bring a picnic and enjoy it while listening to the water of The Cascades and the Merced River.

Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot near the Cascades waterfall and along the Merced River.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
Located on El Portal Road (Highway 140), between the Arch Rock Entrance and Yosemite Valley.

Rules & Regulations:
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings:
For your safety and that of wildlife:
Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Water Safety
Stay back from stream and river banks and avoid "rock hopping."
Supervise children closely when around ALL water.
Melted snow water is cold! Hypothermia can be a serious result of continuous cold water contact.

Accessibility:
The Cascades Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are available nearby.
audioDescription: The paved parking area has a brown wooden structure that holds two vault toilets, a green recycling dumpster, and a brown trash dumpster. A brown, metal sign with a white icon of a picnic table also stands near the parking lot. The sign reads no camping or overnight parking. A path leads to a flat area, dense with tree cover, that has picnic tables and grills spread throughout. The river flows nearby. On the other side of the river, tall rock walls rise above the tree line. Across the street is a waterfall viewing area with a few wayside exhibits.

title: The Loft at Degnan's
listingDescription: The Loft at Degnan's is the perfect place to enjoy Mexican fare, Asian rice bowls, and artisan pizzas. A wide variety of wines and beers on tap are available. The Loft at Degnan's features numerous TVs to enjoy sports and other entertainment. Open year-round, see website for hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village.

images.altText: A brown, A-frame building is surrounded by trees and has two circular signs on the side of the building. One sign reads, The Loft at Degnan's, and the other sign reads Degnan's Kitchen.

bodyText:
The Loft at Degnan's is the perfect place to enjoy Mexican fare, Asian rice bowls, and artisan pizzas. A wide variety of wines and beers on tap are available. The Loft at Degnan's features numerous TVs to enjoy sports and other entertainment.

Hours:
Year-round,
See website for hours.

Getting Here:
Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The Loft is also located at shuttle stop 4 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle route.

Accessibility:
This facility is accessible. There are no designated accessible parking spaces available.
audioDescription: The Loft is located on the second level of a brown, two-story, A-frame building. The restaurant has a cathedral style ceiling, with sky lights and a tall fireplace in the center. Wooden benches are placed around the fireplace. Groups of tables and chairs are laid out across the floor and along two of the four walls.

title: Tioga Pass Entrance
listingDescription: Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park. The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.

images.altText: Small wooden building with a car at the window
images.title: Tioga Pass Entrance Station
images.caption: Tioga Pass Entrance Station

bodyText:
Tioga Road is normally closed from approximately November through May or June. Check road status.

Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park.

The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.

Entrance Fees

(valid for seven days with receipt)

  • Private vehicle: $35 (no per-person fee)
  • Motorcycle: $30 (no per-person fee)
  • Individual (walk-in, bicycle, horse, in a bus): $20 per person, aged 16 or older

Passes

  • Yosemite Pass: $70
    Valid for one year in Yosemite.
  • Interagency Annual Pass: $80
    Valid for one year at all federal recreation sites.
  • Interagency Senior Pass: $80
    (Lifetime) For U.S. citizens or permanent residents 62 and over.
  • Interagency Annual Senior Pass: $20
    For U.S. citizens or permanent residents 62 and over.
  • Interagency Access Pass (Free)
    (Lifetime) For permanently disabled U.S. citizens or permanent residents.
  • Interagency Military Pass (Free)
    (Annual) For active duty U.S. military and dependents.
  • Interagency 4th Grade Pass (Free)
    (Annual) For fourth graders and their families. Must present paper voucher. For paper voucher and more information visit

See website for more details.

Hours

Tioga Road is open to vehicles from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

When Tioga Road is closed, it is not possible to drive to Tuolumne Meadows or enter Yosemite National Park from the east. All other park entrances, including those accessed via Highway 120 from the west, Hetch Hetchy, Highway 140, and Highway 41, remain open all year.

Getting Here

Located on Highway 120 East, about 13 miles from Lee Vining and 62 miles from Yosemite Valley.

Traffic Warnings

From spring through fall, you are likely to experience congestion in Yosemite Valley and at park entrances. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive early in the morning or in the late afternoon to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.
audioDescription: One inbound lane and one outbound lane are on each side of a small wooden kiosk at the Tioga Pass Entrance. The National Park Service logo is placed below the front window on the kiosk. The logo consists of a downward pointing arrowhead, a sequoia tree, a mountain range, a lake, a bison, and text that reads National Park Service. A small triangular sign bolted on to the side of the kiosk, below a service window reads, U.S. Fee Area and has the National Park Service logo. Another sign, posted on the front side of the kiosk reads Tioga Pass, Elevation 9,945 feet. On the right side of the incoming lane, a tall cobblestone pedestal holds a wooden sign that reads Yosemite National Park. A flag pole waving the American Flag is located in front of a cobblestoned building just beyond the entrance sign, along with a bronze plaque that reads, this tablet commemorates the successful labors of Stephen T. Mather, Director of the National Park Service, in securing for the people the Tioga Pass Road, dedicated to the enduring memory of a faithful public servant by members of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle National Park Development Tour, July 20, 1924. On the southside of the road, small lakes, open meadows, and forests stand at the bottom of a few peaks.

title: Tioga Road - Cones and Needles Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands beneath a tall tree.

bodyText: Have you ever wondered how to tell a fir from a pine? Or why you don't really see rattle snakes or giant sequoias at 9,000 feet elevation? Learn more about red firs and Yosemite's life zones and micro-climate at these wayside exhibits.
audioDescription:
This paved roadside turnout is on the west side of Tioga Road and has five wayside exhibits. The area is surrounded by different pine and fir trees and has an open view looking westward.

The first wayside exhibit is titled, Cones and Needles. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, Because of its wide range of elevations, Yosemite encompasses several life zones determined by elevation, moisture, temperature, and exposure to storms. Sometimes, conditions vary significantly within a zone and allow for a micro-climate, a place where the climate contrasts with that of the entire zone. You are in one such micro-climate. Around you, trees that typically grow at higher or lower elevations live in close proximity. Stroll around this area and discover stories of four common Yosemite trees, their relationships with wildlife, and struggles to survive. 

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the right of the first two labels is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). 

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. 

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, cache crop - ever forget where you left your keys? Chipmunks, ground squirrels, and many birds have the same problem. They bury small caches of seeds here and there, and then forget where they put many of these food caches. Consequently, forgetful birds and animals planted many of the trees nearby. 

A series of four photos show different types of trees. 

Photo one is a Red Fir forest, shown with their long branches drooping from the weight of snow that covers them. The trees are tall with pointed tips and reddish bark. 

Photo two is a single Lodgepole Pine, which has a conical shape that tapers, and grey bark. 

Photo three is a single Jeffrey Pine, which has several large branches shooting off a rather bare trunk. Smaller secondary pine branches shoot off the large primary branches. There is no conical shape to this tree, it is randomly fanned out in all directions. 

Photo four is a single Western White Pine, which is a tall, very narrow, slender conical shape, with branches that are arranged in neatly layered horizontal tiers.

The second wayside exhibit is titled, Red Fir, abies magnifica, and has a close-up photo of Red Fir bark on the entire left, one-fifth side of the panel. The bark is reddis-brown and has deep striations. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, the red fir is a spectacular tree, impressive for its height and girth. It can sometimes rise above 200 feet tall, and be nearly 10 feet in diameter. The bark of mature trees is deeply furrowed with a distinctive reddish hue. 

Illustration: A brown pine branch shows green needles that are rounded off at the ends, growing directly out of the branch. A rounded pine cone, which has layers upon layers that closely overlap each other, appears to be closed and smooth. Cone size is 9 inches (23 cm).

Caption: Tree ID hint - How can you tell a fir from a pine? Think "F" for friendly fir. The needles of a fir are soft, and they grow from the branch instead of in bunches. 

When Lightning Strikes - Lightning often hits the tallest of these red firs, leaving snag-topped crowns. These damaged areas provide fertile foraging areas for woodpeckers and sapsuckers looking for grubs. The snags also provide homes for nesting owls and squirrels. 

Illustration: A speckled owl with horn-like pointy ears sits on a snaggled tree trunk that seems to have snapped apart.

The third wayside exhibit is titled, Western White Pine, pinus monticola, and has a close-up photo of Western White Pine bark on the entire left, one-fifth side of the panel. The bark is brown and looks like square plates or bricks that are stacked vertically. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, look beyond the red fir log in front of you. The tree with square-like plates on its bark is the Western White Pine. Their trunks are usually straight, and typically their branches are arranged in neatly layered horizontal tiers. They cannot tolerate deep shade and generally grow in open spaces where they can soak up the rays of the sun. The Western White Pine is a hardy tree, thriving under conditions produced by ground fires that create the ide

title: Tioga Road - Disappearing Meadows Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A stream snakes through a meadow. Pebbles, rocks, and boulders line the bottom and outskirts of the shallow stream. Two mountain peaks rise up above treeline.

bodyText: How and why do we seem to be losing our meadows to trees? Is that a good thing? And, are you in the midst of an ancient volcanic mountain range? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.
audioDescription:
A small, paved, roadside turnout on the south side of Tioga Road has an open view of the area's iconic peaks through meadows with flowing streams. There are also two wayside exhibits and three portable restrooms, one of which is designated accessible. 

On the west side of the driveway, an open meadow that has large boulders scattered about, transitions into a dense pine forest. A wayside exhibit titled, Disappearing Meadow, sits at the edge of the meadow and paved driveway. Text on the left side of the panel reads, as recently as the 1960s, this area was an open wet meadow that dominated the foreground in this view of the Cathedral Range Mountains. However, the meadows are beginning to dry up, providing better conditions for trees to grow. Current science is documenting the increase in Earth's temperature which is advantageous for trees due to longer, warmer growing seasons. While scientists are still investigating other possible reasons for the changes you see, climate change is likely a primary factor. 

Photo: An open meadow has small saplings growing throughout it. In the distance, mountain peaks rise above a line of mature, tall trees. 

Caption: 1963 view of Cathedral Range from this meadow. 

Photo: A small grassy area has a dense stand of pine trees.

Caption: In 2009, young trees dominate the same view. 

Black and white photo: a man, dressed in a long sleeved shirt, long pants, and cap, stands among hundreds of sheep bunched together in a meadow, with tall trees surrounding the open pasture.

Caption: In the late 1800s, cattle ranchers and sheep herders drove their herds into these lush grassy meadows to graze. Human occupation and use increased to accommodate the silver mines established in the Tioga area during the 1870s. These human impacts to vegetation and hydrology may accentuate the effects of climate change. 

On the east side of the driveway, a stream snakes through an open meadow that also transitions into a dense forest. A reddish peak rises on the left while a grey, granite peak rises to the right. A wooden sign by the stream reads, domestic water supply - do not contaminate. A wayside exhibit is also stationed here titled, The Core of Volcanoes. Text on the left side of the panel reads, rising before you are two of the highest peaks in Yosemite, Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs. Their reddish-brown color hints at a different origin than the white granites of the other mountains in the park. The metamorphic rocks forming the summit areas of Mounts Dana and Gibbs are the exposed core of an ancient volcanic mountain range that once graced the Pacific coast. Once miles beneath tall volcanoes, they were slowly revealed as erosion stripped away the overlying rocks. 

Photo: Two peaks rise above a treeline. The silhouette of the two mountain peaks that are labeled Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, is outlined with a red dotted line.

Illustration: The cross-section illustration of the inner and outer workings of a volcano are shown, below and above ground. In the ground, a layer of reddish-orange, oval-like chambers of magma lay horizontally, overlapping and connecting to each other. Thick vein-like paths of magma extend upward through a layer of earth, connecting with the layer of oval chambers above. A small portion of the upper part of the reddish-orange oval chambers is white and is labeled Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, and is noted as crystallizing granite. Above the chambers is a brown area, labeled as metamorphic rock, that slopes up into a peak. A red, thin, vein-like line leads from the magma chambers to the peak and exits as a plume of smoke. Other peaks are in the background.

Caption: Magma, or lava, that erupted at the surface created the reddish-brown metamorphic rock of the volcanoes core. Magma that cooled deep beneath the surface crystalized and formed the white granite of the other peaks and domes you see here.

title: Tioga Road - Form Follows Fracture Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands at a scenic roadside pullout that overlooks the high country landscape.

bodyText: As you drive along the Tioga Road you may notice the granite bedrock is riddled with fractures. You may even see trees taking root in the granite bedrock! How is that possible? Learn more about it at this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
A roadside turnout along Tioga Road gives an open view looking west. The granite bedrock extends for miles, with boulders strewn about, and trees growing out of fractures in the rock. A wayside exhibit titled, Form Follows Fracture, is near the parking area. 

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, the granite bedrock of the Sierra Nevada is riddled with fractures. Major fracture zones dictate where water flows and thus where trees and plants grow. Water in the cracks decomposes the rock and forms soil, creating the conditions for life to grow in this harsh environment. 

Two photos: One photo shows a large mature tree growing out of a granite slab. The second photo shows a one-foot tall sapling growing out of a granite fracture.

Caption: Only the hardiest vegetation is able to grow in this rocky terrain. The Jeffrey pine to your left has two roots growing straight out on either side like a gymnast stretched along a balance beam. 

Photo: An aerial view of a portion of the surrounding terrain, framed in a square, show a squiggly grey line across the top of the square from left to right, and is labeled Tioga Road. Along the Tioga Road, about three-quarters of the way to the right, a red dot indicates, "you are here." The rest of the square is covered with tree canopies, that look like splotchy dark spots, and a web of lines that crisscross each other. A heavy diagonal line that extends downward and slightly to the left from the red dot is labeled Yosemite Creek. 

Caption: This aerial view of the Yosemite Creek drainage shows that the granite is fractured into a network of cracks, or joints, trending in relatively straight lines. These joints result from tectonic stresses associated with uplift of the Sierra Nevada. Linear joints such as these dictate where the major streams flow, and also control the general shape of the landscape.

title: Tioga Road - Glacial Moraine Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands next to a small hillside scattered with different sized boulders.

bodyText: Get a personal glimpse of a glacial moraine and learn how nature shaped Yosemite's mountains and canyons, at this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
A roadside turnout along Tioga Road gives a view of a hill strewn with many different-sized granite boulders, on both sides of the Tioga Road. A wayside exhibit titled, Glacial Moraine, is near the turnout area. 

Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, The hill in front of you is a clue to how nature shaped Yosemite's mountains and canyons. Look over your left shoulder, where the road cuts through the hill. Unlike water-deposited debris, which is layered and sorted by size, this hill is made up of a jumbled mix of sand, gravel, and boulders. Geologists call this deposit a glacial moraine. Material eroded and transported by the Snow Creek Glacier was left here as the glacier receded. Imagine the power it took to move this much earth. 

Photo: A hill along a roadside is covered with many different-sized granite boulders. A red dotted line outlines the entire hill. Many trees grow out from the top of the hill. 

Caption: Where the road cuts through the moraine, you can see the debris left behind by the glacier. 

Illustration: An ice-covered mountainous terrain is shown in a square frame. A few of the peaks popping up over the icefield are Mount Conness in the upper left corner, Mount Dana in the upper right corner, Mount Hoffman, which is midway down and left of center, and Cathedral Peak, which is one-third of the way down and right of center. The majority of the terrain is white, representing the Tuolumne Ice Field, which travels downward and splits into the Tenaya Glacier on the right and the Snow Creek Glacier on the left. Just to the left of the Snow Creek Glacier, near the bottom of the illustration, a red dot indicates, 'you are under here,' and a dotted line represents Tioga Road. 

Caption: Twenty thousand years ago a vast ice sheet covered most of the Tuolumne Meadows area. This ice sheet fed glaciers that flowed east toward Mono Lake, west toward Hetch Hetchy, and southwest toward Yosemite Valley. One of these glaciers, the Snow Creek Glacier, left behind the moraine you see here.

title: Tioga Road - High Sierra Stories Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A meadow surrounds a small lake. A few mountain peaks rise up above the nearby treeline.

bodyText: How do plants and animals survive at the highest elevations in the park? And, how did people travel in this area from hundreds of years ago to today? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.
audioDescription:
This paved parking area allows open views of the high country. A large, open meadow surrounds the parking area. A pond reflects the reddish-brown mountains that are Mount Dana and Mount Gibbs, which rise up over the treeline to the left. To the right, grey granite peaks rise over the treeline in the distance. Large granite boulders are scattered here and there across the flat, open meadow. In the parking lot, a brown sign with a white outline and text reads, no camping or overnight parking. 

The meadow area is roped off from the parking area and two small signs are bolted to knee-height wooden posts. The first sign reads, give plants a chance! Please stay off. An illustration of a foot hovering over small plants is inside a red circle with a diagonal line slashing through its center. The second sign reads, area closed - restoration in progress, Yosemite National Park, and has a silhouette of Half Dome.

Three wayside exhibits line the curb of the parking lot. The first wayside exhibit, located to the far right of the parking area, is titled, Alpine Zone, and has a faint background photo of a large, smooth, granite peak. Text on the left side of the panel reads, you are now near the alpine zone, which includes the highest elevations in Yosemite. Look a few hundred feet higher, and you can see that trees cannot grow because the rugged terrain is windy, dry, and intensely sunlit. To survive such harsh conditions, plants here lie flat against the ground or crouch between stones. Special pigments in their leaves filter out harmful rays of sunlight. Some plants grow in little pincushion-like bunches. If they stand too tall the wind will dry them out or tear them apart. Their vibrant blossoms burst forth in an extra effort to attract insects. 

Illustration: a 3-Dimensional, illustrated, cross-section map of the area's terrain has a road winding through the mountains labeled Tioga Road. Below the Tioga Road, a deep valley is labeled Yosemite Valley. Along Tioga Road, to the far right of the road is a red dot that is marked, 'you are here.' From the front to back of this map, colors transition from orange, to yellow, to green, to blue, to white. On the side of the map, a color-code shows that orange represents the foothills (1,800 to 3,000 feet), yellow represents the lower montane (3,000 to 6,000 feet), green represents the upper montane (6,000 to 8,000 feet), blue represents the sub-alpine (8,000 to 9,500 feet), and white represents the alpine (9,500 - 13,000 feet). 

Caption: As you travel through the different elevations along the Tioga Road, you can observe habitats similar to those found on an excursion from Mexico to the arctic. 

Two photos show two different kinds of wild flowers. The first wildflower is called Davidson's penstemon and is light purple. They are growing in a bunch, out of a crack in a granite rock and are short in stature. Their small flowers are a bit long and flute-like, curving outward at the ends. The second photo shows a wildflower called Sky Pilot, which is purple, and has a spherical bulb of multiple flowers that shoot out of an erect stem. They are growing in a bunch in a rocky area. 

Text on the right side of the panel reads, pikas need to get out of the sun periodically to cool down or they risk lethal overheating. These small mammals live in rock piles at high elevations. They gather plants for winter food in nearby areas, frequently returning to the shade of the rocks. As Earth's temperature warms, they will have to spend more time in the rock piles cooling down. If they have to spend too much time cooling down, they won't be able to harvest enough food to survive the winter. 

Photo: In the bottom right corner, a small, greyish-brown, furry pika faces left and is leaning forward on a rock. It has black beady eyes, large round ears, and long whiskers. 

The second wayside exhibit, located near the middle of the parking area, is titled, High Sierra Stories, and has a faint background photo of a mountain peak that has patches of snow on it. The text reads, these mountains have stories to tell. American Indians have made the journey across the Sierra for thousands of years. Tioga Road existed for decades as a winding, treacherous, single-lane dirt road. Then, in 1961, the National Park Service completed this modern highway which significantly improved visitor access to Tuolumne Meadows and Yosemite Valley. Along this road you will pass countless plants, animals, and evidence of the geologic processes that have shaped the land. 

Illustration: Four adults and three children walk on a path near gnarled trees, walking toward mountainous terrain. Three of the adults carry large, filled, burden baskets on their back. A child uses a walking stick.

Caption: American Indians traveled by foot along this trade route between the east and the west side of the Sierra Nevada. 

Photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads

title: Tioga Road - Meadow Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a roadside pullout.

bodyText: Learn more about the old Mono Trail, a part of a network for American Indian Trade, about the importance of Yosemite's and the Sierra Nevada snow pack, and the history of the Tioga Road, from these wayside exhibits.
audioDescription:
This arched driveway on the south side of Tioga Road has limited, undefined, parking. A green recycle dumpster and brown trash dumpster are located at the east end of the parking area. Trees surround the lot.

Two wayside exhibits stand side by side on the north side of the parking area. The right wayside exhibit is titled Mutual Survival, and has a background photo of a map of central California. Three recognizable areas are labeled, Lake Tahoe, at the top, middle of the panel, San Francisco Bay Area at the left, middle of the panel, and Mono Lake, toward the right middle of the panel. Two large, faint arrows are positioned in a circular way, signifying a counter-clockwise rotation, on the right side of the panel. In the midst of the circular arrows is a map of Yosemite National Park. Panel text reads, Mutual Survival - the Tioga Road follows roughly the same route as the old Mono Trail. This old trail formed the basis of a network for American Indian trade routes leading from the sea to the desert. People on either side of the mountains used this route to negotiate and trade for food items and other materials important to their daily lives. 
Photo Near the San Francisco Bay Area: A string of beads lay on a pink stone, in the sand, next to a seashell.

Caption: Trades from the west bartered with shells and jewelry. 

Photo in the middle of the Central California map: Many acorns are piled up in a basket, and a heap of long sedges is bundled together, laying on its side.

Caption: People in the mountain valleys traded acorns and basket-making materials.

Photo to the upper right of Yosemite National Park: A zoomed-in photo of white granules of salt, and little shrimp swimming bunched together in water. 

Caption: Salt and alkali fly pupa were trade items from the Mono Lake area. 

Illustration to the right of Yosemite National Park and Mono Lake: A black rock with shiny, white edges is shown. 

Caption: Obsidian to make spear and arrow points, knives, and scrapers came from the east. 

The left wayside exhibit is titled, High Sierra Stories, and has a faint background photo of a mountain peak that has patches of snow on it. The text reads, these mountains have stories to tell. American Indians have made the journey across the Sierra for thousands of years. Tioga Road existed for decades as a winding, treacherous, single-lane dirt road. Then, in 1961, the National Park Service completed this modern highway which significantly improved visitor access to Tuolumne Meadows and Yosemite Valley. Along this road you will pass countless plants, animals, and evidence of the geologic processes that have shaped the land. 

Illustration: Four adults and three children walk on a path near gnarled trees, walking toward mountainous terrain. Three of the adults carry large, filled, burden baskets on their back. A child uses a walking stick. 

Caption: American Indians traveled by foot along this trade route between the east and the west side of the Sierra Nevada. 

Photo: A man and two women sit on an open-topped, horse-drawn wagon, on a dirt road that leads through a forest. 

Caption: By the 1890s, horse-drawn wagons followed Indian migration routes. 

Photo: two women stand on a dirt road, next to a soft-top automobile that has two spare tires attached to the rear. 

Caption: Travelers needed spare tires and plenty of gas in the 1920s. 

Photo: Two vintage cars drive side-by-side, taking up the width of the narrow dirt road, while an oncoming car approaches. A large boulder and plenty of trees are right along the roadside. 

Caption: Motorists in the 1940s traveled slowly, navigating a narrow and treacherous dirt road. 

Photo: A bicyclist wearing a helmet rides on a paved road with snowcapped mountains in the background. 

Caption: In 2009, cyclists enjoy a high country biking experience. 

Photo: An older man with a white beard and mustache, a white long-sleeved shirt and black vest, long pants, and a hat, sits horseback, facing to the left. Caption: "...I have crossed the Range of Light, surely the brightest and best of all the Lord has build; and rejoicing in its glory. I gladly, gratefully, hopefully pray I may see it again." - John Muir

The third wayside exhibit is facing the small meadow on the south side of the parking area and is titled, Shrinking Reservoir. The exhibit panel's background photo shows a snow-covered mountain range in the background, and a few building and utility poles on flat terrain in the foreground. Panel text reads, Shrinking Reservoir - The Sierra Nevada is California's reservoir - nature's storage tank of water in the form of winter snow and ice. As the snow gradually melts, it releases the stored water into streams and rivers. The depth of the annual snow pack indicates how much water we will have each year for necessities like drinking water and crop irrigation. In a changing climate, more moisture may come as rain instead of snow. How will it

title: Tioga Road - Surviving the Crossing Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands near a roadside pullout.

bodyText: Who were the first non-Indians to pass through this area, and how did they survive? Learn more from this wayside exhibit.
audioDescription:
A small roadside turnout along the south side of Tioga Road allows for scenic views across the street. A clearing in the trees opens up to panoramic views of rolling hills, looking northward. A wayside exhibit titled, Surviving the Crossing, is on the north side of the parking lot.

The background illustration of the panel shows two men manuevering through a dense forest on horseback. Text reads, in 1833, in a trip that took more than two weeks, Joseph R. Walker led a party of mountain men along a ridge near here. They were the first non-Indians to pass through this area as they crossed the Sierra Nevada. Near starvation they finally found an Indian trail that eventually led them to safety, but not before 24 of their horses succumbed - most of which they had to eat for their own survival. 

Quote: We were then obliged to keep along the top of the dividing ridge between two of these chasms which seemed to lead pretty near in the direction we were going...

...A small deer was the first we had eat since our dried meat was exhausted, during which time we lived on stale and forbidden horse flesh...

-Zenas Leonard, Walker Party

title: Tunnel View
listingDescription: The iconic Tunnel View overlook has captured the awe of visitors for more than 75 years. Tunnel View provides one of the most famous views of Yosemite Valley, showcasing the immensity of the granite walls that surround Yosemite Valley and providing a classic view of El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. It is spectacular at sunset or after the clearing of a storm. Wawona Tunnel The construction of the Wawona Tunnel began on January 30, 19

images.altText: Bright orange wildflowers are at the foreground of a scenic view of Yosemite Valley, with El Capitan to the left of the valley, and Bridalveil Fall to the right.

bodyText:
The iconic Tunnel View overlook has captured the awe of visitors for more than 75 years.

Tunnel View provides one of the most famous views of Yosemite Valley, showcasing the immensity of the granite walls that surround Yosemite Valley and providing a classic view of El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. It is spectacular at sunset or after the clearing of a storm.

Wawona Tunnel
The construction of the Wawona Tunnel began on January 30, 1931, and opened to public travel on June 18, 1933. It took about 230 tons of dynamite to bore through solid granite to create this nearly mile long tunnel. The construction of the Wawona Tunnel is considered significant in its design within the National Park System.

National Register of Historic Places
Wawona Tunnel and Tunnel View were constructed during an era that heralded a boom in design and development throughout the National Park Service, and helped initiate the National Park Service "rustic design style."

Hours:
Year-round


Getting Here:
Located at the east end of the Wawona Tunnel along the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Accessibility:
Designated accessible parking spaces are available and a tactile relief model of Yosemite Valley is present.
audioDescription:
Tunnel View is located on Highway 41, a few miles from Bridalveil Fall. Tunnel View showcases the scenery of Yosemite Valley, with El Capitan to the left of the valley and Bridalveil Fall to the right.

Two wayside exhibits and a bronze relief textile model are located here.

Both wayside exhibits are located to the northeast side of the parking area

Wayside Exhibit Number one:
Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a faint, sepia toned, photo of Yosemite Valley from Valley View. From left to right, the following natural features are labeled, El Capitan, Horsetail Fall, Clouds Rest, which is the furthest peak, in the middle of the photo, then Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, the Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall.

At the top of the panel, the header reads: A Varied View
Text to the right of the header reads:
Whether spring or fall, morning or afternoon, one has the opportunity to experience an ever changing view. In summer, clouds glide amidst granite peaks. Fall splashes autumn hues upon maple and oak trees across the Valley floor. Winter brings snow, accenting the subtle details of granite walls, while spring breathes life back into ephemeral waterfalls and renews the echo of rushing water throughout the Valley.

A sub-header, placed in a light brown bar to the left of the panel reads: Ever-changing Scene
Text reads: In Yosemite, you may never witness the same scene twice.
A quote in italics text reads: This grand show is eternal. It is always sunrise somewhere; the dew is never all dried at once; a shower is forever falling; vapor ever rising. Eternal sunrise, eternal sunset, eternal dawn and gloaming, on seas and continents and islands, each in its turn, as the round earth rolls. - John Muir

Two small black and white photos are located side by side, at the bottom of the panel.

Left photo: A close-up photo of Horsetail Fall shows sparse water, glistening by the sun, falling off the rockface of El Capitan.

Left Photo Caption: Only in spring can you see Horsetail Fall leaping from the east end of El Capitan.

Right photo: A close-up photo of Silver Strand Fall shows sparse water, streaming down in a thin veil to its base.

Right Photo Caption: Also an ephemeral fall, Silver Strand can be found in spring to the southeast of this viewing area.

Wayside Exhibit Number 2:
Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a faint, sepia toned, photo of Yosemite Valley from above Valley View, in the trees. Iconic natural features like El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, and the Cathedral Rocks are shown.

At the top of the panel, the header reads: A View Through Time
Text to the right of the header reads:
From this breathtaking viewpoint into Yosemite Valley, you can see three of its remarkable features: El Capitan, Half Dome, and Bridalveil Fall. In March 1851, a local militia (known as the Mariposa Battalion) was dispatched to the area in search of Miwok people suspected of attacking a trading post. The group stumbled upon this view and became the first Euro-Americans to enter Yosemite Valley.

A sub-header, placed in a light brown bar to the left of the panel reads: A Burning Tradition
Text reads: Miwok people, who called themselves Ahwahneechee, lived in Yosemite Valley for thousands of years. Their traditional practice of regularly burning the meadows and oak woodlands of the Valley contributed to the open landscape first seen by the Mariposa Battalion.

Quote, The whole valley had the appearance of park-like grounds, with trees, shrubbery, flowers and lawns, end-quote. - Lafayette Bunnell, 1880

Two black and white photos are located side by side, at the bottom of the panel.

Left photo: A black and white portrait photo shows an older caucasian man with a beard and long mustache. He is wearing a suit jacket over a white collared shirt with a black neck tab.

Left Photo Caption: Lafayette Bunnell, a member of the Mariposa Battalion, gave names to many of the Valley's prominent rock formations. He later wrote a book about his first impressions of Yosemite Valley.

Right illustration: A pencil drawing of Yosemite Valley shows El Capitan on the left and Bridalveil Fall on the right. In the foreground is a line of tree silhouettes that stretch from the left to the right of the picture.

Right Photo Caption: In this 1855 drawing, Valley from Artist's Point, Thomas Ayres captured the open, park-like nature of Yosemite Valley as it looked in the mid-19th century.

A bronze tactile relief model of Yosemite Valley is located nearby.

title: Tuolumne Grove
listingDescription: Marvel at nearly two dozen mature giant sequoias in the Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias.Begin at Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the Old Big Oak Flat Road-one of the first roads into Yosemite Valley-steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs. The trail drops 500 feet (150 meters) in one mile. The way down can seem much easier than the uphill return to the parking lot. The trip is moderate on the uphill portion. Within the Tuolumne Grove there is an easy, half-

images.altText: A tree that has a tunnel cut out of it is seen among other trees.

bodyText:
Marvel at nearly two dozen mature giant sequoias in the Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias.

Begin at Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the Old Big Oak Flat Road-one of the first roads into Yosemite Valley-steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs. The trail drops 500 feet (150 meters) in one mile. The way down can seem much easier than the uphill return to the parking lot. The trip is moderate on the uphill portion. Within the Tuolumne Grove there is an easy, half-mile, self-guiding nature trail. Parking is limited.

Winter in Tuolumne Grove

Ski or snowshoe touring in Yosemite can be a magnificent experience! The Tuolumne Grove trail descends 500 feet from the trailhead the entire way to the majestic giant sequoias. This is a popular trail both with snowshoers and hikers and is an strenuous uphill return ski.

2.5 miles (4 km) round trip;
500-foot (152 m) elevation gain on return trip. 1-2 hours.

Hours

Year-round. (Expecty snowy and/or icy conditions in winter; skies are snowshoes may be helpful.)

Getting There

The Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias is located on Tioga Road just east of Crane Flat.

Rules & Regulations

Bicycles are not allowed on this trail. Pets are allowed on the paved trail through the grove, but not on the side trails in the grove.

Hazards & Warnings

There is no drinking water at the parking area or in the grove. Be sure to bring drinking water with you.

Accessibility

This trail is not wheelchair accessible.
audioDescription:
A large, paved, parking area is next to a main road and is surrounded by forest. A green recycle dumpster, brown trash dumpster, and a brown facility, which holds four vault toilets, all line the parking lot. Picnic tables, large tree stump seating, and a wayside exhibit panel, framed in log posts, are at the grove trailhead on the north side of the lot, where the paved road trail then leads into the forest.

The green-toned exhibit panel is titled, Welcome to the Tuolumne Grove, and has an illustrated map, which takes up the left side of the panel. The map shows a red dot toward the middle of the map, which is labeled, you are here. A yellow squiggle line, representing the trail, makes its way through a faint canopy of trees upward from the red dot to the sequoia grove. A trail also travels downward from the red dot, leading nowhere specific, and eventually fades out. An aerial view of about 8 bold tree tops are shown at the end of the trail, as well as a tree trunk that has a tunnel through it.

Black and white photo: A sequoia tree trunk, with the upper half of the tree gone, has a tunnel carved out of it.

Caption: The temptation when visiting the Tuolumne Grove is to turn your eyes to the sky line, accessing the superlative qualities of these massive giants. Take a moment along your trip to reflect on the things that can go by unnoticed - the deep silence that accompanies each snow-muffled winter, the moment each spring when the tiny winter wren begins building her nest, the emergence of the white Pacific dogwood petals.

Think also of moments in this grove's recent human history, the jangle of bridles from the first pioneers, pilgrims and discoverers who passed this way, or the rumble of the first automobile engine after the new road was cut. The passage of time through the Tuolumne Grove is marked in small ways, with your experience here being just the most recent.

Map: A generalized map of the entire park, labeled Yosemite National Park, shows the three areas to find sequoia groves in the park. They are indicated by a sequoia tree icon. The Tuolumne Grove and Merced Grove are side by side and located on the left side of the map, about half-way down from the top. The Mariposa Grove is located at the bottom tip of the map.

Text on the right side of the panel reads, one of the three giant sequoia grove in Yosemite National Park, the Tuolumne Grove contains about 25 mature trees. While enjoying your walk through the grove, consider the rarity of this experience. These few maturing giant sequoias appear large and strong but are facing an unknown future. Climate change-and the resulting changes in hydrology and fire regime-may have an effect on the future of giant sequoias. Avoid walking in areas immediately surrounding the trees. Leave cones and other natural items in the grove.

title: Tuolumne Meadows
listingDescription: Visit one of the largest high-elevation meadows in the Sierra Nevada, Tuolumne Meadows, and see the Tuolumne River meandering quietly through its meadow channel against a backdrop of rugged mountain peaks and glacially carved domes. Tuolumne Meadows embodies the high-country of the Sierra Nevada, with its broad sub-alpine meadows and granite domes and peaks.

images.altText: View of alpine meadow and river in Tuolumne Meadows
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows

bodyText:
Visit one of the largest high-elevation meadows in the Sierra Nevada, Tuolumne Meadows, and see the Tuolumne River meandering quietly through its meadow channel against a backdrop of rugged mountain peaks and glacially carved domes.

Tuolumne Meadows embodies the high-country of the Sierra Nevada, with its broad sub-alpine meadows and granite domes and peaks. The Tuolumne River, Lyell Fork, and Dana Fork flow through the vast, colorful meadows bursting with seasonal wildflowers. The meadows are surrounded by stands of western white pine, mountain hemlock, and lodgepole pine.

Popular activities in the area include hiking, rock climbing, backpacking and fishing. A few trails in Tuolumne Meadows include Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge, Elizabeth Lake, Lyell Canyon via the John Muir Trail, Cathedral Lakes, Mono Pass, and Glen Aulin. Nearby Tenaya Lake is a magnificent spot for picnicking, swimming and canoeing.

Hours

Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here

Located along Tioga Road, approximately 8 miles west of the Tioga Pass Entrance and 55 miles from Yosemite Valley.

Rules & Regulations

  • Stay on official trails to protect fragile meadow ecosystems.
  • Dogs, bicycles, and strollers are only allowed on roads that are open to public vehicle traffic.
  • Day-hikers and backpackers must go to the bathroom at least 100 feet away from water, trail and camp areas; bury human waste six inches deep and pack out toilet paper and all other trash.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Stay off domes during thunderstorms!
  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.

Accessibility

Visit the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center to request an accessibility guide.
audioDescription: A large open meadow, Tuolumne Meadows, is surrounded by forest and granite peaks and domes. In the summer, the grasses are a vibrant green, speckled with multi-colored wildflowers. The sparkling waters of a narrow river, the Tuolumne River, snakes through the center of the meadow. Dirt trails are laid out throughout the area, leading to wilderness areas. A paved road, Tioga Road, lines the southern edge of the meadow. The summer months bring clear sunny days and overcast days with thick, dark, billowy, thunderhead clouds.

passportStampImages.altText: A green circular stamp has text that reads Yosemite National Park, Tuolumne Meadows, CA
passportStampImages.title: Tuolumne Meadows Passport Stamp

title: Tuolumne Meadows Grill
listingDescription: After a day of hiking the miles of trails near Tuolumne Meadows, hungry adventurers enjoy hot meals at the Tuolumne Meadows Grill. Breakfast and lunch items are served with vegetarian options. Hamburgers, hot dogs, fries, chili and more, are offered daily. The grill is located along Tioga Road, approximately a half mile east of the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center.

images.altText: Interior counters and ordering station of the Tuolumne Meadows Grill
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows Grill
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows Grill

bodyText:
The Tuolumne Meadows Grill is closed for 2022.

After a day of hiking the miles of trails near Tuolumne Meadows, hungry adventurers enjoy hot meals at the Tuolumne Meadows Grill.

Breakfast and lunch items are served with vegetarian options. Hamburgers, hot dogs, fries, chili and more, are offered daily.

Hours

Mid-June through late September (dates vary depending on the opening of the Tioga Road)

See website for hours

Getting Here

Located along Tioga Road, approximately a half mile east of the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center.

Rules & Regulations

Human food is not healthy for wild animals, and it is illegal to feed any animal in the park.

Accessibility

This facility is accessible. Designated parking spaces are available nearby.
audioDescription: The Tuolumne Meadows Grill is on the right end of a long white building that consists of, from left to right, a store, post office, and grill. The building is a wooden frame structure with canvas roofing and siding. A roofed porch extends from the entrance of the grill, across the structure, to the entrance of the store. A sign in the small square window to the right of the double-door entrance reads, no smoking within 25 feet of building. Above the window is a large white sign with a green border and text. It reads, Tuolumne Meadows Grill - breakfast, hamburgers, and frosties. Above the entrance, a small white sign reads, welcome to Tuolumne Meadows Grill. A bench, brown trash bins, a blue mail box, and a corkboard attached to the side of the building, are all located under the porch. A parking lot lines the front side of the building. A few picnic tables are to the right of the building, and a small white structure, which holds the restrooms.

title: Tuolumne Meadows Lodge
listingDescription: Situated next to the Tuolumne River, this is the perfect place to settle in after hiking in Yosemite-or before embarking on an extended backpacking trip.

images.altText: Entrance and sign for Tuolumne Meadows Lodge
images.title: Tuolumne Meadows Lodge
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows Lodge

bodyText:
The Tuolumne Meadows Lodge is closed for 2022.
