Situated next to the Tuolumne River, this is the perfect place to settle in after hiking in Yosemite-or before embarking on an extended backpacking trip.

Tuolumne Meadows Lodge features 69 canvas-tent cabins, each accommodating up to 4 guests. In keeping with the spirit of camping, there's no electricity, televisions, or phones. Showers (for guests only) and restrooms can be found conveniently in the center of the camp.

Meals at Tuolumne Meadows are served in the riverside dining tent, with a plentiful breakfast spread and dinner that's sure to fill even the hungriest hiker. Box lunches are available, and can be ordered for the next day. Dinner reservations are required, and can be made by calling 209/372-8413 before you arrive. See latest Yosemite Guide for current hours.

See website for more information about the cabins, to check availability, to book a room, and to get an idea of what to bring, and what to do in the Tuolumne Meadows area.

Things to Do

Ranger-led campfire programs and guided hikes are offered throughout the summer in the Tuolumne Meadows area. See the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for a programs schedule and for dining hours.

Transportation

There is a Tuolumne Meadows Hikers Bus with service between Tuolumne Meadows and Yosemite Valley. See website for more information.

YARTS also services the Tuolumne Meadows area on its Hwy 120/395 bus route that connects Yosemite Valley with Tuolumne Meadows and Mammoth Lakes. See website for more information.

Hours

The Tuolumne Meadows Lodge is open approximately early July to mid-September.
The front desk is generally staffed from 7am to 9pm, daily.

Check-in: 4 pm
Check-out: 11 am

Getting Here

Located along Tioga Road, approximately 55 miles from Yosemite Valley.

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all accommodations and buildings in Yosemite.
  • There are no pets allowed on property.
  • Bear-proof storage lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash.
  • To help keep wildlife wild, cooking isn't permitted inside or outside your tent cabin.

Hazards & Warnings

You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.
audioDescription: A large parking lot surrounded by tall trees has four long rows of parking. Multiple food storage lockers line the entire north side of the parking area. At the northeast end of the lot are luggage carts, that are like wheelbarrows, corralled and stacked side by side. Canvas-tent cabins that have metal-frames and cement platforms, are scattered throughout the trees, some with smoke stacks coming out the back side. At the southeast corner of the parking lot is a path that leads to the Tuolumne Meadows Lodge entrance.

title: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead
listingDescription: A steep climb is well rewarded with close-up views of Upper Yosemite Fall and distant views of Half Dome and other Sierra peaks. Along the hike, enjoy a bird's eye view of Yosemite Valley's meadows and the meandering Merced River. Enjoy the views from Columbia Rock, located one mile (and dozens of switchbacks) from the trailhead. The Yosemite Falls Trail is one of Yosemite's oldest historic trails, built 1873 to 1877.

images.altText: Wooden sign at trailhead
images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead

bodyText:
Overview

One of Yosemite's oldest historic trails (built 1873 to 1877), the Yosemite Falls Trail leads to the top of North America’s tallest waterfall, which rises 2,425 feet (739 m) above the Valley floor. This trail starts near Camp 4, along the Valley Loop Trail, and immediately begins its climb, switchback after switchback, through oak woodland. You will begin to climb above some trees and into exposed plateaus that offer you a glimpse of what's to come: great views of Yosemite Valley and its many iconic landforms. Do not stray off of the maintained path, as you will find steep drops adjacent to the trail.

If you make the one-mile, 1,000 foot climb (via dozens of switchbacks) to Columbia Rock, you will be rewarded with spectacular views of Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, and Sentinel Rock. From there, it is worth the time and energy to hike another 0.5 miles (0.8 km) (some of which is actually downhill!) to get a stunning view of Upper Yosemite Fall. Depending on the season, you may even feel the mist from the fall, which may be welcome respite after the tough climb.

The upper half of the trail is steep and rocky, but the arduous climb is well worth the amazing views you will be rewarded with at the top. Here you may be surprised by the small size of Yosemite Creek, which feeds this massive waterfall. Use extreme caution when near the creek and remember you are directly above a waterfall.

Columbia Rock

Distance: 2 miles (3.2 km) round trip
Elevation: 1,000 ft (328 m) elevation gain
Difficulty: Moderate
Time: 2-3 hours round trip
Begin at: Camp 4 area (near shuttle stop #7)

Top of Yosemite Falls

Distance: 7.2 miles (11.6 km) round trip
Elevation: 2,700 ft (823 m) elevation gain
Difficulty: Strenuous
Time: 6-8 hours round trip
Begin at: Camp 4 area (near shuttle stop #7)

Hours

Year-round.

The Yosemite Falls Trail is open year-round; conditions vary depending on the season. In spring, when the waterfall is at its peak, this hike is stunning, and you may even get wet from the spray of the waterfall during a section of the hike. In summer, conditions are hot and dry, and the loose decomposed granite along the trail can be slippery. Keep in mind that by August, the water levels are low and you may only see a trickle here. During winter, the lower portion of this trail gets direct sunlight, so hiking can be snow-free while other trails are icy. Visiting Columbia Rock, located one mile up the trail, is a worthwhile trip at any time of year. The upper portion of this trail, which receives little to no sunlight in winter, can be very icy and slippery, or buried beneath feet of snow, making traction difficult. In winter, hiking in the colder early morning or late afternoon hours can be even more dangerous if the trail is icy.

Getting Here

Begin at the Yosemite Falls Trailhead, beyond the Camp 4 parking lot (Yosemite Valleywide shuttle stop #7)

Rules & Regulations

  • Pets and bicycles are only permitted on paved bike paths.
  • Pack out what you pack in.
  • Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center.
  • Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Wading and/or swimming upstream from waterfalls is extremely dangerous. Each year, unsuspecting visitors drown or are swept over to their deaths.
  • Stay on trails: taking shortcuts causes trail erosion-and is both dangerous and illegal.
  • Carry (and drink) plenty of water: Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
  • Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.
  • Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
  • Rocks in and around waterways are often slippery. Use caution when crossing streams.
  • During winter, the upper portion of this trail, which receives little to no sunlight, can be very icy and slippery, or buried beneath feet of snow, making traction difficult.

Accessibility

This trailhead and associated trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
The trailhead for the Yosemite Falls Trail is marked by a wooden sign that reads Yosemite Falls Trail, Top Yosemite Fall, 3.4 miles, Yosemite Point, 4.2 miles, Eagle Peak, 6 miles, North Dome, 7.9 miles. Dangerous to stray from trail. Horses not permitted off valley floor without guide.

The area is surrounded by forest and rugged terrain. The trail is a rocky path that starts immediately ascending. Fallen logs and boulders are strewn about.

title: Valley Shuttle Stop #10: Cathedral Beach Picnic Area (Valleywide Shuttle)
listingDescription: When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free Yosemite Valley shuttle system. Our eco-friendly shuttles will take you throughout Yosemite Valley. The Valleywide shuttle serves all stops in Yosemite Valley, including lodges, food service, campgrounds, and trailheads. Buses arrive every 12 to 22 minutes (depending on conditions) during hours of operation. You can get off and on the shuttle wherever and whenever you wish.

bodyText:
When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free Yosemite Valley shuttle system. Our eco-friendly shuttles will take you throughout Yosemite Valley.

Stop #10: Cathedral Beach Picnic Area (Valleywide Shuttle)

  • Picnic/viewing areas
  • River access
  • Trail access

Hours

7 am to 10 pm

Getting Here

Valleywide Shuttle Stop #10 is located on Southside Drive, several miles east of Bridalveil Fall.

Rules & Regulations

  • Allow wheelchairs to board first
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated
  • Board shuttles using the front doors ONLY, and exit through the rear doors
  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops
  • No pets
  • No food or drink
  • No smoking

Hazards & Warnings

In case of emergency, alert the shuttle driver or park staff.

Accessibility

All buses are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttle buses is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Bus drivers will help passengers on and off buses or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the bus driver.
audioDescription: The area is dense with trees, however, the tall, granite, Valley cliffsides are still visible through breaks in the trees and above the tree line. Across the street, a dirt road leads down a slight hill to the Cathedral Beach Picnic Area. Near the picnic area entrance, two brown signs read, No camping or overnight parking, and picnic area closes at dusk. A trail crosses the road near this area. The trail leads toward Yosemite Valley or in the opposite direction, toward El Capitan.

audioDescription:
Nearby, a brown sign reads, Four Mile Trail, and has an icon of a hiker inside a square outline and an arrow pointing to the right, next to the roadside parking area, that has limited parking. A noticeable dirt trail starts to retreat into the woods from here. Two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, and a way side exhibit are in this area. Before entering the forest and starting the ascent, a wooden sign is posted and reads, Glacier Point Four Mile Trail; Union Point - 3.0 miles, Glacier Point - 4.6 miles, Sentinel Dome - 5.2 miles. Dangerous to stray from trail. Horses not permitted off valley floor without guide.

The wayside exhibit near the road is titled, Paths Into Wilderness, and has a faint, sepia-toned photograph of fourteen or more men, sitting on both sides of a log that has been halved and is set for a meal. . The caption reads, trail crew stops for dinner. Panel text reads, James McCauley, an Irish immigrant and proprietor of the Glacier Point Hotel, hired John Conway to survey and construct a trail from Yosemite Valley to Glacier Point. Taking only seven months to build, it was completed in the early summer of 1872. The original trail was four miles long and travelers paid a $1 toll. In the 1920s, the National Park Service lengthened the trail to improve the steeper sections. Today it is 4.6 miles from the Valley to Glacier Point.

Black and white photo: One of Yosemite Valley's high, 2,000-foot plus rock walls has a noticeable trail zigzagging its way to the top.

Caption: "...it is the steepest trail out of the valley, zigzagging back and forth a sheer granite wall, one rides up it with little alarm or giddiness." - Helen Hunt Jackson, from Ah-Wah-Ne Days: A visit to Yosemite Valley in 1872. Under a heading that reads, Conway - A "Walkist", panel text quotes an 1869 article in the Mariposa Gazette, "John Conway of Sherlock Creek, last Saturday walked from the Sentinel Hotel, Yosemite Valley, to Mariposa in fourteen hours, including all stoppages. He left the hotel about seven o'clock in the morning and made the trip to town by nine o'clock the same evening. The walk did not seem to fatiguw him much, for he soon left town for his home on Sherlock Creek, six miles farther. Mr. Conway says it is no trip at all for him on foot." Black and white photo: Two older men stand side by side. The man to the right is wearing a hat, has a mustache and long white bear, and is wearing a black suit with a white collared button-down shirt. He is standing with his hands on his hips, looking off into the distance to the right. The other man is dressed similarly and has a mustache and long grey beard. He is standing with his hands down by his side, gazing to the right. Caption: John Conway, on right, shown here with Galen Clark, used only a simple ship's protractor to survey the Four Mile Trail's route.

title: Valley Shuttle Stop #12: Housekeeping Camp and Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center (Valleywide and East Valley Shuttles)
listingDescription: When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free shuttle system. The Valleywide shuttle serves all stops in Yosemite Valley, including lodges, food service, campgrounds, and trailheads. Buses arrive every 12 to 22 minutes. The East Valley shuttle is limited to Yosemite Village, Curry Village, Pines Campgrounds, and trailheads in eastern Yosemite Valley. Buses arrive every 8 to 12 minutes. This stop is part of both routes.

East Valley Shuttles)

Hours

Getting Here

Rules & Regulations

  • Allow wheelchairs to board first
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated
  • Board shuttles using the front doors ONLY, and exit through the rear doors
  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops

audioDescription:
A green and white shuttle stop sign stands near the curb of a roadside turnout along the right side of the one-way road leading into Yosemite Valley. The sign reads, Valley Shuttle, Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center/Housekeeping Camp, and has the number 12 in white font, in a green circle. The area is dense with trees, however, the tall, granite, Valley cliffsides are still visible through and above the tree line. A covered shelter made with wooden beams and a shingled roof, both house two wooden benches.

Nearby, a stone building with a steep-pitched roof and a color, texture, and verticality that blends with the Yosemite Valley walls stands. The center section of the building rises up to a steep point, and two smaller wings are built slightly inward on each side. A stonewall extends off the ends of each wing, slanted inward as well, creating a hexagonal structural layout. Steps lead to the center of the hexagonal layout, a small porch area, then up to the front, wooden, pointed arched, door. Four windows line the front side of the building. At the end of the right stone porch wall, a bronze plaque is adhered to the granite, and it reads, LeConte Memorial Lodge has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America. 1987. National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior.

images.caption: Valley Shuttle Stop #16: Happy Isles

bodyText:
When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free Yosemite Valley shuttle system. Our eco-friendly shuttles will take you throughout Yosemite Valley.

The Valleywide shuttle serves all stops in Yosemite Valley, including lodges, food service, campgrounds, and trailheads. Buses arrive every 12 to 22 minutes during hours of operation. The East Valley shuttle is limited to Yosemite Village, Curry Village, Pines Campgrounds, and trailheads in eastern Yosemite Valley. Buses arrive every 8 to 12 minutes during hours of operation. This stop is part of both routes.

Stop #16: Happy Isles
(Valleywide Shuttle and
East Valley Shuttles)

  • Happy Isles Art and Nature Center
  • Trailhead for John Muir Trail/Mist Trail
  • Restrooms
  • Water fountain

Hours

7 am to 10 pm

Getting Here

Shuttle stop 16 is located on the eastern side of Yosemite Valley, along the Happy Isles loop, an area only accessible by shuttle bus or vehicles displaying a disability placard.

Rules & Regulations

  • Allow wheelchairs to board first
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated
  • Board shuttles using the front doors ONLY, and exit through the rear doors
  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops
  • No pets
  • No food or drink
  • No smoking

Hazards & Warnings

In case of emergency, alert the shuttle driver or park staff.

Accessibility

All buses are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttle buses is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Bus drivers will help passengers on and off buses or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the bus driver.
audioDescription: A sign stands next to the roadside turn-out where the shuttle bus stops. Next to the sign is a wooden shelter that holds two benches. A yellow chain barrier is set up to help queue the line. Behind the shelter is a small wooden building, which is the restroom. A brown trash bin, a green recycle bin, and a drinking fountain are near the restroom facility. Up the road is a bridge, which leads to the Mist Trail and John Muir Trail.

audioDescription:
A green and white sign stands next to the roadside turnout where the shuttle bus stops. The sign is white with a green bar across the top. Within the green bar, text reads, Valley shuttle and has an icon of a bus. Below the green bar, text reads Mirror Lake Trailhead, and the number 17 is in white font within a green circle. Next to the sign is a wooden shelter that holds two benches. A yellow chain barrier is set up to help queue the line. A brown trash bin, a green recycle bin, and a sign that has three small panels across the top and a large map on the bottom, are near the shuttle stop shelter. A paved path/road retreats into the trees behind the shelter.

The first panel of the sign is yellow with a green bar across the top. Text in the green bar reads, shuttle bus schedule. The text in the yellow section reads, shuttle stop 17, Mirror Lake. From 7am to 10am, service every 30 minutes. From 10am to 7pm, service every 20 minutes. From 7pm to 10pm, service every 30 minutes.

The second panel is white with a blue bar across the top. Text in the blue bar reads, Did You Know? Text in the white section reads, Mirror Lake is not really a lake at all. Until the middle of the 20th century, park personnel dredged sand to maintain a pond that reflected the cliffs above. Current park policy is to let the natural succession of pond to meadow occur. During high water, however, you can still see a stunning reflection of Half Dome.

Photo: One person stands in ankle-deep snow, with a backpack on the ground by his side, and his back turned from the camera. He is facing a small body of water and the large face of Half Dome which towers over this lake. Snow covers the landscape.

Caption: At Half Dome's base, Mirror Lake forms in winter and spring, but is more of a sandy beach during the dry season. NPS photo by Erik Skindrud.

The third panel is white with an orange bar across the top. Text in the orange bar reads, Be Bear Aware. Text in the white box reads, Keeping bears away from your food isn't just a way to avoid a fine-it could save a bear's life. Do not store food in vehicles after dark. When not stored in a locker or cabin, food must be within arm's length. Stay at least 50 yards from a bear. If a bear approaches, yell to scare it away.

Photo: A reddish-brown black bear with yellow plastic tags on both ears, is hanging halfway out of a parked car's side door window. The door frame is bent half way down, the side view mirror is dangling, and the glass has been busted out. It is dark out.

Caption: Bear break-ins can cost thousands of dollars and put visitors and bears at risk. NPS photo by Tammy Evans.

A large map showing three different shuttle routes in Yosemite Valley is below. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

A row of baby giant sequoias line the south end of the parking lot while Ponderosa Pines and Cedar trees line the rest of the parking lot. The display is made up of three small text panels that are lined up on top of a large map.

audioDescription:
A green and white sign reads: Valley Shuttle, Lower Yosemite Fall. There is a bus stop shelter made with six large cobblestone posts, wooden beams, and it has a wooden roof. There is a bronze relief plaque of Yosemite Falls on the outer northeast corner post. Split logs serve as benches nearby. In front of the bus stop sign is a crosswalk that leads across the street into Cook's meadow. Also, the accessible trail to Lower Yosemite Fall begins north of the shuttle stop. Limited roadside parking is located east of shuttle stop six. Near the bus stop shelter is a large map of trails. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035. The map header reads Welcome to Yosemite Falls. On the side of the large map is a smaller header that reads: About Yosemite Falls A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Heights of the Falls
The text reads: Upper Fall, 1,430 feet, 435 meters, Middle Cascades, 675 feet, 205 meters, 320 feet, 98 meters, 2,425 feet, 740 meters.

Photo, located to the left of the above text, shows an aerial sepia-toned photo of Yosemite Falls, and labels each part of the Falls, Upper Fall, Middle Cascades, and Lower Fall.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: World Ranking
The text reads: Yosemite Falls is the tallest waterfall in the United States, and the 5th tallest waterfall in the world. The tallest is Salto Angel in Venezuela at 3,212 feet, 979 meters.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Source of the Falls
The text reads: Yosemite Creek, which flows over this waterfall, is entirely fed by melting snow. It drains an area of nearly 50 square miles. At its peak volume in late spring, 2,400 gallons per second, or 9,000 liters, flow over the lip of the Upper Fall. Every summer, when the snow from this drainage is entirely melted, Yosemite Falls usually run dry.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Ice Cone
The text reads: In winter, a dramatic cone of ice accumulates at the base of the Upper Fall. The maximum height of the cone is documented at 322 feet, about as tall as a 25 story building. When temperatures warm up in early spring, the water from the fall begins to drill a hole at the top of the cone, creating a volcano-like structure, and by mid-April, most of the cone has melted.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Moonbow
The text reads: The full moon in April and May offers a special treat at the base of Lower Yosemite Fall. As the moon rises, the light is captured and refracted in the massive spray of the fall, creating a phenomenon called a moonbow.

A sub-header in a brown bar reads: Frazil Ice
The text reads: In early spring, frazil ice sometimes forms in waterfalls and creeks when water becomes super cooled by turbulence. Ice crystals form and group into spongy masses which sometimes overflow the creek bed. In 1997 frazil ice was above the railings of the Lower Yosemite Fall bridge, almost completely burying it!

Quote: When the afternoon sunshine is streaming through the throng of comets, ever wasting, ever renewed, the marvelous fineness, firmness and variety of their forms are beautifully revealed. - John Muir

All buses are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttle buses is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Bus drivers will help passengers on and off buses or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the bus driver.
audioDescription: Trees line the road and frame a distant view of Upper Yosemite Fall. A bench and an informational display containing a map are near the shuttle stop sign.

audioDescription: Vallewide shuttle stop #9 is located on a side road that makes a half circle through the El Capitan Picnic Area, just off Northside Drive, near El Capitan. There is a designated entrance to the road that then travels clockwise to the parking area and then to the designated exit. Shuttle stop #9 is located in the picnic area parking lot, on the right side of the road. Picnic tables and accompanying grills are randomly scattered through this forested area. To the left of the road, there is a vault toilet, trash and recycle receptacles, and food lockers. El Capitan and other nearby rocks tower over the treeline. Climbers are sometime seen on these portions of exposed rocks.

title: Valley View
listingDescription: Catch a glimpse of past glaciers' exposed handiwork from Valley View, a view that highlights El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. Valley View is a remarkable spot to soak in some of Yosemite Valley's unbelievably scenic charm. Although glaciers ended their work carving out Yosemite Valley over 14,000 years ago, the Merced River continues to shape this valley, making Yosemite a very dynamic place.

images.altText: View of El Capitan on the left, the river in the foreground, and Bridalveil Fall on the right
images.title: Valley View
images.caption: Valley View showing El Capitan, the Merced River, and Bridalveil Fall.

bodyText:
Catch a glimpse of past glaciers' exposed handiwork from Valley View, a view that highlights El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall.

Valley View is a remarkable spot to soak in some of Yosemite Valley's unbelievably scenic charm.

Although glaciers ended their work carving out Yosemite Valley over 14,000 years ago, the Merced River continues to shape this valley, making Yosemite a very dynamic place. In January 1997, floodwaters spilled over into the parking lot here, up to a depth of 6 feet!

Hours

Year-round

Getting Here

Located on Northside Drive, near the west end of Yosemite Valley.

Rules & Regulations

Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.

Hazards & Warnings

  • Stay back from the river banks and avoid "rock hopping" around swift water, especially in the spring.
  • Supervise children closely when around ALL water.
  • Melted snow water is cold! Hypothermia can be a serious result of continuous cold water contact.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces available.
audioDescription:
Valley View is located along the left side of Northside drive, as you're about to exit Yosemite Valley. Valley View is next to the river, and showcases the scenery of Yosemite Valley, with El Capitan to the left of the valley and Bridalveil Fall to the right.

A wayside exhibit is located next to the Valley View parking area.

Photo: The background of this wayside panel is a faint, sepia toned, photo of Yosemite Valley from Valley View. El Capitan is on the left, while Sentinel Rock, the Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall are on the left side of the panel.

At the top of the panel, the header reads: The Power of Glaciers.
Text to the right of the header reads:
Following the ancient river channel, a series of glaciers shaped this canyon. When the glaciers melted, they left behind piles of rocks that had been plucked from the cliff walls and carried along in the river of ice. These piles are called moraines. The moraine left behind following the most recent glacial activity dammed the Merced River near Bridalveil Fall. As the glacier melted, a shallow lake formed which eventually filled in with small rocks and sediment. This accounts for the flat valley floor we see today.

A sub-header, placed in a light brown bar to the left of the panel reads: An Everchanging Landscape
Text reads: Although glaciers ended their work here over 14,000 years ago, Yosemite remains a dynamic place. The Merced River continues to shape this valley. On January 2, 1997, floodwaters covered the parking lot here to a depth of 6 feet.

Two small, square, black and white illustrations are located beneath the text.

Photo 1: An aerial view looking into Yosemite Valley shows a glacier that starts in Yosemite's backcountry, moving forward past Half Dome, and ending just after El Capitan and Bridalveil Fall. The glacial ice rise about halfway up the Valley walls.

Photo 1 Caption Header: 30,000 years ago
Photo 1 Caption Text: The last glacier to flow through Yosemite Valley was at its peak. As you can see at the bottom of this illustration, the moraine forms a low ridge at Bridalveil Fall.

Photo 2: An aerial view looking into Yosemite Valley shows the steep walls of Yosemite Valley, with a lake that ends near El Capitan and Bridalveil Fall.

Photo 2 Caption Header: 10,000 years ago
Photo 2 Caption Text: A shallow lake was created by the moraine left behind when the glacier receded.

To the west of the parking lot is a sign that stands over six feet high. The sign reads: Flood Water Level, 11:00pm., January 2, 1997, and has a double sided arrow extending from left to right.

title: Village Grill
listingDescription: Dine al fresco at the Village Grill, which features outside seating on an expansive deck. Grilled sandwiches, burgers, hot dogs, and veggie options are available daily. Open March - October, see website for hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The Village Grill Deck is also located at shuttle stops #2 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle route.

images.altText: People eating at outdoor seating with umbrellas on the deck of the grill
images.title: Village Grill
images.caption: Village Grill

bodyText:
Open seasonlly, you can dine al fresco at the Village Grill, which features outside seating on an expansive deck. Grilled sandwiches, burgers, hot dogs, and veggie options are available. 

Hours

March - October
See website for hours.

Getting Here

Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The Village Grill Deck is also located at shuttle stop #2 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle route.

Rules & Regulations

Human food is not healthy for wild animals, and it is illegal to feed any animal in the park.

Accessibility

This outdoor deck and facility are accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in the Village Store 30-minute Parking Area.
audioDescription: The Village Grill is located on the side of a brown wooden building that also houses the Village Store. An open doorway with a sign that reads Enter is on the right, while another open doorway, with a sign that reads exit, is on the left. All the seating is outside. Circular and rectangular picnic tables with green umbrellas are randomly placed on the paved deck. A few sets of trash and recycle bins are against the fence that lines the deck.

title: Village Store
listingDescription: If you left something behind, or just need to stock up, we have everything you need at the Village Store.The Village Store has all the essentials you need - including groceries, meat and produce, baked goods, camping supplies, books, magazines, postcards, ice and firewood. There's also an ATM in the store. Additionally, you'll find all the souvenirs, T-shirts, sweatshirts and hats you could ever want-perfect for gifts or commemorating your Yosemite experience. Hours :Year-rou

images.altText: A pedestrian walkway leads to a covered entry of a building, a sign reads "Village Store"
images.title: Village Store
images.caption: Village Store

bodyText:
If you left something behind, or just need to stock up, we have everything you need at the Village Store.

The Village Store has all the essentials you need - including groceries, meat and produce, baked goods, camping supplies, books, magazines, postcards, ice and firewood. There's also an ATM in the store. Additionally, you'll find all the souvenirs, T-shirts, sweatshirts and hats you could ever want-perfect for gifts or commemorating your Yosemite experience.

Hours

Year-round
See website for hours.

Getting Here

Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The Village Store is also located at shuttle stop 2 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle route.

Accessibility

This facility is accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby.
audioDescription: The Village Store is located in a brown wooden single-story building that also houses the Village Grill. The front and rear entrances of the Village Store have high pitched rooves held up by tall wooden posts. A large sign reads Village Store in the center of the porch. Three vending machines, a penny press machine, and a large touch screen information kiosk line the front of the building, to the right of the entrance. There are two rows of windows above the entrance and vending machines. The lower row of windows have pictures that correspond to the text, from left to right, the text reads Trail Rides, Biking, Tours, Bracebridge Dinner, Rafting, and HIking. The back entrance has a large touch screen information kiosk, a penny press machine, one vending machine, three pay phones, six newspaper vending machines, two trash bins, a drinking fountain, and two rows of grocery carts nearby.

title: Village Store 30-Minute Parking
listingDescription: Park in this 30-minute parking area to grab something you may have left behind, or just need to stock up on, at the Village Store. Open year-round, during store hours. See website for store hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking.

images.altText: Cars in a full parking lot, with Yosemite Falls in background
images.title: 30-minute Village Store Parking
images.caption: 30-minute Village Store Parking

bodyText:
Park in this 30-minute parking area to grab something you may have left behind, or just need to stock up on, at the Village Store.

Hours

Year-round, open during store hours.
See website for store hours.

Getting Here

Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village.

Rules & Regulations

You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces near the entrance to the Village Store and near the path to the Village Grill Deck.
audioDescription: The Village Store Parking lot is a paved lot located directly behind the Village Store's brown wooden building. A white sign at the entrance of the lot reads 30 minute parking, 8am to 8pm. The lot overflows into a second lot, that is separated by a stand of trees. Tall trees encase the lot and Yosemite Valley's granite walls rise above the treeline.

title: Village Store Complex Architecture

images.altText: A pedestrian walkway leads to a covered entry of a building, a sign reads "Village Store"
images.title: Village Store: western aspect
images.caption: Village Store: western aspect

bodyText:
This large, multi-purpose building has served a variety of functions since its construction. Upon opening, it included a dining room and fountain, grocery, barbershop, beauty parlor, restrooms, and shoe repair shop.

The western pedestrian entrance to the store was originally the primary entrance, featuring a wide bridge over a series of ponds. The exterior of the building throughout incorporates wood soffits and structural elements that impart an organic feel.

The south face showcases the building’s most distinctly Modern feature: a dramatic triangular face with floor-to-ceiling windows and a sloped roof. When first constructed, this section of the building served as a dining room for the restaurant at the time. In the 1970s, the dining room became a retail space, serving as the Village Sport Shop until 2016. After a period of vacancy, the National Park Service renovated both the indoor space and adjacent outdoor plaza to serve as the Yosemite Valley Welcome Center, which opened in 2023.

title: Wagon Shed
listingDescription: Horse-drawn stages were the practical way for visitors to experience the Yosemite, long before automobiles entered the park. Several stages from Yosemite's past are parked in this wagon shed, iconic symbols of the park's history of transportation.

images.altText: Old, red wagons are lined up in this shed that is open for public viewing.

bodyText: Horse-drawn stages were the practical way for visitors to experience the Yosemite, long before automobiles entered the park. Several stages from Yosemite's past are parked in this wagon shed, iconic symbols of the park's history of transportation.
audioDescription: A dirt path leads by this open wooden structure that has exposed timber frame trusses, log posts, and log barriers, and holds about 10 historic horse-drawn wagons and carriages inside. One of the wagons is green and has four large wheels, a basic body large enough to hold a metal barrel with a spigot, and only one seat in front. Another carriage is a bit fancier, with a yellow undercarriage and a red body that holds four rows of people, including the driver, and has a canopy over the top. Down the dirt path is a grey barn and corral. Tall trees surround the area.

title: Wapama and Rancheria Fall Trailhead
listingDescription: Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals, and in spring and early summer, home to brightly colored wildflowers. Enjoy a day hike or overnight backpacking trip (wilderness permit required) in this area at any time throughout the year.Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone. Wapama Fall five-mile, round-trip hike follows the shoreline of the rese

images.altText: A few people follow a paved path that leads into a cave-like tunnel.

bodyText:
Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals, and in spring and early summer, home to brightly colored wildflowers. Enjoy a day hike or overnight backpacking trip (wilderness permit required) in this area at any time throughout the year.

Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone.

Wapama Fall five-mile, round-trip hike follows the shoreline of the reservoir with moderate up and downhill hiking. The trail includes spectacular views of Tueeulala and Wapama Falls.

The trail to Rancheria Falls continues past Wapama Fall and may be done as either a long day hike (13 miles round trip) or a backpacking trip. Along the way, hikers will see beautiful views of the valley and waterfalls. Backpackers can access Tiltill or Rancheria mountains and the vast northwest wilderness of Yosemite from the Rancheria area.

Visit the Hetch Hetchy Entrance to get more information about hikes in this area.

Wapama Fall (moderate)
5 miles (8 km) round-trip; 2 hours

Rancheria Falls (moderate)
13.4 miles (21.4 km) round-trip; 6 to 8 hours

Hours:
Year-round, however, winter weather conditions may cause road closures. Call 209-372-0200 for the latest road and weather conditions. The road is currently open only from 8 am to 5 pm.

There is no access to Hetch Hetchy trailheads by car when road is closed.

Getting Here:
The trailhead is located across the O'Shaughnessy Dam and through the tunnel. The O'Shaughnessy Dam is located on the Hetch Hetchy Road, which begins just outside the park on Highway 120, near the Big Oak Flat Entrance.

Rules & Regulations:
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in.
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Hetch Hetchy Entrance until 5pm, at no cost.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.

Hazards & Warnings:
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Carry sunscreen and watch for rattlesnakes and poison oak.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility:
This trailhead is not accessible.
audioDescription: The official trailhead for this walk begins after walking across the O'Shaughnessy Dam and through a dark tunnel. At the other side of the tunnel, a dirt trail continues around the perimeter of the reservoir. A large body of water is on the right side of the trail. The water is in a granite basin, with high granite cliff walls rising up around the reservoir. Four wayside exhibits line the dirt path near the trailhead. The first sign has two panels stacked on top of each other. The upper panel has a faint, sepia-toned photo of an elderly Native American woman holding a baby in a cradle basket. The text reads, for generations Central Me-Wuk, Southern Sierra Miwuk, and Mono Lake Paiute people made mountain places like this their homes, using the higher mountains for trade routes and summer encampment. We have lived on the land as hunters and gatherers, and traditional skills and beliefs were passed on. We still live here and continue to teach our children the ways of our ancestors. The lower panel is titled, Archeological Site Protection, and has a faint, sepia-toned background photo of three Native American children grouped together. A young girl in a plaid dress and hat is on the left. A young boy with a white, long-sleeved shirt, hat, and long bangs, is to the right of the young girl, and is slightly taller than she is. An older girl, in a white, long-sleeved blouse and long skirt, sits on the ground to the right of the two others, and smiles at the camera. Panel text reads, disturbing these resources is disrespectful to American Indian cultures and is a violation of law. Please participate as a guardian of these important resources. The second sign has four, small, square panels, all located below a large map. Map: The large, detailed map shows the northern portion of the park. Roads, trails, peaks, and lakes are labeled. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.The top left panel is orange with white text and reads, Hetch Hetchy trailhead. You are at the gateway to the northern canyons of Yosemite's wilderness. Wapama Falls - 2.7 milesRancheria Falls - 6.1 milesLaurel Lake - 6.8 milesLake Vernon - 8.0 milesTo protect water quality, swimming and boating is not allowed in the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir and in the stream within one mile of the Reservoir. Closure includes Wapama Falls and Rancheria Cascade. The top right panel is blue with white text and reads, wilderness regulations, the natural integrity of Yosemite's high country depends on you. Help protect the wilderness, and avoid a citation, by following these regulations.Camp at least four trail miles from all developed areas. Pets, firearms, and bicycles are prohibited in wilderness. Stay on the trails; shortcutting switchbacks kills vegetation and causes erosion. Maximum group size for cross-country travel is eight people.Avoid disturbing wildlife and other visitors by keeping quiet on the trail and in camp. Use a gas stove for cooking; wood fires are allowed only below 9,600 feet in existing fire rings using dead and downed wood. Leave campsites as you find them; do not build windbreaks, fire rings, hitch racks, chairs, drainage trenches, or other "improvements."Pack out everything you carry in; do not burn trash. Wilderness permit required for all overnight use. A series of three white circles containing three different icons are outlined in red and have a red diagonal line slashing through the middle. The three icons are of a gun, a dog, and a person on a bicycle.The bottom left panel is yellow with black text and reads, Black Bears - the health and well-being of Yosemite's bears depends on you. Bears are intelligent, curious, adaptable, and hungry. Human food, however, is harmful to bears and other animals here. Keep wildlife wild by using these food storage methods.At the trailhead: Remove all food, ice chests, and scented items from you car. Store them in food storage lockers where available. Never feed bears or other wildlife. In the backcountry: Store food, garbage, and scented items in bearproof canisters, available at front country locations. Keep items stored whenever you are not eating. Remember, bears are active day and night. Scare away any bears you see by making loud noises and acting aggressively. Report all bear incidents.The bottom right panel is blue with white text and reads, water quality - clean, sparkling water is one of the joys of the high country. Wildlife, wilderness visitors, and people downstream all need clean water to stay healthy. Protect your water suppy by following these regulations and suggestions:Camp at least 100 feet (40 steps) from water.Deposit human waste in a six-inch-deep hole at least 100 feet from water; carry out toilet paper.Wash dishes and yourself at least 100 feet from water; even biodegradeable soap pollutes.Carry a large water container and limit your trips to collect water; eroded stream banks and lakeshores contribute to poor water quality. Sta

title: Washburn Point
listingDescription: Enjoy this beautiful overlook that provides views of Half Dome and the eastern crest of the Sierra Nevada. From this vantage point, visitors can take in the "giant staircase" waterfalls - Nevada and Vernal - and also Illilouette Fall. The point is named for the Washburn brothers, who built the first road from Wawona to Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: Visitor enjoying the view with Half Dome in the background
images.title: Washburn Point
images.caption: Washburn Point

bodyText:
Enjoy this beautiful overlook that provides views of Half Dome and the eastern crest of the Sierra Nevada.

From this vantage point, visitors can take in the "giant staircase" waterfalls - Nevada and Vernal - and also Illilouette Fall. The point is named for the Washburn brothers, who built the first road from Wawona to Yosemite Valley.

Hours

Open to vehicles from approximately late May through October or November.
From mid-December through March, cross-country skiers can experience this view after skiing 10.5 miles, conditions permitting.

Getting Here

Located along the Glacier Point Road, near Glacier Point. From Yosemite Valley or Wawona, take the Wawona Road (Highway 41), then turn east onto Glacier Point Road.

Rules & Regulations

  • Vehicles longer than 30 feet and vehicles pulling trailers are not allowed past Sentinel Dome parking lot.
  • The Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings

All park animals are potentially dangerous. They may bite or scratch, and can spread disease. Please do not feed animals.

Accessibility

There is one designated accessible parking spot at the north end of the lot.
audioDescription: Washburn Point is an overlook that gives a panoramic view of Half Dome, Nevada Fall, and Vernal Fall, and other domes, peaks, and natural features found in Yosemite's high country. A ramp or steps descend from the parking lot. A three foot stone wall barrier lines the walkway and viewing area. A wayside exhibit stands on the south side of the overlook.

title: Wawona Covered Bridge
listingDescription: All Yosemite-bound traffic through the Wawona area crossed the covered bridge, which was built in 1857 by Galen Clark. Clark opened the first way-station for visitors in Wawona and later became the first guardian of the Yosemite Grant. He sold his land along the river to the Washburns, and they covered the bridge in the style of their native Vermont. Its restoration was the first step in the creation of the Pioneer Yosemite History Center.As you cross the bridge, listen for t

images.altText: A bright red horse-drawn stage exits an old covered wooden bridge.

bodyText: All Yosemite-bound traffic through the Wawona area crossed the covered bridge, which was built in 1857 by Galen Clark. Clark opened the first way-station for visitors in Wawona and later became the first guardian of the Yosemite Grant. He sold his land along the river to the Washburns, and they covered the bridge in the style of their native Vermont. Its restoration was the first step in the creation of the Yosemite History Center. As you cross the bridge, listen for the low rumble of an oncoming stage and allow your imagination to return to the days of Yosemite's pioneers.
audioDescription: A dirt road leads into this covered bridge. Vertical wooden planks make up the height of this bridge, which extend up to an A-frame roof. There is a wooden divider stretching across the inside of the bridge, making a path for people to walk on, and a road for the stagecoach to use. An exhibit sign reads: The Covered Bridge. The deck and truss portion of this bridge across the South Fork of the Merced River was built around 1857 by settler Galen Clark, who established a tourist facility there. The area was then called Clark's Station. The road from Wawona to the Yosemite Valley opened in 1875 just after the Washburn brothers purchased Clark's holdings. The brothers, who were from Vermont, covered the bridge soon thereafter. Bridges were covered primarily to protect the large wood truss beams and flooring from the weather. It is much easier to re-shingle a roof than to replace the major supporting structures. Although the large beams were hand-hewn with ax and adze, the lumber to cover the bridge was cut locally at the Washburn's sawmill. Did the Washburn brothers cover the bridge exclusively for practical reasons? Maybe so. But a granddaughter claims the reason was nostalgia - they were homesick for a bit of New England.

title: Wawona Grey Barn (Washburn Barn)
listingDescription: In the late 1800s, Wawona was the largest stage stop in Yosemite. After hours of bouncing and bumping along uneven dirt roads, inbound stages stopped for the night at the Wawona Hotel before making the eight-hour trip to Yosemite Valley. If a stage needed a repair before the sixteen-hour round-trip journey, the grey barn was the place to visit. The Washburns, proprietors of the Wawona Hotel, used this barn for repairing stages.

images.altText: One door of a grey barn is open. Rows of lights hang from the ceiling and people can be seen sitting inside. Trees surround the area.

bodyText: In the late 1800s, Wawona was the largest stage stop in Yosemite. After hours of bouncing and bumping along uneven dirt roads, inbound stages stopped for the night at the Wawona Hotel before making the eight-hour trip to Yosemite Valley. If a stage needed a repair before the sixteen-hour round-trip journey, the grey barn was the place to visit. The Washburns, proprietors of the Wawona Hotel, used this barn for repairing stages.
audioDescription: The wooden barn is grey and has a gable style triangular roof. Double doors are open in the front and in the back. A red, white, and blue bunting is placed on the inside of each door. A fenced corral is located to the left and a fire ring is near the front.

title: Wawona Hotel
listingDescription: Immersed in nature, Wawona Hotel is the perfect place to settle in during your Yosemite National Park visit.

images.altText: Image of fountain in foreground and hotel in background
images.title: Wawona Hotel
images.caption: Wawona Hotel and Fountain

bodyText:
Immersed in nature, Wawona Hotel is the perfect place to settle in during your Yosemite National Park visit. 

One of California's original mountain resort hotels, the Victorian-era Wawona Hotel was originally established in 1856. Accommodations consist of 50 standard hotel rooms with private bath and 54 standard hotel rooms with shared restrooms. The hotel dining room serves breakfast, lunch and dinner. In the evening, wind down your fun filled day by gathering around the piano for musical performances in the lounge. Seasonal amenities include a nine-hole golf course, a swimming pool, and a riding stable.

Galen Clark, a former gold prospector, built the first structure on this site. He built the simple log cabin along the original trail. Positioned to ensure a constant flow of foot traffic, it was built along the original trail into Yosemite Valley. Visitors would stop along the way to restock their provisions and rest before continuing their travels. From these humble beginnings, the Wawona Hotel came to be-attracting many famous travelers of the day, including President Theodore Roosevelt.

Hours

March to November and several weeks in December
For opening dates see Website .

The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.
Check-in: 5 pm
Check-out: 10 am

Getting Here

The Wawona Hotel is located 27 miles from Yosemite Valley on the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all accommodations and buildings in Yosemite.
  • There are no pets allowed on property.

Accessibility

All Lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are located on the north side of the Hotel behind Hill's Studio. The hotel dining room, lobby, and restrooms are accessible. Additionally, there are two accessible guest rooms available.
audioDescription: Upon entering the Wawona Hotel area, there is a circular driveway lined with several white buildings. At the far end of the circular driveway, there is a long, white, two-story building that has a sign reading Wawona Hotel. The property is surrounded by tall pine and cedar trees, and has groomed lawns with a few white, wooden chairs scattered about. In the middle of the circular driveway is a grassy area with a fountain that has a paved path surrounding it.

title: Wawona Hotel Dining Room
listingDescription: With authentic Victorian era ambiance, the Wawona Hotel Dining Room features hand painted lamps and a summertime veranda where you can enjoy superb cuisine nightly. Snuggle by the fireplace, relax on the lawn in our comfortable Adirondack chairs, or settle into a great meal in the main dining room. Wawona Hotel also offers a BBQ on select holiday weekends.

images.altText: Indoor seating in the historic hotel dining room
images.title: Wawona Hotel Dining Room
images.caption: Wawona Hotel Dining Room

bodyText:
With authentic Victorian era ambiance, the Wawona Hotel Dining Room features hand painted lamps and a summertime veranda where you can enjoy superb cuisine nightly. Snuggle by the fireplace, relax on the lawn in our comfortable Adirondack chairs, or settle into a great meal in the main dining room.

Wawona Hotel also offers a BBQ on select holiday weekends. Choose a delicious grilled barbecue entree and enjoy unlimited side dishes and a dessert of your liking. Special Sunday holiday brunch menus are offered for Easter and Mother's Day. Holiday dinners are also served for Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve.

Hours

Early-April to Early-December
Mid-December to Early January.
See latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for current hours.

The Wawona Hotel is located 27 miles from Yosemite Valley on the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Accessibility

title: Wawona Meadow Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Take a relaxing and scenic stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin and gives the opportunity to see wildlife and wildflowers. Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course. Once across the golf course, take a left at the sign-posted trailhead. The trail is an unpaved fire road which loops around the meadow and returns to the Wawona Road. You will be sharing the trail with horses, bicyclists, and those that wish to hike with their pets, s

images.altText: A wooden sign at the intersection of a trail and road reads, "Meadow Loop Trail," and has an arrow pointing to the left.

bodyText:
Take a relaxing stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin.

Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course. Once across the golf course, take a left at the sign-posted trailhead. The trail is an unpaved fire road which loops around the meadow and returns to the Wawona Road.

You will be sharing the trail with horses, bicyclists, and those that wish to hike with their pets, so please be courteous of others.

3.5 miles (5.6 km) round trip
1.5 to 2 hours

Hours:
Trail is open year-round

Getting Here:
Begin at the Wawona Hotel, located on the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Rules & Regulations:
Horses, bikes, and leashed pets are permitted on the trail.

Accessibility:
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription: A path from the Wawona Hotel leads across the Wawona Road, past the golf course, to the Meadow Loop trailhead. This mostly flat dirt trail is partially in a forest and partially in open meadow. It is a 3.5 mile loop that goes around the Wawona Meadow, which also contains the golf course.

title: Wawona Picnic Area

Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot along the south fork of the Merced River. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :The Wawona Picnic area is located on the Wawona Road, near the Wawona Campground, about a mile north of Wawona. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not a

images.altText: Picnic tables are located in the shade on the banks of a river.

bodyText:
Be enticed by the refreshing aroma of the forest and the sounds of the burbling river while sitting down to a picnic in Wawona.

Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot along the south fork of the Merced River.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
The Wawona Picnic area is located on the Wawona Road, near the Wawona Campground, about a mile north of Wawona.

Rules & Regulations:
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings:
For your safety and that of wildlife:

Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility:
The Wawona Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible.
audioDescription: The Wawona Picnic area is located immediately off the Wawona road, near the Wawona Campground. As you enter the small parking lot, there is a restroom located on the left, along with trash cans. Picnic tables are lined up from left to right, an approximate ten feet from the parking lot. Trees surround the area and a river flows nearby.

title: Wawona Stable
listingDescription: Beyond hiking, the best way to explore the trails at Yosemite National Park is on a mule ride or horseback riding adventure. Wawona Stable offers the only two-hour ride on mules and horses in the park. Ideal for riders of all ages and abilities, the terrain is flat and the riding is gentle.

images.altText: Riders on horses leaving the stable
images.title: Wawona Stable
images.caption: Wawona Stable

bodyText:
The Wawona Stable is closed.

Beyond hiking, a fun way to explore the trails at Yosemite National Park is on a mule or horseback riding adventure.

Wawona Stable offers the only two-hour ride on mules and horses in the park. Ideal for riders of all ages and abilities, the terrain is flat and the riding is gentle as the ride meanders around the Wawona Meadow.

See website for times and prices.

Hours

Approximately May to September, conditions permitting

Getting Here

Wawona Hotel Stable is located on Chilnualna Falls Road, a quarter-mile off Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Rules & Regulations

  • Arrive one hour prior to scheduled ride.
  • must be at least 7 years of age
  • must be at least 44 inches tall.
  • cannot weigh more than 225 pounds.
  • We recommend long pants
  • Close-toed shoes are required
  • Purses, backpacks and all other bags are not permitted on the ride.

Accessibility

After consultation with the Wawona Stable staff, an opportunity for a gentle horse ride around the corral for someone with special needs, may be arranged.
audioDescription: As you approach the stable from the parking lot, you pass under a black and white sign that reads, Wawona Hotel Stable. There is a dirt path that leads to the stable office. to the left of the dirt path, there is a corral full of mules and horses before reaching a large, wooden, barn like building that faces to the right and has an American Flag and a sign that reads Big Trees Stable, Riding horses, pack trips.

title: White Wolf Lodge
listingDescription: Set near meadows abundant with wildflowers and surrounded by pine trees, you'll find tranquility here at the remote and peaceful White Wolf Lodge.

images.altText: Wooden cabin painted white with a covered porch
images.title: White Wolf Lodge
images.caption: White Wolf Lodge

bodyText:
Set near meadows abundant with wildflowers and surrounded by pine trees, you'll find tranquility here at the remote and peaceful White Wolf Lodge.

White Wolf Lodge features 24 canvas-tent cabins and four traditional wood cabins with private baths.

Guests gather morning and evening in the central dining room-a rustic wooden building with a porch that's perfect for relaxing and taking in the views. There is also a small store on site.

See website for more information about the cabins, to check availability, to book a room, and to get an idea of what to bring, and what to do in the White Wolf area.

Things to Do

The lodge is the ideal starting place for hikes to Lukens and Harden Lakes. Also, several ranger programs are available in the area in the summer. See the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for a programs schedule and dining hours.

Transportation

The Tuolumne Meadows Hikers Bus provides service between Tuolumne Meadows, Tioga Road, White Wolf Lodge, and Yosemite Valley. Call (209) 372-1240 for reservations.

YARTS also services the White Wolf area on its Hwy 120/395 bus route that connects Yosemite Valley with Tuolumne Meadows and Mammoth Lakes. See website for more information.

Hours

Approximately mid-July to early September
The front desk is generally staffed from 7am to 9pm, daily.

Check-in: 4 pm
Check-out: 11 am

Getting Here

Located along Tioga Road, approximately 30 miles from Yosemite Valley.

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all accommodations and buildings in Yosemite.
  • There are no pets allowed on property.
  • Bear-proof storage lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash.
  • To help keep wildlife wild, cooking isn't permitted inside or outside your tent cabin.

Hazards & Warnings

You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility

All Lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are available. Access the front desk and dining area by way of a ramp located behind the main building.
audioDescription: A white building with a roofed porch and white railings has steps that lead up its center to the front entrance. One large window is on either side of the door. To the far right of the building is a smaller service window. Two large split logs serve as benches at the bottom of the porch, on both sides of the steps. A road is located directly in front of the building and leads to a parking area located to the right side of the building. The road then leads on to the White Wolf Campground. Behind the main building, canvas tents with green wooden doors are randomly spaced out. Each tent has a green food locker to the side of the door. Tall trees surround the area.

Ride YARTS to avoid traffic and safely enjoy the scenery instead of watching the road. This particular route

images.altText: A sign that reads, "YARTS, Public transit to Yosemite, 877-989-2787, www.yarts.com," is posted on the side of a major road, with trees in the background.

bodyText:
Save gas, save time, save money, by taking YARTS!

The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system that operates year-round in the Yosemite region.

YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses. Ride YARTS to avoid traffic and safely enjoy the scenery instead of watching the road.

This particular route provides service along Highway 120 West, connecting Sonora, Jamestown, Groveland, Buck Meadows, and Yosemite Valley.

Purchase tickets on the bus with cash (exact change only), or with Visa, Mastercard, or Discover cards, or purchase online . All YARTS tickets include the entrance fee to Yosemite.


Hours:
May - September
Seven days a week. See website for schedule.

Getting Here:
Located on Big Oak Flat Road (Highway 120 from the west), in the Big Oak Flat Information Station parking area, near the park entrance.

Rules & Regulations:
Bags are allowed on YARTS buses, including backpacks of any size. Some backpacks may need to be stored in compartments under the passenger seating.
Bikes are allowed in the storage compartments under the bus, as space allows. Bikes can also be rented inside Yosemite National Park.

Hazards & Warnings:
YARTS does not provide pick up service anywhere other than designated stops, due to narrow roads.

Accessibility:
All YARTS buses are wheelchair accessible. However, this is on a per-ride basis and is dependent upon seating locations on the bus. Please contact YARTS 48 hours prior to your boarding, and we'll help make sure your ride is accessible.

Phone: 877/989-2787
7 am - 6 pm Pacific Time (U.S.)

Service animals are allowed on all YARTS buses.
audioDescription: A YARTS sign stands near a roadside pullout along the Big Oak Flat Road, right in front of the Big Oak Flat Information Station parking area and just down the road from the Big Oak Flat Entrance kiosks. The sign reads YARTS, Public Transit to Yosemite. Beneath the icon of a front facing bus, text reads 877-989-2787, www.yarts.com, Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System. On the poll below the sign, at eye height, is a four-sided plastic box that holds the latest route and schedule on each side. Tall trees and shrubs line the roadway.

bodyText:
Save gas, save time, save money, by taking YARTS!

The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system that operates year-round in the Yosemite region.

YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses. Ride YARTS to avoid traffic and safely enjoy the scenery instead of watching the road.

This particular route provides service along Tioga Road/Highway 120 East, connecting Mammoth Lakes, June Lake Loop, Lee Vining, Tuolumne Meadows, and Yosemite Valley.

Purchase tickets on the bus with cash (exact change only), or with Visa, Mastercard, or Discover cards, or purchase online . All YARTS tickets include the entrance fee to Yosemite.


Hours:
June - September
Seven days a week. See website for schedule.

Getting Here:
Located along Tioga Road, approximately 50 miles from Yosemite Valley.

Rules & Regulations:
Bags are allowed on YARTS buses, including backpacks of any size. Some backpacks may need to be stored in compartments under the passenger seating.
Bikes are allowed in the storage compartments under the bus, as space allows. Bikes can also be rented inside Yosemite National Park.

Hazards & Warnings:
YARTS does not provide pick up service anywhere other than designated stops, due to narrow roads.

Accessibility:
All YARTS buses are wheelchair accessible. However, this is on a per-ride basis and is dependent upon seating locations on the bus. Please contact YARTS 48 hours prior to your boarding, and we'll help make sure your ride is accessible.

Phone: 877/989-2787
7 am - 6 pm Pacific Time (U.S.)

Service animals are allowed on all YARTS buses.

audioDescription:
A blue and white sign reads YARTS, public transit to yosemite. Below a bus icon it reads (888) 989-2787, www.yarts.com, Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System. Below the YARTS sign is an area to insert current bus schedules. A separate green and white sign reads: Valley Shuttle, Valley Visitor Center, and has the number five, in white font, in a green circle.

Two covered shelters made with wooden beams and a shingled roof, both house two wooden benches. An informational display containing a map is located between the two shelters.

The display is made up of three small text panels that are lined up on top of a large map. The left panel is yellow with a green bar across the top. The text within the green bar reads Shuttle Bus Schedule, Shuttle Stop number five, Visitors Center. The text in the yellow box reads From 7am to 10 am, service every 30 minutes. From 10am to 7pm, service every 20 minutes. From 7pm to 10pm, service every 30 minutes.

The middle panel is white with a purple bar across the top. The text within the blue bar reads Shuttle to El Capitan. The text in the white box reads The El Capitan shuttle serves the west end of Yosemite Valley from May through October. Visitors can discover four uncrowded picnic areas, sandy beaches, and great views of climbers on "El Cap." You can hike back to Yosemite Village and Half Dome Village on the Valley Loop Trail, or climb above the Valley on the Four Mile Trail.

Photo: A white shuttle bus with the words Yosemite Shuttle across the side, is on the road in front of El Capitan

Caption: Valley shuttle drivers will be happy to help you with trip and bus transfer information. Photo, Al Golub.

The right panel is white with a blue bar across the top. The text within the blue bar reads Did You Know? The text in the white box reads what is now the Ansel Adams Gallery was first known as Best's Studio. It was owned by the Best family, who let a young Ansel Adams practice on the piano in their home. In 1928, Ansel Adams married Virginia Best here. Today, the gallery offers photography workshops and features Ansel Adams' work, along with other artisans.

Photo: A black and white photo shows a building with a wooden, high-pitched porch roof with stone pillars, and a sign and that reads Bests Studio.

Caption: The building has undergone renovation, but the Ansel Adams Gallery is still located in this 1920s structure. Photo, Yosemite Research Library.

The map shows three different Yosemite Valley shuttle routes. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

A fence runs along the backside of the shelters, separating the paved bus boarding area with a patch of grass. In front of the bus stop sign is a crosswalk that leads across the street to shuttle stop 9. The area is surrounded by black oak trees.
