title: Yosemite Administration Building Architecture

images.altText: A covered entrance to a two-story building with a stonework first level and shingled second level
images.title: Administration Building
images.caption: Administration Building

bodyText:
One of the first buildings constructed in the new village envisioned by Herbert Maier, Myron Hunt, and Thomas Vint, the Park Administration Building was constructed in 1924. Hunt is credited with the design of this particular building, which set the precedent for the similarly designed Post Office and Museum buildings.

Its stone first story and overhanging rustic frame second story reflect the granite canyon walls of the valley surmounted by the conifer forests above the rim.

The Administration Building is not open to public access. One of the first buildings constructed in the new village envisioned by Herbert Maier, Myron Hunt, and Thomas Vint, the Park Administration Building was constructed in 1924. Hunt is credited with the design of this particular building, which set the precedent for the similarly designed Post Office and Museum buildings.

Its stone first story and overhanging rustic frame second story reflect the granite canyon walls of the valley surmounted by the conifer forests above the rim.

The Administration Building is not open to public access.
audioDescription: The administration building is a two-story facility, in a wide rectangular shape. The first story is made of granite boulder stonework, while the second story is wood shingle siding that is painted dark brown. Multiple orange framed windows line both the first and second stories. The eastern aspect, facing the pedestrian plaza of Yosemite Village, has an overhanging entryway. The overhanging entry has two stone pillars at either corner, wood paneling under a pitched roof, and a small wooden sign that reads “administration building.” Under the overhang, there is a series of door panels painted the same as the windows. The building is surrounded by mature trees such as black oaks as well as various shrubs.

title: Yosemite Bike Share Program
listingDescription: The free Yosemite Bike Share opens for the season in late spring, depending on weather and road safety. When it opens, you can use the bike share for short trips (up to two hours) in Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: Bike Share bicycle parked
images.title: Yosemite Bike Share
images.caption: Yosemite Bike Share bicycle

bodyText:
The free Yosemite Bike Share opens for the season in late spring, depending on weather and road safety. When it opens, you can use the bike share for short trips (up to two hours) in Yosemite Valley.

How It Works

  1. Get connected: Download the free Yosemite Bike Share app for Apple/iOS (via the App Store) or Android (via Google Play).
  2. Get a bike: Use the app to unlock a bike at one of the Yosemite Bike Share stations, located at the Yosemite Village Parking Area and in Yosemite Village (between the Valley Wilderness Center and the Valley Visitor Center).
  3. Get pedaling: Ride safely! Use the helmet provided with the bike (or wear your own) and stay on roads and paved bike paths.

  4. When you’re done riding, return the bike to the station where you picked it up. Be sure to leave the bike in the “Used Bike Corral” area. To end your ride and lock the bike, manually close the lock on the rear wheel and press STOP on the app. Double-check that the app has registered the end of the ride before you leave!

Learn more about the bike share program, see a map of bike paths, and plan your routes.

title: Yosemite Cemetery
listingDescription: Take a few minutes to gaze back into Yosemite's interesting past by wandering through the Yosemite Cemetery.People buried at the Yosemite Cemetery include American Indians, casual park visitors, and people who played important roles in the development of what is now Yosemite National Park. A guide to the Yosemite Cemetery is available to borrow or purchase at the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :located in Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, a

images.altText: A grey wooden sign that reads Yosemite Cemetery is located next to a dirt path that is lined by zig-zagging wooden fences, and leads into the cemetery.

bodyText:
Take a few minutes to gaze back into Yosemite's interesting past by wandering through the Yosemite Cemetery.

People buried at the Yosemite Cemetery include American Indians, casual park visitors, and people who played important roles in the development of what is now Yosemite National Park.

A guide to the Yosemite Cemetery is available to borrow or purchase at the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
located in Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, across the street and just west of the Yosemite Museum.

Accessibility:
The cemetery is not accessible.
audioDescription: The entrance to Yosemite Cemetary is marked by a wooden sign held up with two posts, and reads Yosemite Cemetary. A dirt path leads into the cemetary, with a zig-zagged wooden fence on both sides of the path. The Cemetary is full of Cedar trees, a few black oak trees and ponderosa pines, and a couple of giant sequoia trees. The scenery opens up to allow views of Upper Yosemite Fall. About 20 to 30 headstones and wooden memorial markers are scattered throughout the cemetary. Some granite headstones are in the form of obelisks, crosses, and the common rounded top tablet.

title: Yosemite Chapel
listingDescription: The Yosemite Chapel, the oldest structure in Yosemite Valley, has been a place of worship, teaching, fellowship, and weddings for residents and visitors alike for over 140 years. The chapel was listed on the prestigious National Register of Historic Places in 1973.The Yosemite Chapel was originally erected near where the present Four Mile trailhead is located today.

images.altText: An orange structure with a pointed roof and steeple rest among dense, vibrant green foliage.

bodyText:
The Yosemite Chapel, the oldest structure in Yosemite Valley, has been a place of worship, teaching, fellowship, and weddings for residents and visitors alike for over 140 years. The chapel was listed on the prestigious National Register of Historic Places in 1973.

The Yosemite Chapel was originally erected near where the present Four Mile trailhead is located today. By 1901, the surrounding "Lower Village" had nearly disappeared, so the chapel was relocated to its present location in the Old Village. In 1965 some interior restoration was completed, and the foundation was raised 3 feet to help protect the structure from periodic flooding. In spite of these efforts, the chapel sustained damage during the 1997 flood and required further restoration.

With a few minor exceptions, the Yosemite Chapel has been the park's sole church facility since its construction over 140 years ago. Purportedly, Yosemite Chapel services began June 7, 1879.

Yosemite Community Church

Resident Minister: Pastor Brent Moore
See website for special holiday services.
Phone: 209/372-4831
Open: Year-round
Email
More Information

  • Yosemite Valley Chapel
  • Weddings Information

SUNDAY SERVICES IN THE YOSEMITE CHAPEL

  • 9:15 am
  • 11 am (Memorial Day through Labor Day Only)

Getting Here

The Yosemite Chapel is located on Southside Drive, in eastern Yosemite Valley.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are available. The Chapel is wheelchair accessible by way of a wheelchair lift (elevator).
audioDescription: The Chapel is a wooden structure with a steeply pitched roof, and is painted red with orange doors and trim. There is a small set of 8 steps that lead up to the front doors. One vertical, rectangular, 8-paned window is on both sides of the doorway. A tall steeple rises up off the steep roof. A cement pathway starting from the steps in front of the chapel, splits and leads to the parking lot on the side of the chapel, and also to a crosswalk in front of the church. Trees surround the backside of the chapel, and a large rock face rises up behind.

title: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center (formerly LeConte Memorial Lodge)
listingDescription: Peruse through the library or attend an evening program at the Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, Yosemite's first public visitor center and a National Historic Landmark. The Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, was built by the Sierra Club starting in 1903. For over 110 years, a curator and Sierra Club volunteers have provided information to park visitors about Yosemite, the Sierra Nevada, and the national parks.

images.altText: A rustic stone building with a central peak and gabled roofs on either side
images.title: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center
images.caption: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center

bodyText:
Peruse through the library or attend an evening program at the Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, Yosemite's first public visitor center and a National Historic Landmark.

The Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center, was built by the Sierra Club starting in 1903. For over 110 years, a curator and Sierra Club volunteers have provided information to park visitors about Yosemite, the Sierra Nevada, and the national parks.

The Sierra Club still operates the iconic structure as a public education and visitor center, presenting and promoting the conservation ethic through public programs, educational displays, a publicly-accessible library, and interactive programs for kids and families.

The library collection includes books on the natural and human history of Yosemite and the Sierra Nevada; books by and about Yosemite luminaries like John Muir, Ansel Adams, and David Brower; children's nature literature, and Sierra Club books, magazine, and pamphlets.

Free programs on natural history, outdoor adventure, and conservation issues are presented several evenings each week at 8pm. See current Yosemite Guide for program schedule.

Hours

May - September
Wednesday - Sunday
10 am to 4 pm

Getting Here

Located at shuttle stop 12, across from Housekeeping Camp, on Southside Drive in Yosemite Valley.
audioDescription: The granite stone masonry and steep-pitched roof are unlike any other building in the park. The building captures the color, texture, and verticality of the Yosemite Valley walls. As you approach the facility, the center section of the building rises up to a steep point, and two smaller wings are built slightly inward on each side. A stonewall extends off the ends of each wing, slanted inward as well, creating a hexagonal structural layout. Steps lead to the center of the hexagonal layout, a small porch area, up to the front, wooden, pointed arched, door. Four windows line the front side of the building. At the end of the right stone porch wall, a bronze plaque is adhered to the granite, and it reads, LeConte Memorial Lodge has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America. 1987. National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior.

title: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center Architecture

images.altText: A rustic stone building with a central peak and gabled roofs on either side
images.title: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center
images.caption: Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center

bodyText:
Constructed before the establishment of the rustic design guidelines, the Yosemite Conservation Heritage Center is an example of Tudor Revival architecture, a style not seen anywhere else within the national park system. The lodge is a transitional structure of strong European roots combined with the revolutionary way that Bay Area environmental designers used building materials.

The lodge was built by the Sierra Club in 1903 at the base of Glacier Point at a cost of approximately $5,000. As Camp Curry expanded, the lodge was rebuilt in its current location in 1919.

Architect John White donated his time to design the lodge. The building displays distinctive features of the First Bay Tradition, including its steeply pitched roof, emulating Yosemite Valley’s steep granite walls, and its use of local materials, such as granite and timber. The building’s steep roof pitch, masonry walls, and prominent chimney are also distinguishing features of the Tudor Revival style. The interior has a highly unusual, exposed roof structure of hammer beams supporting scissors trusses. The central fixture of the main lodge room is its massive stone fireplace.

During relocation and rebuilding, contractors removed the roof and rebuilt the rest of the lodge in its new location using John White’s drawings. Some elements such as windows appear to have been salvaged and reused in the new building. Rough‐cut granite was brought from Madera County for the reconstructed lodge walls.

title: Yosemite Creek Picnic Area
listingDescription: Let the cool breeze of the high-country and the soothing sounds of nature make for an enjoyable time at this shady picnic spot along Yosemite Creek.Five picnic tables line the perimeter of the driveway, beneath a canopy of pine trees and near the Yosemite Creek. Hours :Approximately late May or early June to sometime in November. Getting Here :Located along Tioga Road, a few miles east of White Wolf Road. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas are available on a first-come, fir

images.altText: A brown and white roadside sign reads, "Yosemite Creek," and has an icon of a picnic table and an arrow pointing left.

bodyText:
Let the cool breeze of the high-country and the soothing sounds of nature make for an enjoyable time at this shady picnic spot along Yosemite Creek.

Five picnic tables line the perimeter of the driveway, beneath a canopy of pine trees and near the Yosemite Creek.

Hours:
Approximately late May or early June to sometime in November.

Getting Here:
Located along Tioga Road, a few miles east of White Wolf Road.

Rules & Regulations:
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings:
For your safety and that of wildlife:
Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility:
Yosemite Creek Picnic Area features one accessible picnic table with an extended top, and an accessible vault toilet. There are no designated accessible parking spaces.
audioDescription: Five picnic tables line the permiter of this paved, loop driveway. The picnic tables are nestled beneath a canopy of tall pine trees, next to the Yosemite Creek. Granite boulders ranging from basketball-size to snowmobile-size and larger, are strewn about the area. Two green recycle bins and two brown trash bins sit at the far end of the loop driveway from the entrance. A small brown structure houses a vault toilet near the entrance. There is no designated parking lot.

title: Yosemite Creek and Ten Lakes Trailhead
listingDescription: Whether hiking or backpacking, travel off the beaten path to a group of pristine lakes or to the incredible views found at the rim of Yosemite Valley. John Muir once described Ten Lakes as "a glacier basin with ten glassy lakes set all near together like eggs in a nest."

images.altText: A brown and white roadside sign reads, "Yosemite Creek, Ten Lakes," and has an icon of a hiker.

bodyText:
Whether hiking or backpacking, travel off the beaten path to a group of pristine lakes or to the incredible views found at the rim of Yosemite Valley.

Ten Lakes Trailhead
John Muir once described these lakes as "a glacier basin with ten glassy lakes set all near together like eggs in a nest." To see the lakes, follow this trail through conifers and across granite to cross a tributary of Yosemite Creek. Take care on this crossing early in the season when the creek is high. Continue on the trail to Ten Lakes Pass, overlooking the Grand Canyon of the Tuolumne and the Sierra Crest. Then descend 693 feet (211 m) into the Ten Lakes Basin, which contains a series of beautiful High Sierra lakes.

Yosemite Creek Trailhead
This is a beautiful path that mostly follows Yosemite Creek to the rim of the Valley and Yosemite Falls. This trail drops about 2.6 miles through lodgepole pine stands before joining the trail from the Yosemite Creek Campground. The trail continues to parallel Yosemite Creek for another 3.3 miles before intersecting with the Yosemite Falls Trail which originates in Yosemite Valley, 3.5 miles below. Follow the signs to the overlook at Yosemite Point, a short distance to the east, for a glimpse of the breathtaking drop into Yosemite Valley and across the High Sierra. Use caution, wet rocks can be slippery.

For hiking and trail information, please visit a visitor center or information station.

Ten Lakes (strenuous)
12.6 mi (20.3 km) round-trip; 6-8 hours
2,200 ft (671 m) elevation gain

Yosemite Creek (strenuous)
16 miles (25.7 km) round-trip; 8-10 hours

Hours 
Accessible only while Tioga Road is open to vehicles, from late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Getting Here 
Dependent on which hike, begin at either the Ten Lakes Trailhead or Yosemite Creek Trailhead, which are across the street from each other, along Tioga Road, east of White Wolf Road

Rules & Regulations 
Stay on established trails
Pets are not allowed on hiking trails
Pack out what you pack in
Overnight backpackers need a wilderness permit, which can be obtained at the Big Oak Flat Information Station.
Bear canisters are required for wilderness food storage for overnight hikers.
Bears and other wildlife can be present on trails at any time of the day or night. Feeding and approaching wildlife is dangerous and illegal! Be sure to properly store your food.
Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call (209) 372-0200.

Hazards & Warnings 
Carry (and drink) plenty of water: a leading cause of injuries on the trail is dehydration. Be sure to treat river, stream, lake, or spring water.
Always carry a map and compass, and know how to use them, and wear sturdy footwear with good traction.
Be prepared for sudden changes in weather and conditions.

Accessibility
This trail is not accessible.
audioDescription:
The paved parking area for Yosemite Creek and Ten Lakes Trailhead is on the west side of Tioga Road and has two green recycle bins, two brown trash bins, four brown food lockers, a facility holding two vault toilets, one wayside exhibit and one map. Trees and granite bedrock surround the area. A dirt lot is located across the street, which is also where the trailhead for Ten Lakes is located. The trailhead for Yosemite Creek is at the north end of the parking area, marked by a metal sign that reads Yosemite Creek Trail and has an arrow pointing forward.

The wayside exhibit shows a faded, black and white, close-up, background photo of a full waterfall. Text on the left side of the exhibit panel reads, rocks, ice, and water - standing here near Yosemite Creek, one feels only a hint of the power that this busy but unassuming waterway will possess by the time it reaches the floor of Yosemite Valley.

The rocky Yosemite Creek watershed, which slopes downhill to the rim of Yosemite Valley about eight miles away, encompasses some fifty square miles of Yosemite's high country. Carved by tributary glaciers about 20,000 years ago, the V-shaped Yosemite Creek drainage was enlarged by the heavy volume of water and `ice which rushed through as the glacier retreated. Today, as spring snow melts, an average of 2,400 gallons per second of icy runoff is funneled through this hanging valley before plunging over the vertical cliff 2,425 feet to Yosemite Valley below.

Photo: A river with white water flows toward a precipice. Granite bedrock and trees are along the banks. A rock formation blanketed in snow is at the far end of the river.

Caption: Yosemite Creek plunging over the top of Yosemite Falls.

Text on the right side of the exhibit panel reads, Yosemite Creek Trail, for hiking and trail information, please visit a Visitor Center or Information Station. This strenuous 16-mile out-and-back trail drops about 2.6 miles through lodgepole pine stands before joining the trail from the Yosemite Creek Campground. The trial continues to parallel Yosemite Creek for another 3.3 miles below. Follow the signs to the overlook at Yosemite Point, a short distance to the east, for a glimpse of the breathtaking drop into Yosemite Valley and across the High Sierra. Use caution, wet rocks can be slippery.

Map: A tall, rectangular map of the surrounding area, shows a horizontal, squiggly, grey line near the top of the map, crossing from left to right, and is labeled Tioga Road. Along the Tioga Road, about three-quarters of the way to the right, a red dot indicates, "you are here." A dotted diagonal line extends downard and slightly to the left from the red dot, representing the Yosemite Creek Trail. Along the trail, Yosemite Creek Campground and the top of Yosemite Falls are labeled. At the bottom of the dotted line is Yosemite Valley. Upper Yosemite Fall and Lower Yosemite Fall are represented by a series of three blue lines stacked on top of one another, each line shorter than the one above it. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

Photo: A black and white aerial photo shows a three tier waterfall coming over a large rock wall. The upper fall is the longest of the three, the middle cascade the shortest. The lower fall is half the height of the upper fall.

Caption: V-shaped Yosemite Creek watershed and Yosemite Falls.

A map labeled, The Tioga Road, is on a sign board inside a wooden frame. The map shows the entire park with emphasis only on the Tioga Road, which is a red, solid, squiggly line that crosses the map from left to right, midway down the map. Major areas, beginning from the left include Crane Flat, which has icons indicating restrooms, groceries, gas, campground, and two sequioa groves that are in the area. A bit to the right is Tamarack Flat Campground. A quarter of the way across the map is White Wolf, which has icons indicating a campground, dining, and hiking are in that area. About one-third of the way across the map is Yosemite Creek, which has a red dot and text that reads, "you are here." This area is labeled with Hiking, restrooms, and picnic icons. Halfway across the map are Olmsted Point, which has no services, and Tenaya Lake, which has multiple hiking, picnic, and restroom icons in the area. About two-thirds of the way across the map is Tuolumne Meadows, which has icons indicating camping, dining, restrooms, groceries, a wilderness center, and hiking, which includes Cathedral Lakes and Lembert Dome. Near the right side of the map, past Tuolumne Meadows, Mono Pass, a hiking destination, and Tioga Pass, the east entrance and exit to the park, are found along Tioga Road. The road then continues down to the first town outside the park, Lee Vining. For information regarding park maps, call our park accessibility coordinator at (209) 379-1035.

title: Yosemite Exploration Center (formerly, Valley Visitor Center) Architecture

images.altText: Glass doors with large rock walls on either side, a sign says "Yosemite Visitor Center and Theater"
images.title: Yosemite Valley Visitor Center
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Visitor Center

bodyText:
Originally serving as the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center, this building was completed in 1967. For many decades, it included an information desk, exhibits, and retail space in its primary building. Attached buildings include two multi-purpose auditoriums, still in use, surrounding a small plaza.

The low, wide front elevation of the visitor center, as well as several accent walls on the interior and exterior, feature stones from the Merced River embedded into concrete slabs. These natural, local design details harmonize both visually and ideologically with nearby rustic buildings. The auditoriums behind the main visitor center are larger, plain structures not easily visible from the main visitor plaza spaces.

This building now houses exhibits and retail space managed by Yosemite Conservancy. Visitor information services moved to the Welcome Center in 2023.
audioDescription: Yosemite Valley Visitor Center is a single story building, made of granite stones and wooden planks. The front side of the building has two sets of double-doors with a bench sitting between both entrances. A wooden awning extends out over the entrances. Above the awning is a sign that reads Yosemite Visitor Center and Theater. To the left of the door, on the stone siding, is the National Park Service Logo, which is a brown, downward facing arrowhead, with a green sequoia tree, a white bison at the bottom, a white lake to the right middle, and a white mountain peak across the mid-section. Above the white peak, it reads National Park Service.

title: Yosemite Falls
listingDescription: Yosemite Falls is made of the upper fall, middle cascades, and lower fall, all dropping a total of 2,425 ft. (740 m), and is one of the tallest waterfalls in the United States. Yosemite Creek, which flows over this waterfall, is fed entirely by snow melt. At its peak in late spring, 2,400 gallons per second can flow over the lip of the upper fall. Yosemite Falls usually runs dry by late summer.

images.altText: View of Yosemite Falls from Cook's Meadow, blue skies and full water
images.title: Yosemite Falls
images.caption: Yosemite Falls

bodyText:
Yosemite Falls is made of the upper fall, middle cascades, and lower fall, all dropping a total of 2,425 ft. (740 m), and is one of the tallest waterfalls in the United States.

Source of the Falls

Yosemite Creek, which flows over this waterfall, is fed entirely by snow melt. At its peak in late spring, 2,400 gallons per second can flow over the lip of the upper fall. Yosemite Falls usually runs dry by late summer.

Ice Cone

In winter, a cone of ice accumulates at the base of Upper Yosemite Fall. The height of the cone can reach as high as 322 feet, about as tall as a 25-story building, and is usually melted by mid-April.

Moonbow

As the full moon rises in April and May, the light is captured and refracted in the massive spray at the base of Lower Yosemite Fall, creating a phenomenon called a moonbow.

Frazil Ice

In early spring, frazil ice sometimes forms in waterfalls and creeks when waterfall mist becomes very cool. Ice crystals form and group into spongy masses which sometimes overflow the creek bed. In 1997 frazil ice was above the railing of the Lower Yosemite Fall bridge, almost completely burying it!

Seasonality

While you can visit Yosemite Falls year-round, there is often no water in Yosemite Fall by late summer. 

Getting Here

Yosemite Falls flows over the north rim of Yosemite Valley. Access to the base of the waterfall is located on Northside Drive, near the Lower Yosemite Falls shuttle stop (Valley Shuttle #6), and across from the Yosemite Valley Lodge. The walk to the base of the waterfall is an easy 1 mile (1.6 km) hike which can be done as a loop.

Access to the top of Yosemite Falls is via the Upper Yosemite Fall Trail, located west of Lower Yosemite Fall near the Camp 4 Campground. Accessing the top of Yosemite Falls is a strenuous 7.2 mile (11.6 km) round-trip hike with 2,700 feet (823 m) of elevation gain. This trailhead can be accessed most easily by parking in the Yosemite Falls Parking Area or by using the free shuttle (Valley Shuttle #7). 

Rules & Regulations

  • Share the trail! Leashed pets and strollers are allowed.
  • Bicycles are prohibited. Numerous bicycle racks are located at the two trailheads (east and west side of the Lower Yosemite Fall loop) for your convenience.
  • Keep your food within arm's reach at all times and do not feed the wildlife.

Hazards & Warnings

Stay on the paved trail. Above the wooden footbridge that crosses Yosemite Creek, the rocks and boulders are slippery even when dry. Scrambling off-trail in this area frequently leads to serious injuries.

Accessibility

An accessible trail to access the base of Yosemite Falls is available near the shuttle stop. Only the eastern portion of the loop is accessible.
audioDescription: Upon approaching the Lower Yosemite Fall, the paved trail opens up to a viewing area. The open space is lined with mosaic stonework on the ground and large boulders. A fallen log also rests at the waterfall end of the viewing area. In the spring, the mist from the waterfall pelts everyone standing by, drenching them in seconds. Dependent on the season, the river either quietly or thunderously flows under a wood bridge nearby. Large rocks and boulders line the riverbed. Vibrant green trees surround the area.

title: Yosemite Falls Parking
listingDescription: Park your car and hit the trails or hop on the free Yosemite Valley Shuttle to see the sites in Yosemite Valley. Open year-round from dawn to dusk. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, near shuttle bus stops 7 and E2. Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.

images.altText: Cars line a parking lot that is surrounded by tall trees. A large granite rock wall rises above the treeline.

bodyText:
Park your car and hit the trails or hop on the free Yosemite Valley Shuttle to see the sites in Yosemite Valley.

Hours:
Year-round
Dawn to dusk

Getting Here:
You can reach Yosemite Valley via Highways 41, 140, and 120. Follow signs for Yosemite Valley Lodge and Camp 4, located in eastern Yosemite Valley, shuttle bus stops 7 and E2.

Rules & Regulations:
Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.
You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Hazards & Warnings:
During the busy summer, you are likely to experience congestion, especially in Yosemite Valley. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive by mid-morning to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility:
This is a dirt lot, there are no designated accessible parking spaces.
audioDescription: The Yosemite Falls Parking lot is a dirt lot located at the west end of Yosemite Valley Lodge and across the street from Camp 4. There are two rows of parking that run parallel to the main road, Northside Drive. A third row of parking, furthest from the main road, is reserved for oversided vehicles and buses. All parking spaces are unmarked. Trees surround the area. Views of Upper Yosemite Falls can be seen through the trees.

title: Yosemite Falls Picnic Area
listingDescription: Picnic beneath this awe-inspiring landmark, North America's tallest waterfall, Yosemite Falls. Picnic tables are conveniently located at this scenic spot that displays a remarkable view of Yosemite Falls. Drinking water and flush toilets are available. This picnic area is available from dawn to dusk.

images.altText: Wooden picnic tables, restroom building and waterfall in background
images.title: Yosemite Falls Picnic Area
images.caption: Yosemite Falls Picnic Area

bodyText:
Picnic beneath this awe-inspiring landmark, North America's tallest waterfall, Yosemite Falls.

Picnic tables are conveniently located at this scenic spot that displays a remarkable view of Yosemite Falls. Drinking water and flush toilets are available.

Hours

This picnic area is available from dawn to dusk.

Getting Here

Located near the Lower Yosemite Fall shuttle stop (Valley Shuttle #6). Also accessible by biking or walking along the pedestrian/bike path.

Rules & Regulations

Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings

For your safety and that of wildlife:

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Yosemite Falls Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, and accessible restrooms. There are no designated accessible parking spaces nearby. The Lower Yosemite Fall Shuttle Sop is nearby and has an accessible path leading to the picnic area.
audioDescription: The Yosemite Falls Picnic Area is located along Northside Drive, and along the walking path between the visitor center and the Yosemite Valley Lodge. The narrow walking path that cuts through the forest and leads to the base of Lower Yosemite Fall, allows for a view of the Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls from the picnic area. About seven randomly placed wooden picnic tables are available. Facing Yosemite Falls is due North. Short wooden fence posts and rails line the west side of the level, dirt, picnic area. Trash and recycle bins are located to the south, bike racks to the east and drinking fountains and a restroom are at the northeast corner.

title: Yosemite History Center
listingDescription: Go back to a time of horse-drawn wagons, a covered bridge, and log cabins. A visit to the Yosemite History Center explores Yosemite's history and explains how Yosemite was the inspiration for national parks across America and around the world. The Yosemite History Center consists of historic structures from different eras of Yosemite history.

images.altText: Horse drawn stage coming through covered bridge with passengers
images.title: Yosemite History Center
images.caption: Horse drawn stage coming through the Wawona Covered Bridge with passengers

bodyText:
Go back to a time of horse-drawn wagons, a covered bridge, and rustic cabins. The Yosemite History Center is a collection of historic buildings where outdoor interpretive signs tell the stories of people who moved here from around the world and shaped the park’s development. During the summer, visit exhibits inside the Chinese Laundry and the Acting Superintendent's Office, take a ride on our horse-drawn wagon, or watch blacksmiths forge iron tools on a coal forge! Check the Yosemite Guide for details.

Many of the buildings that make up the Yosemite History Center were moved to Wawona in the 1950s and '60s from various locations throughout the park. These buildings were moved to make way for more modern park facilities and to create an area to interpret Yosemite's history. The History Center commemorates the efforts of people, the events they experienced, and the issues they faced during the establishment of Yosemite as a national park.

Hours

Year-round

The Yosemite History Center is always open and informational signs are found in front of each building.

Getting Here

Access the complex by parking in the Wawona Store and Pioneer Gift Shop parking lot, located on the Wawona Road (continuation of Highway 41), near the Wawona Hotel.

Accessibility

Paths within the complex have a dirt surface. An accessible restroom is located near the parking lot. There is no designated accessible parking. Parking near the Wawona Store and Pioneer Gift Shop provides the best access; the paved route includes a portion with an 8.1% slope.
audioDescription: From the paved parking area near the Wawona Store and Pioneer Gift Shop, there is a path that leads across a street and beneath a sign that reads Yosemite History Center...a place of pioneers who so profoundly influenced the birth and growth of the National Park Idea. A flat, dirt path passes by a shed filled with 8 plus old stagecoaches. At the end of the shed is the intersection of an old stagecoach road. Taking the road to the right will lead you to the Gray Barn, and taking the road to the left will lead you through a covered bridge that sits over a stream. At the other side of the bridge is a small loop trail, lined with wooden pioneer-era buildings. There is a sign that instructs you to take the trail to the left, leading you to a clock-wise tour of the trail. In order of appearance, the trail takes you by Artist Cabin, Anderson Cabin, Homestead Cabin, Blacksmith Shop, Cavalry Office, Ranger Patrol Cabin, Degnan's Bakery, Wells Fargo Office, and the Powderhouse and Jail, before it loops back to the covered bridge.

title: Yosemite Medical Clinic
listingDescription: Protecting, Promoting, and Fostering Health and Wellness in Yosemite National Park, welcome to the Yosemite Medical Clinic. In the case of an emergency, dial 911. See website for the Yosemite Medical Clinic Notice of Privacy Practice and for information regarding methods of payment and insurance. Open year-round, closed on federal holidays. Located in Yosemite Valley, between Yosemite Village and The Ahwahnee.

images.altText: A roadside sign reads, "medical clinic," and has a red cross in the center.

bodyText:
Protecting, Promoting, and Fostering Health and Wellness in Yosemite National Park, welcome to the Yosemite Medical Clinic.

In the case of an emergency, dial 911.

Managed and operated by the National Park Service (NPS), the clinic is staffed by U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps and NPS healthcare providers. We offer basic medical care. See website for the Yosemite Medical Clinic Notice of Privacy Practice and for information regarding methods of payment and insurance.

Services:
Primary Care
- Physical exams
- Well child exams
- Chronic disease management
- Immunizations

Urgent Care
- Illness evaluation and treatment (colds, flu, and infections)
- Injury care (fractures, sprains, strains, cuts, abrasions)

Laboratory Services
A limited array of lab tests can be performed onsite. Other lab tests are sent to an offsite lab.

Radiology Services (X-ray)
Basic X-ray services may be available onsite, depending on staffing. Referral is made for radiology services that are not performed onsite.

Contact Information:
209/372-4637 (phone)
209/372-4330 (fax)

Mailing Address:
PO Box 550
Yosemite National Park, CA 95389

Physical Address:
9000 Ahwahnee Drive
Yosemite National Park, CA 95389

Hours:
Year-round, closed on federal holidays.
Ambulance available 24 hours by calling 9-1-1.
See website for hours.

Getting Here:
Located in Yosemite Valley, between Yosemite Village and The Ahwahnee.

Accessibility:
This facility is accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located behind the building.
audioDescription: This wood and stone building is set back away from the main road, Ahwahnee Drive, up a gravel driveway. Trees surround the property and The Upper Yosemite Fall is its backdrop. Three signs line the drive way and parking area. One sign reads Medical Clinic and has a square icon with a red cross in the center. The second sign reads Patient Parking Only. The third sign reads Patient Entrance and has an arrow pointing to the right. Monday through friday, 9am to 5pm. After Hour Emergencies dial 9 1 1. Emergency phone located at rear entrance. A square icon with a phone in its center is located to the left of Dial 9 1 1. A handicap symbol is followed by text that reads access in rear. A square icon with a bus in its center and a red slash across the icon is followed by text that reads No oversize vehicles beyond this point.

title: Yosemite Museum
listingDescription: Explore the cultural history of Yosemite Indians and watch daily traditional demonstrations, tour the art gallery, or take a self-guiding tour through an outdoor Indian Village, at the Yosemite Museum. The Yosemite Museum has displays that interpret the cultural history of Yosemite's native Miwok and Paiute people from 1850 to the present, demonstrations of stone tool making, basket-weaving, beadwork, and traditional games.

images.altText: Yosemite Museum building with wood bark house to the left of the main door
images.title: Yosemite Museum
images.caption: Yosemite Museum entrance

bodyText:
Explore the cultural history of Yosemite Indians and watch daily traditional demonstrations, tour the art gallery, or take a self-guiding tour through an outdoor Indian Village, at the Yosemite Museum.

The Yosemite Museum has displays that interpret the cultural history of Yosemite's native Miwok and Paiute people from 1850 to the present, demonstrations of stone tool making, basket-weaving, beadwork, and traditional games.

In front of the museum is a cross-section of a giant sequoia tree that visitors can touch and a re-creation of an umacha, a Miwok and Paiute cedar bark house. Behind the Yosemite Museum, follow a self-guiding accessible trail through the re-constructed Indian Village of Ahwahnee, and learn about the significant plants and structures. Interpretive rangers are available to provide additional information.

The gallery is open periodically and often exhibits art pieces from the Yosemite Museum collection and other artists. See the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for current exhibits.

Hours

Year-round
10 am to 5 pm (closed at noon for one hour) 

Getting Here

Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, nearest to Yosemite Village Parking. The Yosemite Museum is also located at shuttle stop #5 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle route.

Accessibility

This facility is accessible. A few designated accessible parking spaces are available just west of the visitor center.
audioDescription: The building that houses the Yosemite Museum is a two story facility. The first story is made of granite boulder stonework, while the second story is wood shingle siding that is painted dark brown. Multiple orange framed windows line the second story. Above the arched entranceway is a wooden sign that reads museum. The entrance has double wooden doors with glass panes containing a few flyers. To the right of the entrance is a large slab of a giant sequoia trunk, about 9 feet in diameter. A sign reads Big Tree, sequoiadendron giganteum. This nine foot section of a giant sequoia was cut 30 feet from the base of a tree that fell in the Mariposa Grove in 1919. Annual rings show the tree's to be 996 years old, but at the base of the tree, where the diameter was 14 feet, the age was found to be 1,100 years. One of the largest trees in the Mariposa Grove, the Grizzly Giant, has been estimated to be 1790 years old. These big trees should not be confused with the coast redwood, Sequoia sempervirens, which is utilized commercially. Both are sequoias, part of the redwood family of trees, but the giant sequoia Sequoia giganteum, is native only to the western slope of the Sierra Nevada. The coast redwood grows along the Pacific coast from the Monterey Peninsula to southwestern Oregon. The fossil record indicates that over forty species of the redwood family once existed in the Northern Hemisphere. Eighteen species survive to the present, three of which have the name sequoia. There are nine small green arrows tags pointing at rings in the tree, progressing from the oldest, inner ring to the outer, most recent ring. The first tag near the center of the sequoia trunk slab reads A.D. 323, the next tag to the right reads 1066 Battle of Hastings, the next tag reads 1215 Magna Carta, the next tag, which is about two-thirds of the way from the center, reads 1492 Landing of Columbus, the next tag reads 1620 Landing of Pilgrims, and the next tag reads 1776 Declaration of Independence. The next three tags skirt around the outter edge of the slab and they read 1860 Civil War, 1864 Lincoln signed Yosemite Grant, and 1890 Yosemite National Park. To the left of the entrance is an Ahwahneechee Umacha, a traditional dwelling for Yosemite Indians, made up of long cedar planks stacked in a conical shape.

title: Yosemite Museum Architecture

images.altText: A two story building with a rock wall first story and shingle second story
images.title: Yosemite Museum
images.caption: Yosemite Museum

bodyText:
The Yosemite Museum, completed in 1926, was designed by architect Herbert Maier in the newly emerging National Park Service rustic style. The Yosemite Museum was the first building constructed as a museum in the national park system, and its educational initiatives served as a model for parks nationwide.

It was constructed in the emerging village center, in which all buildings were to have a unified architectural theme. Maier described the relationship between the Museum and its natural surroundings by saying, “The elevation of the museum stresses the horizontal—that seemed the logic of the situation…to attempt altitudinal impressiveness here in a building would have meant entering into a competition with the cliffs.

”Indigenous building material, such as native rocks, logs, and wood shingles, were utilized for all visible exterior parts. The architectural philosophy was that rustic style “gives the feeling of having been executed by pioneer craftsmen with limited hand tools. It thus achieves sympathy with natural surroundings and with the past.

”The Museum differs from the others in that where the others have frame floors to the second stories (and ceilings to the first), the ground floor of the Museum is completely fireproof, separated from the frame second story by a thick concrete ceiling, a design factor resulting from its intended museum use with the purpose of preserving artifacts, specimens, and exhibits.

title: Yosemite National Park

images.altText: Black and white of rocky mountain top covered with snow and trees spread out on top
images.title: Yosemite National Park
images.caption: Yosemite National Park

relatedParks.fullName: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Frederick Law Olmsted

tags: frederick law olmsted national historic site
bodyText:
Frederick Law Olmsted didn’t arrive at Yosemite for a vacation but was here to work; he took over as the general manager for the Mariposa gold-mining estate. Many thought he was crazy to leave behind his landscape architecture work, and his father made sure Frederick knew his displeasure over the move. However, at the time no one could have known that this move would set the stage for the creation of parks from the natural domain.

A year after his move to California, the state had secured a grant deeming Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Big Tree Grove inalienable parkland. A commission was formed to oversee the creation of the public preserve, with Olmsted serving as Superintendent and Chairman.

Another year would pass before Olmsted wrote his report on Yosemite Valley and Mariposa, stressing the uniqueness of the valley, not because of the towering cliffs, but because of the union of the entire landscape, and the experience of taking it all in, uninterrupted.

Olmsted wrote his report for Yosemite and Mariposa with a distinct eye for the times; the Civil War was over and he was expanding upon Lincoln’s vision for a broader, more inclusive interpretation of democracy as he wrote the foundation for our national park system.

Like father, like son, Olmsted Jr. would join in on his father’s fight 50 years later when asked to refine his father’s work and address the need for a new bureau to manage scattered parks and monuments. This would start a 6-year correspondence, culminating in Jr.’s writing of the Organic Act, which would help solidify the creation of the NPS, keeping great natural wonders in the hands of the people.

title: Yosemite Theater
listingDescription: Take in a film about Yosemite during your trip at the Yosemite Theater, located behind the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center. The Spirit of Yosemite, is shown daily on the hour and the half hour in the theater behind the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center. The first showing is at 9:30am, and the last showing is at 4pm, except on Sundays, when the first showing is at noon.

images.altText: Double glass doors as the entrance to the theater
images.title: Yosemite Theater
images.caption: Yosemite Theater

bodyText:
Watch an orientation film about Yosemite at the Yosemite Theater before getting your Yosemite plans underway.

The park film, The Spirit of Yosemite, is shown daily on the hour and the half hour in the theater behind the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center. The first showing is at 9:30am, and the last showing is at 4pm, except on Sundays, when the first showing is at noon. Audio description and foreign language headsets are available at the visitor center information desk.

Hours

Year-round
Monday - Saturday: 9:30 am to 4:30 pm
Sunday: Noon to 4:30 pm

Getting Here

Located in Yosemite Village at shuttle stop 5. The theater is behind the visitor center. Either walk through the visitor center, or use the sidewalk to the left of the visitor center, to access the theater.

Accessibility

  • There is an accessible path to the Theater through the visitor center, or via a sidewalk to the left of the visitor center.
  • The Spirit of Yosemite is both captioned and audio described. Ask at the information desk for an assistive listening device.
  • Accessible restrooms are located in the building to the west of the visitor center.
  • A few designated accessible parking spaces are available just west of the visitor center.
audioDescription: The building that houses the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center and Theater, arcs halfway around a courtyard in the back of the facility. The tail end of the building is where the theater is located. It is a simple cement building with a covered walkway lining the front of the theater and extending to the exhibit hall of the visitor center. There are double glass doors that lead visitors into the theater.

title: Yosemite Transportation Office
listingDescription: Yosemite Valley was the center for most visitor services. The Yosemite Transportation Office was constructed in Yosemite Valley in 1910 by the Yosemite Valley Railroad Company as a transportation terminal and telecommunications hub. Visitors arriving by horse-drawn or auto stage used this office to make railroad and lodging reservations, place long-distance phone calls, or send telegrams.

images.altText: Wooden transportation office building with horse drawn stage and passengers in foreground
images.title: Yosemite Transportation Office
images.caption: Yosemite Transportation Office

bodyText:
The Yosemite Transportation Office was constructed in Yosemite Valley in 1910 by the Yosemite Valley Railroad Company as a transportation terminal and telecommunications hub.

Starting in 1907, Yosemite-bound tourists could ride the railroad from Merced to El Portal, just outside the park, eliminating the bumpy, dusty, two-day stage ride. However, the final fourteen-mile leg of the journey from El Portal to Yosemite Valley was still made by stage, and later by autos.

Upon arrival at this terminal in Yosemite Valley, passengers could book a stay in a hotel and make transportation arrangements with travel agents, who lived in the building’s back rooms. Despite its rustic design, the office provided modern conveniences. Visitors could make telephone calls or send telegrams to anywhere in the world. By 1914, automobiles were common in Yosemite, and in that year, horse-drawn stage service was discontinued. However, annual visitation to the park in 1915 doubled to 31,000. Consequently, stage operation was renewed but only for one additional year. In 1916, the era of stage travel ended and another began. The National Park Service, a federal agency created to preserve and manage our country's national parks, was established.

The reliance on transportation companies for park access diminished greatly when the All-Year Highway (now California Highway 140) opened in 1927, and personal cars soon became the dominant means of transportation in Yosemite.
audioDescription: The front of this wooden building has a windowed door in the center and two windows on either side of the door. The windows have a multitude of horizontal diamond-shaped window panes that are lined with white trim. There is a long green bench on each side of the door, and three wooden steps leading up to the door. A wooden sign above the doorway reads "Yosemite Transportation Company, Wells Fargo and Company Express " painted in yellow. This structure has a large A-frame roof.

title: Yosemite Valley Lodge
listingDescription: Yosemite Valley Lodge's close proximity to Yosemite Falls makes it the perfect base camp for exploring Yosemite National Park.

images.altText: front desk of hotel with visitors checking in
images.title: Yosemite Valley Lodge
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Lodge front desk.

bodyText:
Yosemite Valley Lodge's close proximity to Yosemite Falls makes it the perfect base camp for exploring Yosemite National Park.

Yosemite Valley Lodge includes 241 recently remodeled traditional rooms with different available bed options; and 4 Family Rooms.

The lodge offers a gift shop, multiple dining options, a bar, and an outdoor swimming pool on the premises. See the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for hours.

See website for more information about the rooms, to check availability, to book a room, and to get an idea of things to do in the Yosemite Valley Lodge area.

Hours

Year-round
The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.
Check-in: 5 pm
Check-out: 10 am

Getting Here

You can reach Yosemite Valley via Highways 41, 140, and 120. Follow signs for Yosemite Valley Lodge, located in eastern Yosemite Valley. This facility is also accessible by using the free Valley Shuttle (Stop #7). 

Rules & Regulations

  • Smoking is strictly prohibited at all accommodations and buildings in Yosemite.
  • There are no pets allowed on property.

Hazards & Warnings

You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility

All Lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Select rooms are accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in front of the registration office and near pathways leading to lodge rooms.
audioDescription:
The Yosemite Valley Lodge property is made up of three main buildings that contain the front desk, four dining options, a gift shop, and two meeting rooms. These three main buildings are situated in close proximity to each other, and form a triangular shape, with an outdoor amphitheater in the middle. There are also 15 other buildings on property that contain anywhere from 8 to 35 guest rooms per building.

Approaching the front of the main building, which contains the front desk, there is a porte coÂ·chÃ¨re that extends across almost the entire front facade of the building. Three steps on either the left or the right side of a raised porch lead to the entrance, two double-doors located in the center of the buildings' facade. A wooden sign to the right of the doors reads Yosemite Valley Lodge, while a wooden sign above the doors reads Welcome. A blue U.S. Postal Service mail box is also located on the porch to the right of the doors, as well as a bench, just down the steps. A accessible ramp is located to the right of the building.

title: Yosemite Valley Lodge Architecture

images.altText: A peaked window wall with overhanging eaves surrounded by tree branches
images.title: Base Camp Eatery, Yosemite Valley Lodge
images.caption: Base Camp Eatery, Yosemite Valley Lodge

bodyText:
Architect Eldridge T. Spencer designed three new buildings oriented around a central courtyard. Most buildings are connected by covered walkways. This comprehensive building and landscape plan includes the present-day guest registration area, cafeteria, restaurant, cocktail lounge, outdoor amphitheater, and gift shop. Completed in 1959 at a cost of $1.5 million, Yosemite Lodge, as it was then known, was the most expensive project the Yosemite Park and Curry Company had taken on up to that point.

Spencer was inspired by John Muir’s words describing the Sierra Nevada mountains as a “range of light.” When designing the lodge complex, Spencer incorporated a sense of openness and lightness. The walkways and courtyard between buildings take the visitor through natural environments and views of Yosemite Falls. The large window walls create a sense of openness and allow natural light and scenery to reach visitors indoors. Steel framing and glass windows are unobtrusive and blend with the natural environment. The low horizontal massing of the buildings does not compete with the grand height of Yosemite Falls and nearby trees, allowing visitors to appreciate the sense of scale.

Like other Mission 66 buildings in Yosemite Village, the lodge complex features mountain chalet motifs. For instance, inside the cocktail lounge, a large central fireplace features stylized images of skiers embossed in metal. Vaulted wood panel ceilings in several buildings impart both openness and warmth.

title: Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand
listingDescription: Biking is one of the best ways to see Yosemite Valley. Yosemite Valley is flat, which makes for easy riding along our 12 miles of designated paths. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. We also offer a select number of tandem bikes and hand-crank bikes for guests with physical limitations. Wheelchairs, electric scooters, and strollers may also be available for rent.

images.altText: Bikes lined up at the rental facility at Yosemite Valley Lodge
images.title: Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand

bodyText:
Yosemite Valley is flat, which makes for easy riding along our 12 miles of designated paths. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. We also offer a select number of tandem bikes and hand-crank bikes for guests with physical limitations. Wheelchairs, electric scooters, and strollers may also available for rent.

All rental bikes are available first-come, first-served - reservations are only available for bicycles intended for people with disabilities.

Before you begin your biking trip, be sure to review the trail map and familiarize yourself with our biking rules. See website for rates.

Hours

Spring through Fall, weather dependent

See website for hours, or call 209/372-1208.

Getting Here

Located on the Yosemite Valley Lodge premises, shuttle bus stop #7, near the swimming pool and post office. 

Rules & Regulations

  • Ride only on paved bicycle paths. Bicycles are not allowed on trails.
  • Riders younger than 18 are required to wear a helmet at all times. However we strongly recommend that all bike-riders wear helmets at all times.
  • Obey all traffic laws and signs.
  • Let pedestrians know when you're passing them.
  • Rental bikes are not permitted on Mirror Lake hill and Lower Yosemite Fall Trail.
  • When riding in groups, please ride single file on the right hand side of the path.
  • Only one rider is allowed per bike. Passengers not permitted including babies.
  • Rental bikes must stay in Yosemite Valley.

Accessibility 

This facility is accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby. Tandem and hand-crank bikes are available for rent, as well as wheelchairs and electric scooters.
audioDescription: The Yosemite Valley Lodge Bike Stand operates out of a small, brown, wood-paneled kiosk. It is located near the pool, behind the main Yosemite Valley Lodge complex. Rows of bikes are parked side by side within a chain linked fence. The bikes are a variety of colors and range in size from larger adult-sized bikes, to smaller child-sized bikes, to tandem bikes, and bikes with trailers for children.

title: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center
listingDescription: Visit the wilderness center to learn about wilderness safety, plan trips, obtain wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters. Free wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness A

images.altText: A rustic brown building with large beams and posts, a shingled roof top and shingled siding
images.title: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center

bodyText:
Visit the Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).

Wilderness Permit Reservations

Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness Act.

Late April through mid-October

Sixty percent of wilderness permit reservations become available by lottery 24 weeks in advance. Of these, any remaining reservations after each week's lottery become available on a first-come, first-served basis the Friday after the lottery application period closes and are available up to three days in advance. The remaining 40% of reservations become available seven days in advance (up to three days in advance).

Late October to mid-April

During late fall through early spring, wilderness permits are available without a reservation and on a self-registration basis. You can get a wilderness permit the day before or day you intend to start your hike at the permit issuing station nearest the trailhead. While trailhead quotas are still in effect, most trailheads don't fill up. Bear canisters are only available for rental at the Exploration Center.

Most of Yosemite is covered in snow during winter. Before planning a wilderness trip during this time, please ensure you're prepared for winter conditions.

John Muir Trail

If you plan to hike the John Muir Trail (JMT) as a continuous hike, you only need one wilderness permit from Yosemite for the entire trip (you do not need a "Whitney stamp" or permits from other national forests or national parks). The only two trailheads that provide access to the full John Muir Trail beyond Yosemite are Happy Isles to Past LYV (Donohue Pass eligible) and Lyell Canyon (Donohue Pass eligible).

  • Learn more from our Frequently Asked Questions
  • Learn more about wilderness conditions and current closures. 

Half Dome Permits

If you're planning to hike to the top of Half Dome, you need a Half Dome permit, which you can request on your wilderness permit application. (This is a different process than if you're planning to day-hike to Half Dome.)

  • Half Dome Permits for Backpackers
  • Half Dome Permits for Day Hikers

Hours

  • May through mid-October: 8am to 5pm daily
  • November through late April: The Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center is closed. Permits are available on a self-registration basis at the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center, from 9am to 5pm.

Phone Hours

From Monday through Friday, 9am to noon and 1pm to 4:30pm, from March through early October you can speak to a wilderness ranger by calling 209/372-0826. 

Getting Here

Located in Yosemite Village, between The Ansel Adams Gallery and the post office. Park at Yosemite Village Parking, it's about a five-minute walk. Or, take the free shuttle to stop 5.

Rules & Regulations

Bear-resistant food canisters are required in Yosemite's Wilderness. Use a canister to store all food or scented items when left unattended. Whenever food or scented items are out, please keep them within arm's reach, even while day hiking. 

Certain bear-resistant portable containers designed for backpackers to store food are allowed for use in Yosemite (however, only the Garcia Backpackers' Cache 812 is available for rental in Yosemite).

Accessibility

This facility is accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located behind the post office which is adjacent to the Wilderness Center.
audioDescription: A rustic brown building with large beams and posts, a shingled roof top and shingled siding, serves as the Yosemite Wilderness Center. Large picture windows are framed with varnished logs, and the rest of the building also has split log trim. A large grey bear canister return bin sits under the porch as well as a bench. A large sign hangs from the porch rafters by chains and reads Yosemite Wilderness Center, with a circular logo that reads Yosemite Wilderness, National Wilderness Preservation System on the left, and the National Park Service logo to the right. The single door entrance is framed in wood and is painted orange.

title: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center Architecture

images.altText: A small single story building with a covered porch, rustic log details, and shingle infill
images.title: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center
images.caption: Yosemite Valley Wilderness Center

bodyText:
Originally named the Pohono Indian Studio, this small building was completed in 1925 during construction of the village. It has served many purposes through the years, including as a photography studio, gift shop, and even briefly as a ranger training center.

While it was built during the rustic era alongside other classic park buildings, this building has limited architectural significance. The log frame and shingle infill are its primary rustic features and have remained almost wholly unchanged since its construction.

title: Yosemite Village Parking
listingDescription: If you're visiting Yosemite Valley for the day, look for parking in the Yosemite Village Parking. This lot is centrally located to lodging, dining, and recreation in Yosemite Valley. Free shuttle service to destinations throughout Yosemite Valley is available from here. Once you find a place to park, please leave your car parked.

images.altText: Cars are parked along a wooden railing. Half Dome can be seen through the trees in the background.

bodyText:
If you're visiting Yosemite Valley for the day, look for parking in the Yosemite Village Parking. This lot is centrally located to lodging, dining, and recreation in Yosemite Valley. Free shuttle service to destinations throughout Yosemite Valley is available from here. Once you find a place to park, please leave your car parked. Using the free shuttles will help you avoid congestion and trouble finding another place to park. Parking fills to capacity throughout Yosemite by mid-morning. Don't forget where you parked your car, as there are multiple parking areas throughout the Valley. Driving or parking on vegetation is prohibited.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
Located in Yosemite Village, in eastern Yosemite Valley.

Rules & Regulations :
Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.
You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Hazards & Warnings:
During the busy summer, you are likely to experience congestion, especially in Yosemite Valley. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive by mid-morning to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility:
There are designated accessible parking spaces near shuttle stop 1 and near the path to Yosemite Village.
audioDescription: The Yosemite Village Parking lot is laid out in a large semi-circle and has four long rows of parking, rows A, B, C, and D. Rows A and B are split into three sections, A1, A2, A3, B1, B2, and B3. Rows C and D are at the inner part of the semi-circle parking lot. A two lane bike and pedestrian path that leads to the visitor center or to Half Dome Village, is located at the north end of the parking lot. Trees line the road and the parking lot. Half Dome is viewable in the distance through the trees.

title: Yosemite Village Post Office
listingDescription:
Mail postcards and letters with the Yosemite National Park postmark to your family and friends.



Hours :
Year-round,
Monday - Friday
8:30am to 5pm,
Saturday
10am to Noon

Getting Here :
Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The post office is also located near shuttle stop 4 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle system.

Accessibility :
This facility is accessible. There are no designated accessible parking spaces available.

images.altText: A two-story building with steps leading up to the front door and trees surrounding
images.title: Yosemite Village Post Office
images.caption: Yosemite Village Post Office

bodyText:
Mail postcards and letters with the Yosemite National Park postmark to your family and friends.

Hours

Year-round
Monday - Friday
8:30am to 5pm
Saturday
10am to Noon

Getting Here

Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The post office is also located near shuttle stop 4 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle system.

Accessibility

This facility is accessible. There are no designated accessible parking spaces available.
audioDescription: An elongated, two-story, building serves as the post office. The first story is made up of granite stonework, while the second story, which slightly overhangs the first story, is made up of wooden shingled siding. The second story has a row of windows with orange frames, while the first story windows and doors all have white frames. The are three sets of double doors with one set of four steps leading up to them, in the middle of the buildings facade. Potted plants hang from the rafters and some also sit on the ground, between each set of doors. Above the middle set of double doors is a wooden sign, that reads Post Office, Yosemite National Park, California, zip code 95389. A small wooden sign attached to the left door of the middle set of double doors reads Open, Monday through Friday, 8:30am to 5pm. A blue mailbox and a bike rack are located to the left of the path that leads to the entrances of the post office. Trees surround the building. A side entrance from the west does not have steps.

title: Yosemite Village Post Office Architecture

images.altText: A two-story building with steps leading up to the front door and trees surrounding
images.title: Yosemite Village Post Office
images.caption: Yosemite Village Post Office

bodyText:
Designed by architect Herbert Maier, who also designed the Museum, the Post Office was completed in 1925.

This building is the first in this tour of a trio of buildings that possess a very similar aesthetic. Along with the Museum and Park Administration Building, these three constructions are all two-story buildings with a stone lower story and overhanging frame second story. Since its construction, the Post Office now has composition shingles on the exterior of the second story in lieu of the original wood shingle finish.
